ARE.overall:
The United Arab Emirates (UAE) ranks 30th on the Commitment to Development Index. Whilst it ranks second on the technology component, it comes bottom for environment, second last for investment, and 35th for security.

When we assess UAE’s performance relative to expectations based on its income level, its overall rank falls to 34th place. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
UAE ranks 13th on the development finance component. It provided 0.38 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development, compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent, placing it in the top 10 for quantity.

On quality, UAE is in the top half of countries. It is highly transparent (reporting its development finance projects to the OECD’s Development Assistance Committee) and untied, and has a high focus on fragile countries. However, it makes little use of multilateral organisations, providing just 3 percent of its development finance in this way (compared to a CDI average of 47 percent).
components.investment:
UAE ranks 37th on the investment component, ranking last on the indicators for business and human rights and anticorruption. It also ranks among the bottom five countries on avoiding financial secrecy.

UAE’s strongest performance is on the indicators for international investment agreements, where it ranks 13th. Its more recent investment treaties contain provisions to ensure that partner countries can pursue their own development objectives. The UAE is mid-table on natural resource governance as it neither supports nor implements the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative.

UAE has most room for improvement by fully engaging with the OECD’s responsible business conduct principles, enforcing the OECD’s Anti-Bribery Convention, and increasing its current corporate tax rate from 9 percent to the globally agreed minimum of 15 percent.
components.migration:
UAE ranks 18th on the migration component, an improvement of 12 places since the last CDI.

It has moved up to second on migrant inflow with a high number of migrants relative to its population and arrivals tending to be from lower-income countries, for which we award a greater weight. However, only around a third of these migrants are female, which is second lowest and far below the CDI average of 48 percent. UAE also ranks in the bottom 10 on its policies to integrate migrants into its society and economy, and for the number of refugees it hosts, which at 0.1 per 1,000 people is less than a fiftieth of the median CDI country.
components.trade:
UAE ranks 22nd on the trade component. It has very few tariff peaks (tariffs of 15 percent or higher), making it one of the top five performers on this indicator. It also ranks in the top half for the quality of its trade infrastructure, and the efficiency of its customs procedures is also above average.

UAE has the most room for improvement on average tariff rates (weighted inversely by the income of trading partners), where it ranks in the bottom half of countries, and it could also improve transparency by publishing data on the level of its agricultural subsidies.
components.environment:
UAE ranks last on the environment component, and it performs in the bottom five countries for its greenhouse gas emissions, fossil fuel production, fossil fuel support, carbon pricing, and fishing subsidies.

UAE is one of just nine CDI countries without any carbon pricing scheme, and we were unable to find data on either fishing subsidies or support for fossil fuel provided by UAE; it therefore ranks joint last on these indicators.

UAE ranks 37th for fossil fuel production, producing oil and natural gas embodying an equivalent of 72.4 tonnes of CO2 per capita (compared to the CDI average of 11.1 tonnes). Its direct domestic greenhouse gas emissions per capita are higher than any other CDI country, at 23.1 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita (compared to a CDI average of 9.1 tonnes). The UAE does appear to intend to reduce these—the ambition embodied in its Nationally Determined Contribution suggests that, by 2030, it plans to reduce its emissions by 44 percent against current business-as-usual projections (above the CDI median of 34 percent).
components.health:
UAE ranks 19th on the health component, up seven places since the last edition of the CDI. It ranks joint 1st for its export restrictions on food and health products, being one of the few countries with zero products restricted in the last two years. UAE comes in the top 10 countries for its vaccination coverage: its coverage by the nationally recommended age is 94 percent for measles (against a CDI median of 92 percent), and its coverage among 1-year-olds is also 96 percent for diphtheria, tetanus toxoid, and pertussis (against a CDI median of 95 percent).

Since the last CDI, UAE has signed up to monitor and report its antibiotic use through the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System on antimicrobial consumption (GLASS-AMC) and now ranks joint top of the health treaties indicator by committing to all seven areas we assess. Still, despite improved governance of antimicrobial resistance, its antibiotic use in humans and livestock remains very high.

The UAE currently ranks in the bottom 10 countries for tackling illicit trade in tobacco. It should sign the Protocol against Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products and complete the relevant monitoring exercise on tobacco supply chains.
components.security:
UAE ranks 35th on the security component, and it comes in the bottom 10 on every indicator.

It ranks 32nd for its troop and financial contributions to global peacekeeping missions (equivalent to 0.007 percent of GNI, under half the CDI average of 0.019 percent)—and this is entirely due to financial contributions to the UN as it contributes no troops to either UN or non-UN peacekeeping missions. UAE did not contribute any vessels to sea lanes protection, and so also ranks joint last here (on average CDI countries allocate the equivalent of 0.019 percent GNI to sea lanes protection).

UAE ranks 29th for its arms trade. It does not publish consolidated official data on the volume of its arms exports, and available data suggest that the degree to which they are sold to countries that are poor, militaristic, or undemocratic is only slightly higher than the CDI median. However, there are ongoing investigations into allegations that the UAE is covertly supplying the Sudanese Rapid Support Forces in contravention of a UN arms embargo—a charge denied by Abu Dhabi.
components.technology:
UAE ranks second on the technology component. This is largely due to its stand-out performance in the number of foreign students it welcomes (when weighted by the income level of their origin countries). However, it does not publish data on what proportion of these are female and so receives the minimum on that indicator (34 percent compared to a CDI average of 49 percent). UAE also comes in the top five for including researchers from lower-income countries in its international research teams. It ranks in the top half of countries for intellectual property rights, as its trade agreements are not too restrictive and allow useful knowledge to spread to developing countries. Together, these indicators show UAE performing strongly in terms of policies to diffuse and share technology.

However, UAE performs less well for its policies to encourage technology creation. No data was available for its government spending on research and development, nor for its tax incentives to private researchers. This missing data pulls down UAE’s performance on the technology component.

ARG.overall:
Argentina ranks 38th in the Commitment to Development Index overall. Its best performances are on technology (for which it ranks 21st) and migration (27th). It has the most scope for improvement on health (38th) and trade (37th).

When assessed relative to expectations based on its income level, Argentina’s rank rises to 36th place. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Argentina ranks 33rd in the development finance component, though this rises to 22nd when adjusting scores for income.

Argentina provided only 0.01 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development, among the five lowest of any CDI country and less than several other countries with similar incomes.

Argentina ranks 26th on the quality of its development finance. Very little information is provided about its finance activities—meaning it ranks bottom on transparency—but it appears that little of its bilateral finance is allocated to poor and fragile countries. Its score is helped by the fact that most of Argentina’s development finance (86 percent) is provided through multilaterals. There was no data on which to assess the extent to which Argentina provides finance in line with country priorities.
components.investment:
Argentina ranks 36th on the investment component, with a mixed performance across indicators.

Argentina ranks joint 1st on the new corporate tax rate alignment indicator: the lowest available corporate income tax rate in the country is above the 25 percent average in low- and middle-income countries (and well above the globally agreed effective minimum of 15 percent). Meanwhile, it performs akin to the median CDI country for its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention and engagement with the OECD guidelines for responsible business conduct.

Argentina ranks in the bottom half on international investment agreements, indicating that its investment treaties do not provide much policy space for partner countries to pursue their development objectives. Furthermore, it ranks in the bottom five for its natural resource governance (Argentina is one of only three countries in the CDI that does not participate in the Kimberley Process on trade in conflict diamonds). It is also in the bottom five countries for financial secrecy.
components.migration:
Argentina ranks 27th on the migration component.

It ranks in the bottom 10 countries for the number of refugees it hosts relative to its population size. According to the latest UN data, Argentina has also seen a lower inflow of migrants per head of population relative to other CDI countries, although those arrivals have come from countries with relatively low levels of income. A high proportion of Argentina’s migrants are female, and it tops this indicator.

Argentina ranks in the top half of countries for its migrant integration policies, and though it ranks joint 10th for its ratification of international conventions aiming to protect migrants, it has not ratified the International Labour Organization’s (ILO) Migrant Workers Convention or the Migration for Employment Convention.

Argentina could accept substantially more migrants and should ensure that migrants’ rights are protected by ratifying the relevant ILO conventions. It should also aim to increase the number of refugees it hosts.
components.trade:
Argentina ranks 37th on trade.

Though Argentina ranks top on avoiding agricultural subsidies, giving just 0.2 percent of the value of farm production (the CDI average is 12.6 percent), it performs much worse on the other indicators. It has the second highest average tariff rates (weighted inversely by the income of trading partners) and the largest number of tariff peaks (tariffs on product lines of 15 percent or higher). According to the World Bank, Argentina also has some of the lowest-quality trade logistics among CDI countries, ranking in the bottom five for both its customs procedures and trade infrastructure.

Argentina could improve its own economic performance as well as its contribution to development by ensuring that its trade processes are simple and by reducing tariffs, especially for poorer countries.
components.environment:
Argentina ranks 32nd on the environment component. Its best performance is on the fishing subsidies indicator, where it was one of only six CDI countries for which fishing subsidies were negative (indicating that the fisheries sector made more payments than it received), reducing the risk of stock depletion due to overfishing. Since we updated data for this edition of the CDI, Argentina has also signed the WTO Agreement on Fisheries Subsidies. Argentina’s greenhouse gas emissions are below average (7.8 tonnes CO2 equivalent per capita, compared to a CDI average of 10.2 tonnes) though its Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) is not very ambitious—by 2030 Argentina plans to reduce its emissions by 12 percent relative to expected emissions based on GDP growth (the CDI median is a reduction of 34 percent).

Argentina has significantly reduced its subsidy support to fossil fuel production and consumption in the last few years, and consequently ranks 20th, up from 36th in the previous CDI, though fossil fuel production has remained steady relative to the size of its population. Its carbon pricing schemes added just $0.59 on average to the cost of emitting one tonne of CO2—well below the CDI average of $15.23. Argentina should reduce its negative impact on the environment by continuing to reduce its subsidies to and production of fossil fuels, and by raising its carbon price.
components.health:
Argentina ranks 38th on the health component.

Its best performance is on pandemic preparedness, where it ranks joint 4th. However, Argentina ranks joint last for its regulation of tobacco supply chains, and bottom for the export restrictions it imposed on food and health products over the last two years. It also ranks bottom for its vaccination coverage: immunization coverage by the nationally recommended age is just 54 percent for measles (against a CDI median of 92 percent), and coverage among one-year-olds is 66 percent for diphtheria, tetanus toxoid, and pertussis (against a CDI median of 95 percent).
components.security:
Argentina ranks 34th on the security component.

Argentina’s total contributions to peacekeeping were equivalent to 0.006 percent of its GNI, which is less than half the CDI average of 0.019 percent, meaning Argentina is in the bottom five on this indicator. That said, the proportion of Argentina’s UN peacekeepers that are female is slightly higher than the CDI average (14 percent compared to 13 percent).

Argentina contributed no vessels to sea lanes protection, placing it joint last on this indicator, and no data was available on the volume and composition of Argentina’s arms exports. Argentina should become a party to the Convention on Cluster Munitions.
components.technology:
Argentina ranks 21st for technology, making this its strongest component.

Argentina generally performs well for its policies to diffuse and share technology. Although it ranks in the bottom half of countries for the number of foreign students it welcomes (when weighted by the income level of their origin countries) relative to the size of its tertiary student population, the proportion of those foreign students that are female is the highest in the CDI at 61 percent. It does well on research collaboration, indicating that research collaborations are more likely to be with academics from relatively poorer countries than most other CDI countries. Additionally, its free trade agreements are assessed as containing fewer intellectual property rights clauses that are more restrictive than World Trade Organization standards than most CDI countries.

Argentina performs worse on its policies to encourage knowledge creation. It ranks in the bottom five for its tax incentives to private researchers, and it is one of only three CDI countries that tax rather than subsidise private research and development (R&D). Argentina is also in the bottom 10 countries for its direct government spending on R&D, allocating 0.34 percent of GNI compared to the CDI average of 0.55 percent.

AUS.overall:
Australia comes 15th on the Commitment to Development Index, a slight improvement on its position in the 2023 edition of the CDI, thanks in part to improvements in its development finance. Its best performance is on trade, where it ranks 2nd. It also performs well on technology and health (3rd and 5th, respectively). It has the most room for improvement on environment, where it ranks in the bottom five.

When we assess Australia relative to expectations based on its income level, it falls seven places to 22nd. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Australia ranks 23rd in the development finance component, falling to 35th after we adjust the score for its relatively high income.

Australia ranks mid-table for the quantity of development finance it provides, giving 0.18 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development, compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent. Notably, Australia has committed not to cut its development budget, in contrast to many other donors.

The quality of this finance is mixed. Australia’s focus on countries in the Indo-Pacific means that its finance is not directed towards poorer countries, and the relatively small proportion channelled through multilateral institutions is lower than the CDI average—22 percent compared to the CDI average of 47 percent. Despite this, it reports transparently and does not tie any of its aid to bids from Australian contractors (one of only four CDI countries with no tied aid whatsoever).
components.investment:
Australia ranks 9th in the investment component.

Australia does well on its natural resource governance. It is a member of the Kimberley Process on conflict diamonds and supports the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. It ranks joint 3rd for its anti-corruption efforts, where its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention is assessed as “moderate” by Transparency International. Its corporate income tax rate is also higher than both the average in low- and middle-income countries of 25 percent, and the globally agreed effective minimum of 15 percent, meaning it is less likely than other CDI countries to be used to facilitate corporate tax avoidance by large multinational enterprises.

Still, Australia ranks in the bottom half of countries on limiting financial secrecy: it could improve by requiring multinationals incorporated in the country to submit country-by-country reporting on their activities, as well as bringing its anti-money laundering regime more in line with the recommendations of the Financial Action Task Force. It should also ensure that its bilateral investment agreements with lower-income countries afford counterparts more policy space to pursue their development objectives than average across the CDI.
components.migration:
Australia ranks 25th in the migration component.

Australia hosts just one refugee per 1,000 people, half the level in 2022, and well-below the CDI average of 11, meaning it ranks 27th on this indicator. It ranks mid-table for the number of migrants it accepts from poorer countries relative to its population, though a higher proportion of the migrants it does accept are women (52 percent, compared to a CDI average of 48 percent). Australia ranks in the bottom half of the table for its hosting of refugees, and has faced criticism over the illegal offshore processing and detention of asylum seekers.

Australia ranks in the top 10 for its domestic policies to encourage the integration of migrants into society and the economy, but it should sign the International Labour Organization’s conventions on Migrant Workers and Migration for Employment and complete a review of its implementation of the UN Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Australia ranks 2nd in trade, with a consistently strong performance across all areas assessed under this component.

Australia has particularly low tariffs against poorer countries and no tariff peaks (product lines with tariff rates of 15 percent or higher). Its trade logistics are good, ranked 11th with high-quality infrastructure and a good customs regime. Australia’s trade in services is relatively unrestricted. Furthermore, it ranks 5th for its low level of trade-distorting agricultural subsidies: at 2.8 percent of farm-gate production value, they are much lower than the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
Australia ranks 35th in the environment component, its weakest by some margin.

Australia has the fifth-highest greenhouse gas emissions of any CDI country, totalling 17.5 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita compared to a CDI average of 10.2 tonnes. Its direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry contributed 19.2 tonnes of the total—lower than only the UAE and Saudi Arabia—but it has negative emissions embodied in its international trade. Its current Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) also suggests that it lacks climate ambition compared to most CDI countries (coming in at 29th)—achieving its NDC target would represent a reduction in emissions of roughly 29 percent below its expected emissions in 2030 based on GDP growth.

Australia ranks 35th for its fossil fuel production, with particularly high coal production—around four and a half times more per capita than the next largest producer. It also gives a significant amount of support to the production and consumption of fossil fuels, particularly for oil, though less than the CDI average.

On a positive note, Australia doesn’t give harmful subsidies to its fishing industry; instead, it effectively applies a tax worth 2 percent of the production value, and in October 2023, it accepted the WTO’s Agreement on Fishing Subsidies.
components.health:
Australia ranks 5th in the health component.

Australia ranks in the top quarter on antimicrobial resistance (AMR): antibiotic consumption in livestock is among the lowest and it has strong AMR governance, having completed a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization. However, antibiotic consumption in humans is higher than the average of CDI countries.

Australia ranks joint top for both its pandemic preparedness and its (lack of) export restrictions on health and food products. It also does reasonably well for vaccination coverage, with immunization coverage for both measles and diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis higher than the CDI averages.

Australia could further strengthen its commitment to international health by better regulating international tobacco supply chains (by signing and implementing the WHO Protocol on Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products) and participating in more international health agreements, such as the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System module on antimicrobial consumption.
components.security:
Australia ranks 24th in the security component.

Australia ranks mid-table for its peacekeeping contributions: though it makes relatively large financial contributions to the UN, it does not provide as many troops for UN or non-UN peacekeeping missions as the average CDI country. That said, of the UN peacekeepers it does send, almost 30 percent are female, the third-highest proportion among CDI countries.

Australia’s arms exports are worth 0.41 percent of its GNI, reflecting a significant increase in the last few years, and its trading partners also have a higher conflict potential (are poorer, more militaristic, and less democratic). However, Australia has signed all security conventions we assess, ranking joint 1st on the indicator.
components.technology:
Australia ranks 3rd in the technology component.

Australia ranks in the bottom half of the table for its policies to support knowledge production. Its government provides direct support for research and development (R&D) worth 0.40 percent of GNI (below the CDI average of 0.55 percent), and it also provides tax incentives for private business R&D, worth a further 0.16 percent of GNI. Though this is still below the CDI average of 0.19 percent, it marks an improvement since the 2023 CDI.

Australia performs better than average on its policies to encourage the diffusion of knowledge. It does well by accepting a large number of foreign students from poorer countries relative to its tertiary student population (ranking second only to the UAE), though these students are marginally less likely to be female (48 percent) than in most CDI countries. Australia does reasonably well on research collaboration, ranking 12th for the proportion of international publications its academics co-publish with academics from lower-income countries. Its trade agreements with lower-income countries also leave a fair amount of policy space for technology transfers, with fewer than average intellectual property rights restrictions that go beyond World Trade Organization standards.

AUT.overall:
Austria ranks 6th on the Commitment to Development Index, coming in the top half on all components except development finance. Its strongest performances are on technology and security (ranking 5th for both).

When we assess Austria relative to expectations based on its income level, its overall rank falls to 9th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Austria ranks 20th on development finance, and after income-adjusting, its score falls by nine ranks to 28th.

Although it ranks in the top half for development finance quantity, providing 0.27 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development in 2024, which is slightly above the CDI average of 0.28 percent, Austria ranks in the bottom half of the table for the quality of its international development finance. While it scores well for transparency and for the high share of finance disbursed through multilateral agencies, Austria should improve its focus on poor and fragile states in its bilateral finance, do more to ensure its development projects align with recipient priorities, and make more of its development projects open to bids from contractors from other nationalities.
components.investment:
Austria ranks 15th on investment. Its rank on the corporate tax rate alignment indicator fell from joint top in the 2023 CDI to mid-table, following a decision by the previous government to cut its rate from 25 percent to 23 percent (compared to the CDI average of 18 percent, and exceeding the globally agreed minimum of 15 percent). It performs well on measures to prevent financial secrecy, ranking 7th.

Austria ranks mid-table for a number of other investment indicators. Its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention has been assessed as “limited” by Transparency International. It comes joint 15th for its natural resource governance; though it participates in the Kimberly Process, Austria does not support or implement the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. Austria ranks joint 24th for its engagement with the OECD’s responsible business conduct principles, and 24th on the international investment agreements, which measures the degree to which clauses in bilateral investment agreements impinge on the policy space to pursue development objectives of poorer countries.
components.migration:
Austria ranks 7th on migration. It ranks 4th on refugee hosting, with 29 refugees per 1,000 people, almost three times the CDI average; most of the refugees it hosts are from Syria, Ukraine, and Afghanistan. It has also recently increased the number of non-refugee migrants it accepts relative to its population size (when weighted higher for origin countries with lower incomes) and ranks in the top 10 on that indicator. Half of Austria’s migrants are female, up from 46 percent in the previous CDI. However, it is in the bottom half of countries for its domestic migrant integration policies in areas like education, health, and the economy.

Austria also ranks joint last on its participation in international conventions aiming to protect migrants. It has not ratified the Migration for Employment Convention or the Migrant Workers Convention, and has not submitted a voluntary review of its progress against the objectives of the UN Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Austria ranks 14th in the trade component. Along with other EU members, its tariff rates (when weighted inversely to trading partner income) are low, and it has fewer tariff peaks than average (the number of tariff lines with rates over 15 percent). Austria also ranks within the top half of countries for its trade logistics systems; the quality of both its customs procedures and trade infrastructure is above average. It has the most room to improve on its trade barriers for services, for which it ranks 23rd.

Austria could also improve on its agricultural subsidies, where it ranks 19th. Currently worth 11.6 percent of farm production value, these subsidies (mainly agreed at EU level) have fallen since the last CDI and are slightly below the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
Austria ranks 12th on the environment component. As a landlocked country, its government provides no harmful subsidies to the fishing industry. It has also signed and fulfilled its monitoring requirements on all biodiversity and environmental agreements assessed, except for national reporting under the Convention on Biological Diversity (placing it joint 15th on this indicator).

Austria ranks 20th for its current greenhouse gas emissions, with direct emissions of 7.7 tonnes of CO₂ equivalent per capita (which compares to the CDI average of 9.1 tonnes), but with a higher-than-average value of emissions embodied in its international trade. Still, as part of the EU, Austria has relatively high climate target ambition, and ranks joint 11th for the ambition of its Nationally Determined Contribution: by 2030, the EU jointly plans to reduce its emissions by 34 percent against expected emissions based on GDP growth.

Austria ranks in the top half of the table for providing low financial support to the domestic consumption and production of fossil fuels (rank 14), as well as on its fossil fuel production (rank 15). It produces no coal, while its gas and oil production embodies emissions worth roughly 0.5 tonnes of CO2 per capita (below the CDI average of 10.8 tonnes). Austria ranks 7th for the price it imposes on its carbon emissions, which stands at $29.52 per average tonne—a doubling in two years and well above the CDI average of $15.23.
components.health:
Austria ranks 14th in the health component. It ranks joint 5th for its participation in health treaties, codes, and memberships, and also joint 5th for its regulation of international tobacco supply chains. Austria ranks 7th on antimicrobial resistance: its antibiotic consumption is below the CDI average in humans (11.0 defined daily doses per 1,000 people, versus the CDI average of 19.2) and even more so in livestock (17.1 milligrams per kilogram of livestock animal, versus the CDI average of 53.5). And it is approximately the median CDI country in terms of its export restrictions on food and health products: relatively few products are restricted, but the restrictions lasted for a majority of the last two years.

However, Austria ranks amongst the 10 worst-performing countries for pandemic preparedness and also ranks relatively poorly for vaccine coverage. It can particularly improve its vaccination coverage for diphtheria, tetanus toxoid, and pertussis among one-year-olds, which is 84 percent (below the CDI median of 95 percent). Meanwhile, its preparedness for pandemics could be improved by completing a Joint External Evaluation and Simulation Exercise with the World Health Organization, updating its National Influenza Plan, and completing a Performance of Veterinary Services evaluation with the World Organisation for Animal Health.

Security

Austria ranks 5th on security. It has ratified all nine international security conventions we assess, and it also performs strongly (ranking 5th) on peacekeeping contributions, with troop and finance contributions to global peacekeeping efforts amounting to an equivalent of 0.037 percent of its GNI—about double the CDI average. However, of the UN peacekeepers it deploys, only 5 percent are women—less than half the CDI average of 13 percent.

Austria ranks 11th on its arms trade. The value of its arms exports is below the CDI average (equivalent to 0.15 percent of GNI, versus a median of 0.18 percent) and these sales have a low incidence of poor, militaristic, and undemocratic countries in their destinations.
components.security: placeholder
components.technology:
Austria ranks 5th on technology, making this its joint best component.

Austria has strong performance across indicators which assess its support for the production of new knowledge. It ranks 2nd on direct government support for research and development (R&D) as its central budget expenditure on R&D amounts to 1.08 percent of its GNI, almost double the CDI average of 0.55 percent. It also ranks 11th for tax incentives for business R&D, which are equivalent to 0.29 percent of GNI (above the CDI average of 0.19 percent).

However, Austria should do more to diffuse and share its technology. While Austria welcomes a large number of foreign students, 54 percent of whom are female, they are among the least likely to originate from poorer countries. It performs in the bottom half of countries on intellectual property rights (alongside other EU countries): the free trade agreements with developing country counterparts which it is party to as an EU member tend to be more restrictive on intellectual property rights than required by World Trade Organization standards. Further, researchers from poorer countries are not well represented in its international research publications, and Austria is the worst-performing country on the research collaboration indicator.

BEL.overall:
Belgium ranks 13th on the Commitment to Development Index. It scores well on development finance, migration, and health, ranking in the top 10 for each. However, its performance is middling across the other components. Its lowest ranks are on the investment and security components (26th in each) due to the lack of development policy space it provides in its international investment agreements with lower-income countries and its lack of corporate tax rate alignment in the former and relatively high volume of arms exports in the latter.

When we assess Belgium relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank drops to 15th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Belgium ranks 5th on development finance. It scores well on development finance quantity, providing 0.40 percent of GNI in Finance for International Development—above the CDI average of 0.28 percent—but its high rank is driven primarily by the quality of that finance, for which it ranks 3rd.

Belgium’s development finance had the highest “poverty focus” of all CDI countries, meaning it targets countries that are poorer on average than any other CDI country. Belgium was among the countries most transparent about its development finance activities (along with other members of the Development Assistance Committee), and nearly all of Belgium’s aid contracts are open to bidders from other countries, making its finance largely untied. Belgium has most room for improvement on country ownership, the only measure on which it is in the bottom half, ranking 28th. It should ensure it provides finance in line with the priorities of its partner countries.
components.investment:
Belgium ranks 26th on the investment component. Its worst score is on the corporate tax rate alignment indicator, for which it ranks 34th. Belgium is currently reforming its tax system, but as of 2022, its lowest available corporate tax rate was just 3 percent—significantly lower than the globally agreed 15 percent minimum.

However, Belgium is among the best performers on financial secrecy, ranking 3rd, with strict requirements on banking transparency and for companies to report country-by-country activities. It participates in the Kimberley Process to eliminate conflict diamonds and supports transparency in the extractives industry.

However, Belgium has limited to no enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and scores below the CDI average on the degree of policy space to pursue development objectives in its bilateral international investment agreements with lower-income country counterparts.

To improve its performance, Belgium should raise its corporate income tax rates, ensure that future investment treaties leave space for partner countries to pursue development objectives, and make greater efforts to ensure bribery is not tolerated.
components.migration:
Belgium ranks 4th on migration, up from 7th in the 2023 CDI, and ranking in the top half for all migration indicators. It has some of the best policies for helping migrants to integrate (ranking 7th), has fully ratified the International Labour Organization (ILO) Migration for Employment Convention, and has completed a voluntary review of its implementation of the UN Global Compact for Migration. It should, however, ensure migrants’ rights are protected by ratifying the ILO Migrant Workers Convention.

Belgium has significantly increased the number of migrants it accepts relative to its population, from under 9 per 1,000 people two years ago to 16 per 1,000 people now. These migrants tend to come from countries with lower incomes than for the typical CDI country, meaning Belgium ranks 5th on the inward migration indicator. Belgium hosts slightly more refugees than the majority of CDI countries, at almost 15 refugees per 1,000 population, compared to a CDI average of 11.
components.trade:
Belgium ranks 11th on trade. Along with other EU members, it ranks joint 4th and joint 7th on the tariffs and tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more) indicators, respectively, with EU tariffs generally low and including several exemptions for poorer countries. However, Belgium has scope to reduce the restrictiveness of its trade in services, where it comes in the bottom half of CDI countries (particularly in the accounting and air transport sectors).

Belgium also provides significant agricultural subsidies mostly agreed at the EU level (worth 13.3 percent of farm gate production value, compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent), putting agricultural exporters from lower-income countries at a disadvantage.
components.environment:
Belgium places 23rd on the environment component. Belgium is one of only five CDI countries to have ratified all environmental treaties included in the CDI, and it is up to date on existing reporting commitments to, for example, the Convention on Biological Diversity. It also performs well in fossil fuel production: Belgium does not produce any coal and negligible amounts of natural gas, but it does produce small amounts of oil.

However, Belgium’s score is hampered by significant greenhouse gas emissions per capita: its direct domestic emissions have fallen to 8.3 tonnes CO2 equivalent per person compared to a CDI country average of 9.1, but it has significant emissions embodied in its international trade—the second-most of any CDI country. Its environmental performance is further held back by the subsidies it provides for oil and gas, both above the CDI averages.
components.health:
Belgium ranks 9th on the health component. It ranks in the top 10 on international tobacco supply chains, having signed, ratified, and reported on its implementation of key treaties regulating the tobacco trade. It also performs well on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) governance, ranking in the top five; its national AMR action plan identifies funding and is being implemented, and it scores well on AMR within its Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization. It has also signed up to the global antimicrobial resistance and use surveillance system, reflecting its broader participation in health codes and treaties, for which it ranks joint 5th.

Belgium should push for the EU to lift its export restrictions on food and health products, which are among the highest in the CDI. Although relatively few lines are covered by these restrictions, they have remained in place over much of the last two years.
components.security:
Belgium ranks 26th on the security component. It has ratified all international security treaties for which the CDI gives credit, ranking joint 1st on that indicator.

Belgium’s financial and troop contributions to peacekeeping are worth roughly 0.012 percent of its GNI, below the CDI average of 0.019 percent (making Belgium 23rd on peacekeeping), and the proportion of peacekeepers it does deploy who are women is low at 5 percent. However, it makes additional contributions to sea lanes protection, with the value of deployed vessels worth 0.016 percent of GNI.

Belgium has significant room for improvement on the arms trade indicator. Although the destinations of Belgian arms exports are not as fragile or conflict-prone as those of most other CDI countries, the volume of Belgium’s arms exports—0.39 percent of its GNI—is double the CDI median of 0.18 percent of GNI.
components.technology:
Belgium ranks 15th on the technology component. Belgium’s government provides direct support for research and development (R&D) worth 0.58 percent of its GNI, which is slightly above the CDI average. However, it comes in the top 10 countries on providing tax incentives for private business R&D, with implied subsidies worth 0.35 percent of GNI, almost double the CDI average.

On indicators measuring technology transfer and diffusion policies, Belgium displays mixed performance. It ranks in the higher end for the proportion of foreign students it admits from poorer countries. At 59 percent, the proportion of its foreign student population that is female is second highest of all CDI countries. However, its research collaborations are slightly less likely to be with lower-income-country researchers than the CDI average, and, along with other EU countries, its trade agreements with lower-income countries are restrictive beyond World Trade Organization standards when it comes to intellectual property rights, hindering the spread of useful knowledge.

BRA.overall:
Brazil ranks 31st on the Commitment to Development Index—the third-highest rank of the BRICS+ countries. Brazil’s strongest components are investment (10th) and technology (20th), and it has the most room for improvement on trade and development finance, where it comes in the bottom five countries.

When we assess Brazil relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises by eight places to 23rd. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Brazil ranks 36th in the development finance component.

Brazil ranks in the bottom five countries on quantity, giving less than a tenth of the CDI average in Finance for International Development, at 0.02 percent of its GNI.

Brazil also ranks near the bottom for the quality of its finance: its bilateral finance is not reported very transparently and is generally not targeted at the poorest or most fragile countries. It provides 58 percent of its finance through multilateral agencies, higher than the average but a significant reduction from 95 percent in the 2023 CDI.
components.investment:
Brazil ranks 10th on investment—by far the best performance of the BRICS+. It jumps to 3rd when we adjust Brazil's score for income.

Brazil’s corporate income tax rate is higher than both the globally agreed effective minimum of 15 percent and the developing country average rate of 25 percent, meaning it is unlikely to be used to facilitate tax avoidance by large multinational enterprises. Brazil also tops the indicator on international investment agreements; its bilateral investment agreements also leave a significant degree of policy space for its partner countries to pursue their own development objectives.

There are, however, a number of ways that Brazil could further improve its investment policy to capitalise on its good performance. It ranks 35th on financial secrecy and should focus on reducing the secrecy of its banking regulations and on strengthening its anti-money laundering policies. Although it participates in the Kimberley Process, it should also become a member of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative to improve its natural resources governance. Brazil could also improve its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, which is currently assessed as “limited” by Transparency International.
components.migration:
Brazil ranks 30th on the migration component, rising to 18th when its score is adjusted for income. It ranks in the bottom 10 countries for the number of migrants it accepts (when weighted by the income of their origin countries), and the proportion that are female is 46 percent, just below the CDI average of 48 percent. Since the last CDI, it has significantly increased the number of refugees it hosts, although it remains below average with just over 1 refugee per 1,000 people in the most recent data year, compared to the CDI average of 11.

Brazil has good domestic policies to help migrants integrate into society and the economy, ranking joint 10th. It could improve its support for migrants by signing the International Labour Organization’s Convention on Migrant Workers and completing a voluntary review of its implementation of the Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Brazil ranks 36th on trade, making this its joint weakest component in the CDI. It has significant room to improve on its tariffs against poorer countries: it has high average tariff rates with fewer exemptions for less developed trade partners than the CDI average, and a high number of tariff peaks (product lines with tariffs of 15 percent or higher). Its trade logistics are relatively poor, both for its customs regime and its trade infrastructure as assessed by the World Bank, and its trade in services is also highly restricted as assessed by the OECD.

Positively, Brazil ranks in the top five countries on avoiding agricultural subsidies. It gives only 2.0 percent of farm gate production value in trade-distorting agricultural subsidies, compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
Brazil ranks 28th in the environment component.

Brazil ranks 13th for its greenhouse gas emissions: its direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry were 5.7 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per person compared to the CDI average of 9.1. It also has the second-highest emissions per capita (1.9 tonnes of CO2 equivalent) from land use change and forestry, and ranks 26th for its production of fossil fuels per capita.

Brazil is one of only nine CDI countries with no carbon pricing scheme, meaning it ranks joint last for this indicator. It has signed all the biodiversity and environment agreements considered in the CDI, although its acceptance of the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fishing Subsidies was after the CDI data was updated.
components.health:
Brazil ranks 28th in the health component. It has among the weakest vaccination coverage in the CDI, with coverage for the measles and the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccinations standing at 64 percent and 90 percent respectively—a significant improvement on two years ago, but still not back to pre-COVID levels and World Health Organization targets. Brazil also imposed significant export restrictions on medical product lines in the past two years and comes in the bottom 10 on this indicator.

Brazil ranks 28th on antimicrobial resistance (AMR): consumption of antibiotics in humans and livestock in Brazil is approximately equal to the CDI average, and Brazil could improve its AMR governance by completing a Joint External Evaluation (JEE) with the World Health Organization and updating its national action plan on AMR. Completing a JEE would also contribute to improving its pandemic preparedness, and signing up to the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System module on antimicrobial consumption (GLASS-AMC) would mean it ranked top on the health treaties indicator—and would likely lead to better performance on AMR.
components.security:
Brazil ranks 25th in the security component. Its peacekeeping contributions were worth an equivalent of 0.002 percent of its GNI, less than one-tenth of the CDI average. That said, of the peacekeepers it sent on UN missions, 17 percent were female; this represents continued significant progress and means Brazil now ranks 10th on the indicator, up from 29th since the 2023 edition of the CDI.

Brazil ranks in the top five for its arms trade with a low volume (worth 0.06 percent of GNI compared to a median of 0.18 percent), and it appears that these exports were less likely to go to conflict-prone countries (poorer, more militaristic, and less democratic) than were other countries’ exports. However, it should publish data on destinations of its arms exports and improve its commitment to global security by signing the Convention on Cluster Munitions.
components.technology:
Brazil ranks 20th in the technology component.

Brazil’s government allocates 0.63 percent of GNI directly to research and development (R&D), and a further 0.07 percent in tax incentives for private business R&D.

Brazil does less well for the number of foreign students it accepts—among CDI countries, Brazil has the third-lowest share of foreign students in its total student population, though they were more likely to come from lower-income countries. Of the students it accepts, 46 percent are female, compared to a CDI average of 49 percent. Brazil ranks in the higher end of the table on intellectual property rights: its free trade agreements with lower-income countries contain fewer additional intellectual property rights restrictions beyond existing World Trade Organization standards than the CDI average.

CAN.overall:
Canada ranks 8th on the Commitment to Development Index and is the 4th best performer among the G20 economies. It performs particularly well on the investment, technology, and migration components, where it ranks in the top 10. It has the most room for improvement on the environment component (34th)—the only component for which it ranks in the bottom half of the table.

When we assess Canada relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank falls by two places to 10th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Canada ranks 17th in the development finance component.

Canada contributed 0.24 percent of its GNI in cross-border, grant-equivalent Finance for International Development, slightly less than the CDI average of 0.28 percent, coming in at 18th most generous of CDI countries relative to the size of its economy. The quality of that finance is ranked 20th: Canada reports regularly and transparently on its bilateral finance, its projects are open to bids from contractors from other countries, and it is relatively well targeted at poor and fragile countries. However, Canada spends a relatively small proportion (26 percent) of its aid through multilateral channels.
components.investment:
Canada ranks 3rd on investment, making this its strongest area. Its strongest performance is on its bilateral investment agreements, where it ranks 2nd, indicating that these include few clauses to protect its investors at the expense of the host country’s policy space to pursue development objectives. Other areas of strength include Canada’s commitment to natural resource governance investment standards, and its corporate income tax rate, which exceeds the average of lower- and middle-income countries (25 percent) and the globally agreed effective minimum of 15 percent, meaning it is less likely to be used to facilitate corporate tax avoidance by large multinational enterprises than most CDI countries.

Still, Canada has room for improvement on business and human rights and should adopt a National Action Plan on the subject. Transparency International has assessed Canada as having “limited” enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention. Canada should also do more to limit its financial secrecy, especially its beneficial ownership regulations and agreements on automatic exchange of information with other jurisdictions.
components.migration:
Canada ranks 8th on the migration component: it has significantly increased the number of migrants it accepts in recent years, from under five per 1,000 people to over 10 in the latest figures. That said, Canada has announced a sharp reduction in its targets for new permanent residents. Its immigrants also tend to be from lower-income countries, meaning that it now ranks 7th on the inward migration indicator. Just over half of migrants are women (50 percent), above the CDI average of 48 percent, and its domestic policies to encourage the integration of migrants into society and the economy are fourth-best in the CDI.

Canada ranks 23rd for its hosting of refugees with 5 refugees per 1,000 people; this is well below the CDI average of 11 per 1,000 people.

Canada can also improve by ratifying the International Labour Organization’s conventions on Migrant Workers and Migration for Employment.
components.trade:
Canada ranks 12th in the trade component, maintaining its improvement on its 2021 CDI performance that saw improvements in trade logistics. It has the 2nd best trade logistics of all CDI countries, as well as relative strengths in limiting agricultural subsidies, which fell slightly in recent years (to 5.2 percent of farm gate production value, compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent). It performs above most countries on limiting restrictions on trade in services (ranking 17th on this indicator).

Canada’s performance is held back by its relatively high average tariff rates (when inversely weighted by trading partner income), for which it ranks 27th, and by the number of tariff peaks it imposes (product lines with tariffs of 15 percent or higher), which, although somewhat improved, still mean it ranks 29th of all CDI countries; it should reduce these to enable trade with lower-income countries.
components.environment:
Canada ranks 34th in the environment component, with ample room for improvement on reducing its greenhouse gas emissions, fossil fuel production, and fishing subsidies.

Although emissions embodied in Canada’s international trade are negative, it produced almost double the CDI average in direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry at 17.5 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita (compared to a CDI average of 9.1). Canada’s Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) shows a high degree of ambition on climate, suggesting it plans to reduce emissions by 45 percent below what it is expected to emit in 2030, or almost 40 percent lower than its current emissions, ranking as the second most ambitious country. Still, it is unclear if Canada can meet this target given current policies. The CO2 per capita embodied in its fossil fuel production is over three times higher than the CDI average, and it ranks mid-table on carbon pricing, with the average tonne of CO2 emissions priced at an additional $13.85, slightly below the CDI average of $15.23.

Canada provides harmful subsidies to the fishing industry equivalent to over 9 percent of the production value, higher than most CDI countries for which we have comprehensive data. To improve, it should reduce these subsidies and build on the progress of rejoining the International Tropical Timber Organisation in 2023 by ratifying the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals.
components.health:
Canada ranks 13th in the health component. It does well on pandemic preparedness, ranking joint 1st, but has a middling performance on most other indicators.

Canada has made a number of improvements in antimicrobial resistance since the last edition of the CDI. It has become a member of the antimicrobial consumption module of the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System (GLASS-AMC), meaning it now ranks joint 21st for its participation in health treaties. Canada has published data on antimicrobial consumption rates showing an improvement, and it has published a new National Action Plan on AMR.

Canada ranks in the bottom 10 for its vaccination coverage: an immunization rate of 79 percent for measles is much lower than the CDI median of 92 percent.
components.security:
Canada ranks 16th in the security component. Its contributions of troops and finance to peacekeeping missions, worth 0.011 percent of its GNI, are below the CDI average of 0.019 percent—although the troops it sends on UN peacekeeping missions include the second-highest proportion of women, at almost 30 percent. Canada has also ratified all the security treaties assessed in the CDI, meaning it ranks joint 1st on the security treaties indicator.

Canada’s arms exports as a share of GNI are below the CDI average. However, it can improve its performance on arms trade by exporting to less conflict-prone countries.
components.technology:
Canada ranks 4th overall in the technology component and is also the top-scoring G7 economy in this policy area.

Although it has a middling performance for its policies on knowledge production, with direct government support for research and development (R&D) worth 0.53 percent of GNI, and tax incentives for private business R&D worth a further 0.2 percent—each lower than average—it performs better than most on its technology diffusion and transfer policies.

Canada performs well on the number of foreign students it accepts (when weighted inversely by the income of their origin countries), ranking 4th. However, only 46 percent of foreign students are female, which is below the CDI average of 49 percent. Furthermore, the government has reduced the number of international student permits it issues in 2024 and 2025. One of Canada’s strongest indicators is intellectual property rights, where it ranks 3rd, indicating that it includes few additional restrictions beyond existing World Trade Organization standards in its free trade agreements with lower-income countries. Canada could further improve its performance by including more researchers from poor countries in its international research teams.

CHE.overall:
Switzerland ranks 9th in the Commitment to Development Index. Its strongest performances are in technology (7th), which saw great improvement as a result of less restrictive intellectual property rights clauses in recent trade agreements, and health (8th), with strong antimicrobial resistance stewardship and no export restrictions placed on food and medical goods. It has the most room for improvement in trade and migration (for which it ranks 24th and 16th, respectively).

When we assess Switzerland relative to expectations based on its income level, it falls by 20 ranks to 29th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Switzerland ranks 12th in the development finance component, though after adjusting for its income level, it falls 22 places to 34th.

Switzerland ranks in the top half of the table for the quantity of development finance. It provides 0.35 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development, compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent.

It also ranks in the top 10 for development finance quality. Its bilateral finance is mostly open to bids from non-Swiss contractors and is regularly and transparently reported. It is also relatively well directed towards those countries with the greatest needs (those that are poorer and more fragile)—more so than the CDI average. Furthermore, recipients report that Swiss development projects align well with their own development priorities. Switzerland could improve by increasing the proportion of finance it gives through multilaterals, which currently stands at 31 percent: a slight increase on 29 percent in the 2023 CDI, but still well below the CDI average of 47 percent.
components.investment:
Switzerland ranks 12th on the investment component, but when we income-adjust Switzerland's score, it falls by 10 ranks to 22nd.

Switzerland ranks joint 1st on business and human rights, as it fully engages with the OECD Guidelines on Multinational Enterprises and has published a national action plan on the subject. It also ranks 1st on anticorruption, joint with the United States, with active enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention. It also does well on natural resources governance, supporting the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative and participating in the Kimberley Process on conflict diamonds.

However, Switzerland ranks mid-table on international investment agreements, indicating it could do more to ensure its bilateral agreements do not impinge on its counterparts’ policy space to pursue development objectives. It also has ample scope to improve its financial secrecy, particularly on limiting banking secrecy and improving international legal cooperation. Switzerland also ranks 35th on the corporate tax rate alignment indicator—at 2.6 percent, its lowest available corporate tax rate as assessed by the Tax Justice Network is the 4th lowest of all CDI countries and far below the globally agreed 15 percent effective minimum, meaning Switzerland is at higher risk than other countries of being used for corporate tax avoidance and profit shifting.
components.migration:
Switzerland ranks 16th in the migration component, though when adjusted for income, this falls by 18 ranks to 34th.

Switzerland ranks 8th on refugee hosting with 21 refugees per 1,000 people compared to a CDI average of just 11. It also ranks in the higher end of the table on non-refugee migrant inflow (migrant numbers weighted inversely to the incomes of their origin countries)—of these migrants, 45 percent are female, which is slightly lower than the CDI average.

Switzerland ranks just below mid-table for its migrant integration policies, and joint last for its (lack of) participation in international migration conventions. To improve, it should implement stronger policies to integrate migrants and refugees into its economy and society, ratify the International Labour Organization’s Migration for Employment and Migrant Workers conventions, and complete a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Switzerland ranks 24th in the trade component, its lowest rank, and when scores are adjusted for income, it falls to 33rd.

Switzerland ranks 1st for its trade logistics, with good quality trade infrastructure and customs procedures. However, it ranks in the bottom half of the table for each of the other indicators in the component. It ranks in the bottom half of the table both on average tariff rates and on tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher), ranking 25th and 26th, respectively. It also ranks in the bottom half of the table on the extent of restrictions on trade in services.

Switzerland’s weakest performance is on agricultural subsidies: it gives the equivalent of 28.4 percent of farm gate production value in agricultural subsidies, nearly double the CDI average of 12.6 percent. To improve its trade-related policies, Switzerland should lower barriers to trade and reduce agricultural subsidies.
components.environment:
Switzerland ranks 13th in the environment component, falling six places since the 2023 CDI.

Switzerland has ratified and reports on all biodiversity and environmental agreements assessed in the CDI, including the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fisheries Subsidies—as it provides no harmful fishing subsidies, it also ranks well on this indicator. It also ranks in the top five for fossil fuel production, producing no gas or coal and little oil. On the climate ambition indicator, its Nationally Determined Contribution suggests that it plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 by 41 percent compared with a business-as-usual scenario. Since the 2023 CDI, Switzerland’s carbon pricing has gone backwards—from imposing an additional $38.71 on the average tonne of CO2 emitted to $29.14 in the latest data.

However, Switzerland ranks 31st for its current greenhouse gas emissions. While direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry are the fourth lowest of all CDI countries at 4.7 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, the emissions embodied in its international trade are the highest of any CDI country at over 9 tonnes per head.
components.health:
Switzerland ranks 8th in the health component.

Switzerland ranks 1st on antimicrobial resistance (AMR), with relatively low rates of consumption of antibiotics in both humans and livestock, and strong AMR governance. It also ranks joint first on avoiding export restrictions on food and health products, having not restricted any product line in the last two years. It also ranked joint 6th on pandemic preparedness.

However, Switzerland ranks joint last for its lack of regulation of international tobacco supply chains: to improve its health-related policies, it should ratify the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control and the UN Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products.
components.security:
Switzerland ranks 15th in the security component.

Switzerland ranks joint 1st on international security conventions, having ratified all the treaties and agreements assessed in the CDI. It ranks in the top 10 for its arms trade, with a below-average value of arms exports relative to GNI (0.10 percent), and with a relatively low proportion of these exports going to poor, militaristic, and undemocratic countries—those with a higher conflict potential.

It ranks 12th for its peacekeeping contributions, which are worth 0.02 percent of its GNI—slightly more than the CDI average. Its direct financial contributions to UN peacekeeping and the value of troops sent to non-UN missions are both higher than average, but the monetary equivalent value of troops sent to UN missions is below average (and, of the troops sent on UN peacekeeping missions, a low share of 11 percent were female). To improve on this component, Switzerland should increase the number of troops it sends to UN peacekeeping missions and increase the percentage of women peacekeepers.
components.technology:
Switzerland ranks 7th in the technology component, a gain of 11 ranks compared to the 2023 edition of the CDI, making this its strongest component.

Switzerland ranks in the top five on government budget support for research and development (R&D), worth 0.90 percent of GNI compared to a CDI average of 0.55 percent. However, despite its reputation for innovation, Switzerland was much less generous with its tax incentives for private business R&D, instead effectively imposing additional taxes worth 0.02 percent of GNI and ranking last on the indicator.

Switzerland has a middling performance on its policies for knowledge diffusion. It ranks 15th for the number of foreign students it hosts: they account for almost 20 percent of Switzerland’s total tertiary student population, which is the sixth highest in the CDI, but those students were also among the least likely to come from lower-income countries. The driving force behind Switzerland’s improvement in the component lies in the new trade agreements it has signed, which contain less restrictive intellectual property rights provisions than previous agreements: Switzerland now ranks joint 11th on the indicator, up from joint 19th. It has the most room for improvement on research collaboration, suggesting it should include more researchers from low-income countries in its international research teams.

CHL.overall:
Chile ranks 26th on the Commitment to Development Index.

Chile’s highest scores are on the environment and trade components (ranking 5th and 20th, respectively). It has the most room for improvement in technology and health (ranking 34th for each).

When we assess Chile relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises by seven places to 19th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance: placeholder
components.investment:
Chile ranks 19th on investment, an improvement of nine places since the 2023 CDI. Its corporate tax rate has increased above the average of lower- and middle-income countries of 25 percent (and the globally agreed minimum of 15 percent) since our last assessment. This means it is less likely to be used to facilitate corporate tax avoidance by large multinational enterprises than most CDI countries.

Chile ranks joint top on business and human rights, having established a National Action Plan on business and human rights and a national contact point to assist companies in following the OECD guidelines on multinational enterprises. Its international investment agreements also leave more policy space for partner countries to pursue their own development objectives than most CDI countries, ranking 10th on the indicator.

However, Chile is joint last on natural resource governance. It neither supports the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative nor participates in the Kimberley Process to eliminate conflict diamonds. It also does relatively poorly on financial secrecy because of secrecy in its banking sector and because it does not require country-by-country reporting of activities by multinational companies.
components.migration:
Chile ranks 24th on the migration component.

Chile comes in the top 10 for the migrant inflow indicator, accepting a relatively high number of migrants from lower-income countries relative to the size of its population. However, only 45 percent of migrants are female, and there is room for improvement in its policies that assist migrants in integrating into society and the economy.

Chile has significant room for improvement on refugee-hosting—it is ranked 33rd with 0.1 refugees per 1,000 people compared to a CDI average of 11. It should also ratify the International Labour Organization’s Conventions on Migrant Workers and Migration for Employment, as well as submit a review of its implementation of the Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Chile ranks 20th on trade but rises to 6th when scores are adjusted for income.

Tariffs charged by Chile (weighted by income of partner country) are relatively low, ranking 4th among non-EU countries, and Chile is one of only three countries to have no tariff peaks (product lines with tariffs of 15 percent or higher). Its services trade is not very restricted, and it provides low levels of trade-distorting agricultural subsidies (these increased slightly since the last CDI to 3.3 percent of production, compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent).

Chile has the most scope for improvement on the trade logistics indicator. It could strengthen the efficiency of its customs procedures and quality of its trade infrastructure; doing so would benefit its own economy and have positive development outcomes.
components.environment:
Chile ranks 5th on environment, its best component and a rise of 10 places since the previous CDI, in part reflecting a reduction in fishing subsidies.

Chile ranks 2nd for its greenhouse gas emissions, which stand at 2.7 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita when accounting for the carbon sequestration resulting from land use change and forestry in the country. At 5.3 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, Chile’s direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry are lower than the CDI average of 9.1 tonnes per capita.

Chile provides virtually no support for the consumption and production of fossil fuels, meaning it ranks 1st on the indicator; production of fossil fuels is also low.

Chile could go even further in its commitment to environmental policy by increasing the ambition of its Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC), which currently suggests that, by 2030, Chile plans to reduce its emissions by 26 percent against expected levels based on GDP growth, relative to a CDI median of 34 percent. Having accepted the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fishing Subsidies in 2023, it should also join the International Tropical Timber Organisation.
components.health:
Chile ranks 34th on the health component.

Chile’s highest rank is on the export restrictions on food and health products indicator, where it comes in joint 1st for being just one of six CDI countries that imposed no restrictions over the last two years. However, it performs poorly across the rest of the component.

For example, Chile ranks joint 14th on pandemic preparedness and should improve this by completing a Joint External Evaluation (JEE) with the World Health Organization and updating its national influenza plan. Completing a JEE would also facilitate assessment of Chile’s recently published National Action Plan on AMR and contribute to improving its antimicrobial resistance governance. Chile should also work to improve vaccination coverage for the measles vaccine by the nationally recommended age.
components.security:
Chile ranks 31st on the security component. Its best performance is on the international treaties indicator: Chile has ratified all treaties for which the CDI gives credit, but it should also adopt Protocol II to the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons.

Chile has the most room for improvement on the peacekeeping subcomponent, where it comes 36th for providing financial and personnel contributions worth just 0.003 percent of its GNI, below the CDI average of 0.019 percent. Chile should also publish data on the volume and destinations of its arms exports.
components.technology:
Chile ranks 34th on the technology component.

Chile has relatively weak policies to encourage knowledge creation, with its government spending on research and development (R&D) the lowest of all CDI countries, at just 0.15 percent of GNI—well below the CDI average of 0.55 percent. It also provides very few tax incentives for private R&D. These are worth 0.05 percent of GNI.

Chile does better on its policies to encourage knowledge diffusion. It ranks in the top 10 on the intellectual property rights indicator, meaning its trade agreements place fewer restrictions on intellectual property rights beyond World Trade Organization standards than most CDI countries. Though it accepts a relatively small number of foreign students in proportion to its tertiary student population, these students are more likely to come from lower-income countries and to be female than in most other CDI countries.

CHN.overall:
China ranks 34th in the Commitment to Development Index. It is the 13th best performer among the G20 countries, and the 4th best performer among the BRICS+.

China comes in the top half of countries on technology, where it ranks 18th. It has the most room for improvement on development finance, health, and migration, where it comes in the bottom five countries.

China is relatively new to the CDI, having been added in the 2020 edition when the CDI expanded to reflect the rising importance of major economies in the G20 and beyond.

When we assess China relative to expectations based on its income level, it rises by one rank to 33rd. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
China ranks 37th in the development finance component.

China ranks in the bottom quarter of countries on development finance quantity. Whilst the face value of its lending is large, its concessionality is relatively low, and it provides just 0.03 percent of its GNI in grant-equivalent Finance for International Development in the most recent estimate, compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent.

China also ranks near the bottom on development finance quality. China’s development finance is often tied, not transparently reported, and a lower proportion of it—31 percent—is provided through multilateral channels than the CDI average. Recipients of Chinese development finance reported that projects align with their country priorities slightly less than the average across CDI countries.
components.investment:
China ranks 30th in the investment component.

While China ranks in the top half of countries for the degree of policy space to pursue development objectives afforded to its counterparts within its bilateral investment agreements, its commitment to global investment standards is weak. China has been assessed as having no enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention by Transparency International, and it comes in the bottom five on business and human rights, as it does not adhere to the OECD Guidelines on Multinational Enterprises. While it participates in the Kimberley Process on conflict diamonds, it does not take part in the Extractives Industry Transparency Initiative.

China ranks mid-table on financial secrecy when including Hong Kong and Macao in its score. It requires country-by-country reporting of activities by companies to a greater degree than the average CDI country. However, its banking sector is more secretive than average, and its financial institutions participate in fewer automatic exchange-of-information agreements than the CDI average, as assessed by the Financial Secrecy Index.

China ranks 30th on corporate tax rate alignment. Its lowest available corporate income tax rate—when adjusted for its dependent territories—is 12 percent, below the 15 percent globally agreed minimum.
components.migration:
China ranks 35th in the migration component.

China comes last on refugee hosting, with fewer than one refugee per million population, compared to the CDI average of 11 per thousand population. China also ranks in the bottom five countries for migrant inflows from poorer countries. Of the migrants it accepts, new data suggests a high proportion are female.

China’s migrant integration policies in areas like education, health, and employment are assessed as being in the bottom 10.

China has not submitted a voluntary review towards the UN Global Compact for Migration, and has not ratified the International Labour Organization conventions on migrant workers and on migration for employment.
components.trade:
China ranks 28th in the trade component, rising to 22nd when its score is adjusted for its relatively lower income.

China’s average tariffs and tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more) against poorer countries are on the higher end. At the start of 2025, China introduced tariff-free access for least developed countries and, while this is yet to be reflected in available data, it should improve its performance. China is also relatively restrictive in its services trade, as assessed by the OECD Services Trade Restrictiveness Index.

China’s trade logistics have middling performance, with strengths in its trade infrastructure but below-average performance on its customs regime.

China’s trade-distorting agricultural subsidies have dropped since the last CDI and remain better than average. It gives just 3.6 percent of farm gate production value in subsidies, compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
China ranks 20th in the environment component.

China’s per capita greenhouse gas emissions are marginally lower than the CDI average at 9.4 tonnes CO2 equivalent per capita. China’s emissions embodied in trade are negative, meaning that some of China’s direct emissions are emitted in goods consumed within other countries.
