China ranks in the bottom 10 for the ambition in its Nationally Determined Contribution, which implies that, by 2030, China plans to emit 28 percent less than what it might otherwise be expected to emit based on GDP growth projections.

China also ranks in the bottom 10 on fossil fuel production, with particularly high coal production per capita. It does better than average on fossil fuel subsidies, which are the sixth-lowest of CDI countries. China’s regional emissions trading pilots and national emissions trading scheme collectively imposed an average additional cost per tonne emitted of less than $0.01 nationwide in 2023—well below the CDI average of $15.23 per tonne.

China provided harmful fishing subsidies worth 3 percent of its total landed fish value, lower than the average of reporting CDI countries. This represents a significant improvement, and China should continue to remove subsidies that may exacerbate overfishing and depletion of fish stocks worldwide.
components.health:
China ranks 37th in the health component, with strong vaccination coverage of its population, but weaknesses in antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and participation in global health treaties and memberships, where it comes in the bottom five countries.

Though China’s human consumption of antibiotics is low, its livestock population consumes some of the highest amounts of antimicrobials per kilogram of livestock animal. China has an approved National Action Plan on AMR but it has not completed a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization (WHO), which would allow further analysis.

China ranks joint bottom for pandemic preparedness. It should update its national influenza plan, complete a Simulation Exercise with the WHO, and a Performance of Veterinary Services assessment with the World Organisation for Animal Health.

In the last two years, China has implemented and maintained restrictions on the exports of 41 different food products and 57 medical goods. This is a significant increase, meaning that China now ranks 37th on the export restriction indicator, down from 10th.

China ranks in the bottom half of countries on controlling tobacco supply chains. While it has signed the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, it has not signed onto the Protocol on Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products.
components.security:
China ranks 32nd in the security component.

China’s contributions to peacekeeping amount to less than 0.01 percent of its GNI, below the CDI average of 0.019 percent. Although the proportion of China’s UN peacekeepers who are female has risen in the last two years, it remains low at under 4 percent overall compared to a CDI average of 13 percent.

China's arms exports are worth 0.14 percent of its GNI according to available data, which is slightly below average among CDI countries. However, the conflict potential of the countries to which it exports those arms is the highest among CDI countries.

China should do more to further global security by ratifying the Mine Ban Treaty and Convention on Cluster Munitions and signing onto the International Criminal Court.
components.technology:
China ranks 18th in the technology component, rising by four ranks to 14th when its score is adjusted for its income.

China’s policies to encourage knowledge creation are mixed: the government allocates approximately 0.46 percent of GNI directly to research and development (R&D), less than the CDI average of 0.55 percent. However, its implied subsidies to private researchers are worth approximately 0.45 percent of GNI, over double the CDI average.

China performs particularly strongly on the intellectual property rights restrictions indicator: its trade agreements restrict technology transfers to lower-income countries to a lesser extent than other CDI countries.

However, China ranks 36th on foreign students, accepting fewer tertiary students from poorer countries than other CDI countries. These students are also less likely to be female than in other CDI countries. When Chinese researchers co-author with researchers from other countries, they collaborate with poorer countries less often than the CDI average, with China ranking 27th on the research collaboration indicator.

CZE.overall:
Czechia ranks 18th in the Commitment to Development Index, with relative strengths on the migration (2nd) and environment (16th) components.

Czechia has the most room for improvement on security, technology, and investment, where it ranks in the bottom half of countries.

When we assess Czechia relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises 10 places to 8th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Czechia ranks 21st in the development finance component. It contributes 0.12 percent of its GNI as cross-border Finance for International Development, which is below the CDI average of 0.28 percent, meaning it ranks 29th on development finance quantity.

Czechia performs slightly better on the quality of its development finance, ranking 21st. Czechia reports on its development finance transparently and gives a high proportion of its finance—81 percent—through multilateral institutions, and partner countries generally report that projects align with their own priorities. However, Czechia could do more to focus its bilateral development finance on poorer and more fragile countries.
components.investment:
Czechia ranks 21st in the investment component. Although it ranks in the top half of CDI countries for limiting financial secrecy and for its approach to business and human rights, it should do more to implement the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention.

Czechia also has room for improving the development friendliness of its international investment agreements with developing countries. These agreements currently leave little policy space for counterparts to pursue their development objectives, ranking 25th on this indicator.
components.migration:
Czechia ranks 2nd in the migration component, making this its highest-ranking component. Notably, with the ongoing war in Ukraine, Czechia has increased the number of refugees it hosts more than one-hundred-fold—while in 2020, Czechia hosted just 0.2 refugees per 1,000 people, by 2024 this increased to over 33 refugees per 1,000 people, placing Czechia second on this indicator, just behind Türkiye. Czechia has also increased the number of non-refugee migrants it receives and, even though these are typically from other high-income countries, it has moved into the top five on this indicator (after migrants from lower-income countries are given a greater weight). A clear majority (58 percent) of immigrants were female in the latest data, a change from the 40 percent level typically seen in the five years before 2021.

Czechia still has room to improve on the quality of its integration policies for migrants, which has been assessed as below the CDI average.

Czechia should also ratify the International Labour Organization conventions on migrant workers and migration for employment, and complete a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Czechia ranks 18th in the trade component, rising seven places to 11th after we adjust for income.

Along with other EU members, Czechia’s tariff rates (when weighted inversely to trading partner income) are low, and it has fewer tariff peaks than average (the number of tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher). It also has few restrictions on trade in services, ranking 4th on this indicator.

Czechia has the most room for improvement on its trade logistics, where it ranks in the bottom 10 countries for both its customs regime and the quality of its infrastructure as assessed by the World Bank. Czechia should also lower the level of trade-distorting subsidies it provides to agriculture mainly through the EU—these fell substantially since the last CDI from 22.9 to 14.9 percent of farm gate production value, but remain higher than the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
Czechia ranks 16th in the environment component. Its greenhouse gas emissions per capita are about average at 9.9 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita in direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry, compared to the CDI average of 9.1 tonnes, although it also sequesters more through land use and forestry than the CDI average.

Czechia ranks joint 11th on climate target ambition, as its Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC), submitted jointly with the EU, foresees EU average emissions reduced by 34 percent over business-as-usual projections. In its 2023 update, the EU’s joint NDC complied with Paris Agreement obligations by outlining emissions reduction allocations for each member state: compared to 2005 levels, Czechia is set to reduce its emissions by 26 percent by 2030.

Czechia performs well on not providing harmful fossil fuel subsidies, but it ranks in the bottom half of the table on fossil fuel production, especially for coal. Still, we do see some improvement over the 2023 edition of the CDI, with the value of CO2 embodied in its coal production currently at 3.6 tonnes per capita, as compared to 4.0 tonnes two years prior.

Czechia ranks joint 6th on its participation in international biodiversity and environmental agreements. To score full marks, it should submit an implementation report on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora.
components.health:
Czechia ranks 16th in the health component. It has more effective regulation of tobacco supply chains and higher participation in international agreements related to health than most other CDI countries, although it could still improve its implementation of the International Code for Marketing of Breast Milk Substitutes.

Czechia ranks mid-table on antimicrobial resistance stewardship, with below-average rates of human and animal antibiotic consumption, but poor performance on antimicrobial governance—its national action plan on AMR is now out of date. Likewise, it ranks mid-table on domestic vaccination coverage. It should also improve its health policies, especially pandemic preparedness, by performing a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization.
components.security:
Czechia ranks 27th on security, its lowest rank.

Czechia ranks joint 1st on security conventions, having ratified all nine treaties assessed by the CDI.

Czechia ranks mid-table on peacekeeping contributions, with high levels of non-UN peacekeepers but relatively low troop and financial contributions to the UN. However, of the UN peacekeepers it deploys, a high proportion—29 percent—are women, as compared to the CDI average of 13 percent. As a landlocked country, it does not contribute any vessels to sea lanes protection.

To improve its security policies, Czechia should focus on further reducing its arms exports: it performs worse than the average CDI country for both the total volume of exports and the degree to which these are directed to low-income, militaristic, or undemocratic countries.
components.technology:
Czechia ranks 23rd in the technology component.

The Czech government allocated 0.59 percent of its GNI directly to research and development (R&D) in 2023, which is higher than the CDI average of 0.55 percent but marks a continued decline in R&D spending. Czechia ranks 20th for the tax incentives it provides for private R&D.

On indicators assessing Czechia’s commitment to the diffusion of technology, it ranked in the top half for foreign student inflows (when inversely weighted by the income level of origin countries), and it admitted a high proportion of female students from abroad. However, it could do more to participate in research collaborations and publish with researchers from lower-income countries. Like other EU countries, Czechia’s intellectual property rights clauses in its free trade agreements are highly restrictive beyond World Trade Organization standards.

DEU.overall:
Germany ranks 2nd in the Commitment to Development Index and is the top-ranked country across both G7 and G20 economies. It ranks in the top 10 on all components except technology, where it ranks 11th, and security, where it ranks 22nd.

When we assess Germany’s score relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank increases by one place to 1st. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Germany ranks 10th on development finance. It scores better on the quantity of its development finance than its quality: in 2024 it was the sixth-largest donor, providing 0.48 percent of its GNI as Finance for International Development (almost twice the CDI average of 0.28 percent). However, due to budget cuts, and for the first time since 2020, Germany failed to meet the UN target for 0.7 percent of GNI to be official development assistance in 2024.

Germany ranks 13th on the quality of its development finance. Germany’s development finance is transparently reported, largely untied, and second best of all CDI countries at aligning projects with the priorities of recipient countries. The percentage of development finance channelled to projects in both fragile and lower-income countries is slightly above average. However, Germany could increase the share of its aid channelled through multilateral agencies, where it lags behind the 47 percent average at 35 percent.

Investment

Germany ranks 4th on investment, performing especially well on investment standards. It ranks joint 1st on business and human rights (fully engaging with the OECD’s responsible business conduct principles), as well as joint 1st for its natural resource governance (participating in the Kimberly Process, and fully supporting and implementing the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative). It also ranks joint 3rd for its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention.

Germany ranks 17th on corporate tax rate alignment. Its lowest available corporate income tax rate is 23 percent, which is above the 15 percent globally agreed minimum, but still slightly below the developing country average of 25 percent.

It also ranks mid-table on limiting financial secrecy as assessed by the Financial Secrecy Index. It lags behind, especially on anti-money laundering and for concealing the ultimate beneficial owners of legal entities.

Germany performs worst on international investment agreements, ranking in the bottom five countries. It should improve here by doing more to ensure the clauses in its bilateral investment agreements leave policy space for lower-income counterparts to pursue their development objectives.
components.investment: placeholder
components.migration:
Germany ranks 1st on the migration component, an improvement of five places on the last CDI. It ranks in the top half of countries (14th) for its domestic migrant integration policies and joint 2nd for its participation in international conventions aiming to protect migrants’ working rights. Germany has also submitted a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration.

Germany hosts the third-highest number of refugees in the CDI—32 per 1,000 people, a significant increase over 13.8 refugees per 1,000 people in 2019. Germany has significantly increased the number of migrants it welcomes relative to its population size, and the degree to which they come from lower income countries is about average for the CDI: it now ranks third on this indicator, up from 15th. Of these migrants, 49 percent are women compared to a CDI average of 48 percent.
components.trade:
Germany ranks 3rd on trade. Along with other EU members, Germany ranks joint 4th on tariff averages, and 7th for tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher), as its tariffs are low with few peaks and offer preferences to poorer countries. Germany also has strong performance for its low restrictiveness on trade in services across sectors, where it ranks 6th.

It ranks joint 3rd on trade logistics, with strong scores on both its efficient customs procedures and good trade infrastructure.

Germany has most room to improve on trade-distorting agricultural subsidies. These are mostly agreed at EU-level and amount to 12.2 percent of Germany’s production value, slightly below the CDI average of 12.6 percent).
components.environment:
Germany ranks 9th on environment.

Although Germany’s current emissions level—amounting to 8.2 tonnes per capita in direct emissions, with a further 1.8 tonnes per capita “embodied” indirectly in its international imports—places the country within the bottom half, it aims to lower emissions by 40 percent relative projected emissions in 2030.

Germany ranks in the top 10 countries on carbon pricing, with the average tonne of carbon priced at an additional $31.14. However, it ranks mid-table on both fossil fuel production and fossil fuel subsidies, with high support given especially to coal.

Germany ranks in the top 10 for its participation in global biodiversity and environmental conventions but comes in the bottom half of countries on the harmful fishing subsidies it provides, worth 5.4 percent of total landed fish value.
components.health:
Germany ranks 7th in the health component. It ranks joint 5th for its participation in health treaties, codes, and memberships, having joined the WHO’s Global Antimicrobial Resistance Use Surveillance System (GLASS) for both the resistance and consumption modules. Germany’s antimicrobial consumption by humans was 13.3 defined daily doses per capita, below the CDI average of 19.2. However, it has not published its Joint External Evaluation from the WHO.

Germany also ranks highly (4th) on pandemic preparedness, with an influenza plan updated within the last 10 years and a simulation exercise within the last two years.

Germany comes in the bottom half of the CDI for its vaccination coverage: while it’s at 93 percent for measles at the nationally recommended age (above the CDI median of 92 percent), it has just 91 percent for diphtheria, tetanus toxoid, and pertussis among one-year olds (below the CDI median of 95 percent).

Germany ranks in the bottom half of countries in placing export restrictions in food and medical goods, having implemented restrictions on 13 food and medical products within the last two years (compared to a CDI average of 11), though these have tended to be enforced for a shorter duration than average. Germany ranks 20th on its regulation of tobacco supply chains where it could introduce measures like licensing and confiscating illegal proceeds.
components.security:
Germany ranks 22nd in the security component, its weakest performance in the CDI.

It ranks 17th on contributions of troops and finance to global peacekeeping missions. These amount to an equivalent to 0.017 percent of GNI, below the CDI average of 0.019 percent. It also contributes vessels worth approximately 0.025 percent of its GNI to global sea lanes protection, coming 10th on this measure.

Although Germany continues to improve the representation of women in its UN peacekeeping forces—the proportion now stands at 9 percent, lower than the CDI average of 13 percent—Germany ranks 22nd on this measure.

Germany’s arms exports are lower than the CDI average but are still significant (equivalent to 0.25 percent of GNI, versus a median of 0.18 percent), and a greater than average share of these go to countries that are poor, more militaristic, or less democratic.

Germany ranks joint first for security treaties, having ratified all the security conventions assessed in the CDI.
components.technology:
Germany ranks 11th in the technology component. It ranks 3rd on its support to research and development (R&D), having raised spending in recent years to 0.90 percent of GNI, above the CDI average of 0.55 percent. Germany also has relatively high tax incentives for private research, with these now worth an additional 0.36 percent of its GNI.

On policies to diffuse and share technology, Germany comes in the top 20 for the foreign students indicator, welcoming a relatively high number of foreign students (when weighted by the income of their origin countries). However, Germany ranks in the bottom half on the research collaboration indicator, which measures the proportion of researchers from lower-income countries represented in co-authored publications from German institutions. Germany also ranks in the bottom half of countries on intellectual property rights: along with other EU members, its free trade agreements contain more stringent intellectual property rights restrictions than required in World Trade Organization membership.

DNK.overall:
Denmark ranks 14th on the Commitment to Development Index. Its best score is on development finance, where it ranks 4th for its generous concessional finance and tendency to prioritise poorer countries. Denmark has the most room for improvement on the technology and environment components, where it ranks in the bottom half of countries.

When we assess Denmark relative to expectations based on its income level, its overall rank falls to 26th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance: placeholder
components.investment:
Denmark ranks 17th on investment.

It ranks within the top 10 for its natural resource governance as it both participates in the Kimberley Process for eliminating conflict diamonds and supports the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. It also performs well on tackling financial secrecy, ranking 11th.

However, Denmark ranks mid-table for its corporate tax rate alignment, and the strength of its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention is assessed as “little or none” by Transparency International. It ranks 32nd on the international investment agreements indicator, suggesting that it should make greater efforts to ensure that its bilateral investment agreements leave policy space for partner countries’ development objectives.
components.migration:
Denmark ranks 17th on migration. Denmark ranks mid-table for its refugee hosting—at almost 11 refugees per 1,000 people, it is in line with the CDI average of 11. It is just above mid-table on the number of non-refugee migrants it accepts relative to its population (after migrants from lower-income countries are given a greater weight), ranking 16th, and 53 percent of those migrants are female—above the CDI average of 48 percent.

Denmark has fairly weak policies to help migrants integrate into society and the economy through education, employment, and health, ranking 25th on the indicator—joint with South Africa. It should aim to improve these, and it should also ratify the International Labour Organization’s Migration for Employment and Migrant Workers Conventions.
components.trade:
Denmark ranks 13th on trade but falls to 24th when scores are adjusted for income.

Along with other EU members, Denmark ranks joint 4th and joint 7th respectively on the indicators for average tariff rates (when weighted inversely by the incomes of its trading partners) and tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more), with EU tariffs being generally low and having several exemptions for poorer countries. Denmark is in the top 10 for both the efficiency of its trade logistics (ranking joint top for its customs procedures) and for its openness to trade in services.

However, Denmark ranks 36th on agricultural subsidies, providing subsidies mainly through the EU worth 27.5 percent of production compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent. Denmark should seek to reduce these subsidies to avoid putting agricultural exporters from lower-income countries at a disadvantage.
components.environment:
Denmark ranks 22nd on environment, with a mixed performance across indicators.

Denmark ranks mid-table for its greenhouse gas emissions, emitting slightly less CO2 equivalent (10.0 tonnes per capita) than the average CDI country (10.2 tonnes per capita), with fewer direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry, but far more resulting from land use and embodied in its international trade. Denmark also ranks mid-table for its production of and support for fossil fuels, particularly oil.

Denmark performs better for its carbon pricing, imposing an additional $22.89 to the cost of emitting the average tonne of CO2, above the CDI average of $15.23. Denmark has also announced that from 2030, farmers will face a further tax on agricultural emissions of methane. It also ranks in the top half of countries regarding harmful subsidies to the fishing industry, with subsidies of 0.7 percent of production value against a CDI average of 9.9 percent.

To improve, Denmark should reduce its greenhouse gas emissions, as well as the production of and subsidy support for oil. It should also report on its implementation of the Convention on Biological Diversity and the UN Convention to Combat Desertification.
components.health:
Denmark ranks 15th on the health component.

It ranks joint 5th for its participation in health treaties, codes, and memberships, and also does well for its vaccination coverage—ranking joint 9th. Vaccination coverage in Denmark for measles is 93 percent by the nationally recommended age (against a CDI median of 92 percent) and 97 percent for diphtheria, tetanus toxoid, and pertussis among 1-year-olds (against a CDI median of 95 percent). Denmark also ranks in the top half of countries for its limited export restrictions on food and health products.

However, Denmark ranks mid-table for its regulation of tobacco supply chains, not having ratified the Protocol against Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products. It also ranks mid-table for its policies on antimicrobial resistance (AMR): although its antibiotic consumption is below the CDI median for both humans and animals, Denmark performs poorly on AMR governance. It should publish a national action plan on AMR and complete a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization to improve—this would also contribute to increasing its score on pandemic preparedness.
components.security:
Denmark ranks 10th on security, its second-best rank.

Denmark ranks in the top 10 for peacekeeping contributions, with total contributions equivalent to 0.025 percent of GNI (largely from troop contributions to non-UN peacekeeping missions), above the CDI average of 0.019 percent. It has made improvements in the percentage of its UN peacekeepers that are female, which at 15 percent is now above the CDI average.

Denmark has ratified all international security treaties for which the CDI gives credit, ranking joint 1st on that indicator. It also does well on the arms trade indicator, as it exports a lower volume than most CDI countries, and its arms exports are less likely to go to conflict-prone countries.
components.technology:
Denmark ranks 25th on the technology component, its lowest rank. It comes in the top 10 for government investment in research and development (R&D), spending 0.81 percent of GNI compared to a CDI average of 0.55 percent. However, it ranks 35th for the (lack of) tax incentives provided to private business R&D.

Denmark has a middling performance for its policies to promote knowledge diffusion. It accepts a fair number of foreign students, but they are less likely than in most other CDI countries to come from low-income countries. They are, however, more likely to be female than the CDI average—Denmark’s foreign students are 54 percent female, compared to an average of 49 percent. Like other EU countries, its trade agreements are more restrictive than World Trade Organization standards when it comes to intellectual property rights, hindering the spread of useful knowledge to lower-income countries.

Denmark has the most room for improvement on its research collaborations, which are primarily with other wealthy countries. It should include more academics from lower-income countries in its international research teams.

ESP.overall:
Spain ranks 16th on the Commitment to Development Index, an improvement of four ranks over the 2021 CDI, amidst recent reforms to its development system. It ranks 3rd in the environment component, with relatively low greenhouse gas emissions for a CDI country, and with low production of, and subsidies for, fossil fuels. It also ranks in the top 10 for the migration and trade components, with a significant increase in the number of migrants it hosts since the 2023 CDI, and scoring well on the services trade restrictiveness indicator.

Spain has the most room for improvement in the technology component, where it comes 32nd. It accepts relatively few foreign students from poorer countries, and its researchers co-publish with lower-income country academics less than researchers from most other CDI countries.

When we assess Spain relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises nine places to 7th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance: placeholder
components.investment:
Spain ranks 11th on the investment component. It ranks 2nd of all CDI countries for the extent to which it limits financial secrecy, with particularly good scores on anti-money laundering and international legal cooperation. It also ranks joint first for its corporate tax rate alignment, with its corporate tax rates exceeding both the globally agreed 15 percent minimum and the developing country average of 25 percent, thus presenting less risk of being used to facilitate base erosion and profit shifting.

However, Spain has room for improvement on certain investment standards. Although Spain does relatively well on business and human rights, ranking joint 8th, it could improve on the natural resources governance indicator by supporting and implementing the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. Also, its performance on anticorruption standards is weak according to Transparency International, with its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention assessed as being “limited”.

Spain also ranks low—35th—on international investment agreements, indicating that the provisions within these agreements often do not leave policy space for developing country counterparts to pursue their own development objectives.
components.migration:
Spain ranks 9th on the migration component, an improvement of four places on the previous CDI.

It comes mid-table on refugee hosting: although it has substantially increased the number of refugees it hosts, from 1.2 refugees per 1,000 people in the 2021 edition of the index, to 8.75 refugees per 1,000 people in 2024, this happened in a context of other countries accepting even more refugees against the backdrop of the war in Ukraine.

Still, Spain comes in the top 10 countries for the number of non-refugee migrants it accepts—the number more than doubled since the last CDI, although they tend to be from higher-income countries than most CDI countries. Also, of these, 51 percent were female—higher than the CDI average of 48 percent. Spain’s domestic migrant integration policies are fairly strong. It also ranks within the top 10 for its participation in international migration agreements, having ratified the International Labour Organization (ILO) Migration for Employment Convention, and completing a voluntary review of the UN Global Compact for Migration, though it could also ratify the ILO Convention on Migrant Workers.
components.trade:
Spain ranks 8th on the trade component, rising to 2nd place if scores are adjusted for income.

Along with other EU members, Spain ranks joint 4th and joint 7th, respectively, on the tariff averages and tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more) indicators, with EU tariffs being generally low and having several exemptions for poorer countries. Spain has also seen big improvements on its services trade restrictiveness indicator, where it now ranks 3rd. It also ranks in the top half for the quality of its trade infrastructure and customs procedures.

Spain has the most room for improvement on agricultural subsidies. Through the EU, it provides subsidies worth 16.7 percent of production, compared to the CDI average of 12.6 percent, which puts agricultural exporters from lower-income countries at a disadvantage. Spain should seek to lower agricultural subsidy levels at the forthcoming EU budget negotiations.
components.environment:
Spain ranks 3rd on the environment component, its highest rank. It scores in the top half of countries consistently across all indicators, although it has room for improvement on carbon pricing, where it comes 17th.

Spain participates in and reports on all major biodiversity and environment agreements for which the CDI gives credit. Its fishing subsidies, which are harmful for global fish stocks, were relatively low at 0.3 percent of total landed fish value.

Spain’s greenhouse gas emissions are well below CDI averages, with direct emissions amounting to just 5.7 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita. Its fossil fuel production is 7th-lowest of CDI countries, with no coal or gas production and only minimal oil production. Spain’s subsidies for fossil fuels have increased since the last CDI, particularly for oil, and Spain now ranks 24th on the fossil fuel support indicator.

Spain has the most room for improvement on carbon pricing. Its policies add $14.96 to the cost of an average tonne of carbon emitted; slightly below the CDI average $15.23 and well below the leading countries on this indicator, four of which impose a price of over $40 per tonne emitted.
components.health:
Spain ranks 25th on the health component.

Along with most other EU member states, it performs reasonably well for how few export restrictions it has imposed on food and health products over the last two years, ranking mid-table for this indicator. Spain has strict rules governing international tobacco supply chains, including a requirement for legible marking and legislation against illicit trade.

Spain continues to rank in the bottom half of countries for its antimicrobial stewardship, with a slight rise in human consumption of antibiotics in the latest data, with 24 defined daily doses (DDDs) per 1,000 people annually, still slightly above the CDI average of 19 DDDs per 1,000 people.

Spain’s domestic vaccination coverage has risen since the 2023 CDI and it is now just in the top half of countries for its coverage on both measles and diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccines.

Given Spain’s recent prioritisation of global health and pandemic preparedness, it should also complete a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization and update its National Influenza Plan to improve pandemic preparedness.
components.security:
Spain ranks 19th on the security component but rises by 10 ranks to 9th if scores are adjusted for income.

Spain has ratified all nine international security conventions for which the CDI gives credit. It also ranks in the top five on international sea lanes protection: Spain provides naval vessels for protecting sea lanes worth 0.056 percent of GNI. Its other contributions to international peacekeeping are middling, worth another 0.018 percent of its GNI (slightly less than the CDI average of 0.019 percent). Notably, of the UN peacekeeping troops it deploys, just 8 percent are women, compared to a CDI average of 13 percent.

Spain has the most room for improvement on the arms trade indicator. Although the proportion of its arms exports going to poorer, more militaristic, and less democratic countries is relatively low, its overall arms sales are worth 0.28 percent of GNI, compared to the CDI median of 0.18 percent.
components.technology:
Spain ranks 32nd on technology, its lowest rank, with a mixed performance across indicators.

Although Spain’s direct government expenditure on research and development (R&D) is middling (worth 0.54 percent of GNI, compared to a CDI average of 0.55 percent), it provides reasonably high tax-incentive support for business R&D (0.23 percent of GNI, compared to a CDI average of 0.19 percent).

However, Spain accepts only 43 foreign students per 1,000 total tertiary students, compared to a CDI average of 107, and these are slightly less likely to come from poorer countries than for other CDI countries. Still, 54 percent of the foreign students Spain accepts are female, which is slightly higher than the CDI average. Along with other EU members, Spain’s free trade agreements are more restrictive than the standard World Trade Organization intellectual property rights provisions (it ranks in the bottom half on this indicator). Furthermore, its academics tend to collaborate with researchers from lower-income countries much less often than do researchers from most other CDI countries.

FIN.overall:
Finland ranks 4th in the Commitment to Development Index. It ranks in the top half on all components except for technology, and scores particularly well on both health and security, where it ranks 1st place.

When we assess Finland relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank falls two places, to 6th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Finland ranks 11th in the development finance component. Finland contributed cross-border Finance for International Development worth 0.36 percent of its GNI, above the CDI average of 0.28 percent.

Finland performs better on the quality of that development finance, ranking 7th. Its finance is mostly untied and transparently reported. It also does well in ensuring its development finance is focused on poorer and more fragile countries.

Finland could improve its rank by ensuring a greater share of its development projects are further aligned with the recipient country’s priorities.
components.investment:
Finland ranks 13th in the investment component. It performs in the top 10 on limiting financial secrecy, but it should bring its anti-money laundering policies more in line with the Financial Action Task Force’s recommendations.

Finland should also improve its adherence to the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, for which it is currently assessed as having little to no enforcement by Transparency International. In terms of other investment standards, Finland performs well on natural resource governance, participating in the Kimberley Process to eliminate conflict diamonds and the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. Finland has a National Action Plan on Business and Human Rights and fully participates in the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises.

Finland’s lowest available corporate income tax rate is 20 percent, which is above the globally agreed 15 percent minimum but below the developing country average of 25 percent.
components.migration:
Finland ranks 14th on the migration component. It could improve its contribution by welcoming more non-refugee migrants; it currently accepts fewer than average migrants per head of population, although the migrants it does accept tend to be from slightly lower-income countries than other CDI countries. The gender balance of the migrants it accepts is within the bottom half of CDI countries, with just 44 percent of migrants being female as compared to the CDI average of 48 percent. It should also ratify the International Labour Organization conventions on migration for employment and on migrant workers.

Finland has received a significant increase in the number of refugees it hosts (from 4.2 per 1,000 people in 2020 to 15.7 per 1,000 people in 2024, mainly as a result of hosting a significant number of Ukrainian refugees) and comes 12th on the refugees indicator overall. Finland also has effective domestic integration policies for migrants, ranking 2nd on this indicator.
components.trade:
Finland ranks 7th in the trade component. Alongside other EU countries, it ranks joint 4th on average tariffs against lower-income countries and joint 7th on tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more). It also has among the best trade logistics, minimizing unnecessary costs for importers. However, Finland ranks mid-table on the restrictiveness of its services trade.

Although Finland provides lower trade-distorting agricultural subsidies than the CDI average (9.1 percent of production compared to an average of 12.6 percent), there is scope to reduce these further through negotiation at the EU level.
components.environment:
Finland ranks 18th in the environment component, making this its second-lowest scoring component.

Finland ranks 28th for its greenhouse gas emissions. Its direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry are equivalent to 7.4 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita (which is below the CDI average), but it has the highest emissions from land use change and forestry of all CDI countries, contributing an additional 2.5 tonnes per capita to Finland’s carbon footprint. Finland has reduced its support for fossil fuels since the 2023 CDI, rising from the bottom 10 of countries into the top half.

Finland has ambitious carbon pricing, imposing an average additional cost of $55.70 per tonne of CO2 emitted, which is second only to Sweden’s carbon price, and considerably higher than the CDI average additional cost of $15.23. Finland lacked the necessary data on harmful fishing subsidies, and its score was interpolated based on the lowest-ranking country, placing it joint last. It should report its fisheries support estimates to the OECD.
components.health:
Finland ranks 1st in the health component. It scores especially well on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) stewardship, with low levels of both human and animal antibiotic consumption. Finland performs well on pandemic preparedness, having conducted a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization (WHO) and updated its national influenza plan within the last decade.

Finland implemented eight restrictions on exports of food and health-related products in the last two years, below the CDI country average of 40. Finland should increase its vaccination coverage, as it does not meet WHO targets of 95 percent coverage for either the measles (92 percent coverage) or the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis (91 percent coverage) vaccines. It also has room for improvement on AMR governance measures by updating and improving its national action plan, which ran until 2021.
components.security:
Finland also ranks 1st in the security component.

Finland now has the highest peacekeeping contributions of all CDI countries, contributing 0.057 percent of its GNI in the way of direct financial contributions and the value of troop deployments. Still, it should improve on the gender diversity of its UN peacekeepers, with just 6 percent of its peacekeepers being female compared to the CDI average of 13 percent. It did not contribute any vessels to protect sea lanes in 2024.

Finland exports relatively few arms compared to other CDI countries (worth 0.05 percent of its GNI), and the arms it did export went to relatively less conflict-prone countries: it ranks 4th on the indicator overall. Finland has recently submitted its instrument of withdrawal from the Mine Ban Treaty, and it should further improve its commitment to global security by ratifying the Convention on Cluster Munitions.
components.technology:
Despite its reputation of being among the most innovative countries in the world, Finland comes only 27th on technology, making this its lowest-ranking component. Although Finland allocates 0.76 percent of its GNI directly to government research and development (R&D), which is higher than the CDI average of 0.55 percent, it could also provide tax incentives for private R&D, which it currently does not.

Finland’s research collaborations are slightly less likely to be produced with co-authors from lower-income countries than the CDI average, and—along with other EU countries—its trade agreements are restrictive beyond World Trade Organization standards when it comes to intellectual property rights, hindering the spread of useful knowledge to lower-income countries. Finland ranks 13th for the number of foreign students from poorer countries it accepts relative to its student population, and it could increase the proportion of female foreign students, which is currently 46 percent, compared to a CDI average of 49 percent.

FRA.overall:
France ranks 7th in the Commitment to Development Index and is the third-highest scoring G7 and G20 nation. France scores fairly well across most components, with its best performances in investment (2nd), environment (7th), and technology (9th). France has the most room for improvement on migration, where it ranks in the bottom half of countries.

When we assess France relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises to 4th place. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
France ranks 14th on the development finance component. France ranks 10th on the quantity of cross-border development finance it provides, with its Finance for International Development worth 0.38 percent of GNI—above the CDI average of 00.28 percent. In 2024, France provided 0.48 percent of GNI as official development assistance (ODA)—down from 0.56 percent in 2022, and further from meeting its pledge to provide ODA worth 0.7 percent of GNI by 2025.

France ranks 22nd for the quality of its development finance. Although France transparently reports on its finance provision (alongside other DAC members) and aligns projects relatively well with recipient country priorities, it does not target its development finance particularly well towards countries with higher needs, and more than a tenth of its aid is tied to French contractors.
components.investment:
France ranks 2nd on the investment component, with strong performance across most indicators. It ranks joint 3rd for its strong enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and joint 4th for its efforts to promote good standards in natural resource investments, participating in the Kimberly Process to eliminate conflict diamonds, and supporting the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI), though it has yet to make progress in implementing the EITI standard.

France ranks in the top 10 for its policies aimed at tackling financial secrecy, performing well across most metrics on this indicator, though it still lags behind in addressing banking secrecy. France’s lowest rank in the investment component is for the international investment agreements indicator. Its agreements limit the policy space of poorer countries to pursue their development objectives, though it still performs better than the CDI average.
components.migration:
France ranks 23rd on the migration component, down five places since the 2021 CDI. Although its refugee hosting has improved in recent years, it is slightly below average at just over 10 per 1,000 people and is only just in the top half of countries on this indicator. France ranks in the bottom half of the table on non-refugee migrant inflows (weighted inversely by the income of their origin country). Of these, 48 percent are women, again leaving France below most CDI countries. France should improve its migration-related policies by increasing the number of refugees and migrants it accepts whilst continuing to ensure that low-income countries are well represented among them.

France’s domestic migrant integration policies are slightly better than the CDI average, although it could do more to participate in international conventions protecting migrants. France should sign up to the International Labour Organization Migrant Workers Convention, fully ratifying the Migration for Employment Convention (which it has currently ratified with limiting provisions), and completing a voluntary review of its implementation of the Global Compact on Migration.
components.trade:
France ranks 15th on the trade component. Along with other EU countries, France ranks joint 4th on tariff rates and joint 7th on tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more), as the EU generally has low tariffs and several preference schemes for lower-income countries. France also ranks in the higher end of the table both on services trade restrictions, as these are quite low, and on its trade logistics, as it has above-average quality of customs procedures and trade infrastructure.

France could improve its trade-related policies by reducing its agricultural subsidies. These are set at the EU level, and, in France, they amount to 15.4 percent of production value (above the CDI average of 12.6 percent), creating uncompetitive barriers for lower-income countries wishing to export agricultural produce.

Environment

France ranks 7th on the environment component.

On climate-relevant policies and performance, France’s direct greenhouse gas emissions (excluding land use change and emissions embodied in trade) are below the CDI average, amounting to 5.4 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita (the CDI average is 9.1 tonnes). With one of the largest nuclear power programmes in the world, France’s fossil fuel production is low, with no coal or gas and negligible oil production. France also ranks within the top five for its carbon price: it adds $31.92 to the cost of emitting an average tonne of CO2 equivalent, which is above the CDI average of $15.23. However, France should reduce financial support to the domestic consumption of fossil fuels, for which it ranks in the bottom half of the CDI.

France ranks joint 11th on climate target ambition, as its Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC), submitted with the EU, foresees EU average emissions falling 34 percent relative to expected emissions in 2030. However, the EU’s joint NDC is also currently noncompliant with the Paris Agreement, as it does not provide individual emission levels allocated to each Member State, including France.

France has signed up to all the major biodiversity and environmental agreements we assess but is not up to date on reporting on its implementation of the UN Convention to Combat Desertification, nor the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. France’s harmful fishing subsidies are relatively limited (at 0.9 percent of landed fish value, below the CDI median of 2.2 percent).
components.environment: placeholder
components.health:
France ranks 10th on the health component. It ranks joint 1st for its regulation of international tobacco supply chains, and joint 5th for its participation in health treaties, codes, and memberships, having recently signed up to the Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (‎GLASS)‎ module on consumption with the World Health Organization (WHO).

Still, France has room to improve its policies relating to antimicrobial resistance (AMR), for which it ranks 17th. France’s population consumes a high level of antibiotics (24.1 defined daily doses per 1,000 people, which is above the CDI average of 19.2).

On vaccination rates, France has recently improved its coverage for measles to 93 percent of its population, above the CDI median of 92 percent, and near the WHO target of 95 percent.

France ranks 25th for its export restrictions on food and health products. It has implemented harmful restrictions on 16 such products in the last two years, which is more than most CDI countries (the CDI median is 11), and these restrictions have tended to be in place for longer than most.

Although France has updated its national influenza plan in the last decade and participates in WHO-led simulation exercises, it could do more to enhance pandemic preparedness by completing a Joint External Evaluation with the WHO and performing an assessment of its veterinary services.
components.security:
France ranks 20th on the security component.

France continues to rank joint 1st for having ratified all nine security conventions assessed in the CDI. However, its performance on peacekeeping contributions, where it ranks 15th, is less impressive: despite giving among the most of all CDI countries in direct finance contributions to the UN Department of Peacekeeping Operations, the value of troops provided by France for global peacekeeping missions is low. The total value of finance and troops now stands at 0.019 percent of GNI, the same as the CDI average. Despite this, France ranks in the top five on its allocation of naval resources to protect global sea lanes (equivalent to 0.053 percent of GNI, above the CDI average of 0.019 percent).

France’s security-related policies should be most improved with respect to its arms trade, where it ranks 26th. Its arms exports are equivalent to 0.27 percent of GNI which is an improvement since the previous edition of the CDI, but this remains higher than the CDI median (0.18 percent). The proportion of arms exported to poor, militaristic, and undemocratic countries (which have higher risks of conflict) also remains higher than the CDI average.
components.technology:
France ranks 9th on the technology component. Its tax incentives for businesses to invest in research and development are worth 0.44 percent of GNI compared to a CDI average of 0.19 percent, placing France 4th on this indicator. Direct government spending for research and development is also higher than average—equivalent to 0.70 percent of GNI, compared to a CDI average of 0.55 percent.

On its policies to encourage the diffusion of technology, France welcomes large numbers of foreign students (weighted inversely by the income of their origin countries to reward for accepting students from low-income countries) and ranks 7th on this indicator. France could, however, include more researchers from lower-income countries in its international research collaborations, where it ranks mid-table. Alongside other EU countries, France could reduce the extent to which its free trade agreements impose restrictive intellectual property rights provisions beyond World Trade Organization standards on its developing country counterparts.

GBR.overall:
The UK ranks 5th on the Commitment to Development Index. The UK’s best performances are on the trade (ranking 4th), investment (5th), and security (8th) components. It ranked in the top 10 on development finance, though this reflects the value of its finance in 2024, before it began implementing a substantial 40 percent reduction by 2027. The UK also performs in the top 10 countries for environment and in the top half for health and technology. It has the most room for improvement on migration, where it ranks 22nd.

The UK’s overall rank does not change when we assess it relative to expectations based on its income level. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
The UK ranks 9th in the development finance component, coming 11th for quantity (based on 2024 data, before announced aid reductions) and 4th for quality. The UK provided 0.37 percent of its GNI as development finance compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent. These values are based on CGD’s Finance for International Development measure, conceptually lower than official development assistance as it excludes flows spent domestically.

The UK’s development finance is transparently reported, and its allocation has a strong focus on fragile states relative to other providers. It performs well on the poverty focus of its allocation, too. The share of the UK’s development projects aligned with recipient country priorities (79 percent) has improved in more recent survey data and is now above the CDI average (65 percent). However, the UK provides a below-average share of its aid through multilateral organisations (27 percent versus the CDI average of 47 percent).
components.investment:
The UK ranks 5th on the investment component. It ranks joint first for business and human rights (fully engaging with the OECD’s responsible business conduct principles), as well as for its natural resource governance (it participates in the Kimberly Process and supports and meaningfully implements the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative standard). The UK also ranks joint 3rd for its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention.

The UK also performs relatively well on tackling financial secrecy (rank 10), though its overseas territories weigh down on its rank. The UK still lags behind average performance in banking secrecy and on making statistics on its economic and financial engagement with the wider world publicly available.

The UK has most room for improvement on international investment agreements (rank 28), and on the new corporate tax rate alignment indicator (rank 29), which is brought down by the network of Crown Dependencies and Overseas Territories that are used as tax havens or offshore financial centres. To improve, the UK should include fewer provisions in its bilateral investment agreements that limit the policy space of its counterparts to pursue their development objectives. It could also improve in this area by ensuring that it and its dependent jurisdictions are in line with the globally agreed minimum effective corporate tax rate of 15 percent.
components.migration:
The UK ranks 22nd in the migration component.

Despite the influx of refugees arriving by small boat in recent years, the UK ranks mid-table (20th) for the number of refugees it hosts (7.1 per 1,000 people, compared to a CDI average of 11). It is in the bottom half of countries in terms of the number of non-refugee migrants it accepts relative to its population, both in terms of the numbers relative to population and the extent to which they come from lower-income countries. Still, the share of these migrants who are female is 52 percent, which is above the CDI average of 48 percent.

The UK ranks joint 18th in the most recent assessment of its policies aiming to help migrants integrate through education, employment, and health. It ranks 9th for its ratification of international conventions aiming to protect migrants: it has not ratified the Migrant Workers Convention and has ratified the Migration for Employment Convention with only limited provisions.
components.trade:
The UK ranks 4th in the trade component, a rise of four places since the 2023 CDI. It ranks 3rd for its average tariff rates (weighted inversely to the income of the trading partner), and 6th for its below-average number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher). The latest data (2023) is beginning to reflect the implementation of the UK’s new Developing Countries Trading Scheme, which lowered tariffs from the middle of that year. The UK also has relatively few restrictions on trade in services across sectors, where it ranks 2nd. It ranks 19th on the trade logistics indicator, which measures the quality of customs procedures and trade infrastructure.

The UK has most room to improve on agricultural subsidies, though these have fallen since the last edition of the CDI. Currently, they are worth 9.5 percent of farm gate production value and have fallen below the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
The UK ranks 10th in the environment component.

It has signed up to all the biodiversity and environmental agreements assessed in the CDI and has accepted the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fisheries Subsidies since the last edition. Its reporting is up to date on all but one, so ranks joint 6th on this indicator. It ranks 20th on harmful subsidies to the fishing industry, with subsidies of 2.4 percent of production value against a CDI average of 9.9 percent.

The UK’s rank on carbon pricing has fallen from 10th to 15th, adding $16.01 to the cost of emitting one tonne of CO2, just above the CDI average of $15.23 but down on its previous figure of $21.09. Its rank is also middling—18th—for its direct and indirect greenhouse gas emissions, which stand at 8.3 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita when accounting for both land use change and emissions embodied in trade (though this is still lower than the CDI average of 10.2 tonnes). The UK scores better on the ambition of its Nationally Determined Contribution: by 2030 it plans to reduce its emissions by 41 percent against current business-as-usual projections (above the CDI average of 31 percent).

The UK could improve by reducing its production of fossil fuels, as well as its financial support to the domestic consumption and production of fossil fuels. The UK ranks 23rd for the amount of CO2 per capita embodied in the fossil fuels it produces, mainly via oil and gas. This production amounts to 2.9 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita (compared to a CDI median of 1.6). It ranks 27th on its support for fossil fuel production and consumption (equivalent to 0.95 percent of GNI, compared to the CDI median of 0.53 percent).
components.health:
The UK ranks 12th in the health component. It fulfils all of our indicators on the regulation of tobacco supply chains, and participates in all of the health treaties, codes, and memberships we assess.

The UK performs above most countries (ranking 11th) for its policies on antimicrobial resistance, with above-average governance and relatively low antibiotic use among animals. Still, antibiotic use in humans is slightly above the CDI average (19.2 defined daily doses per 1,000 people). It also ranks joint 14th on pandemic preparedness.

The UK ranks in the bottom half of countries on vaccination coverage: its immunization coverage by the nationally recommended age is 85 percent for measles (against a CDI median of 92 percent), and its immunization coverage among 1-year-olds is 92 percent for diphtheria, tetanus toxoid, and pertussis (against a CDI median of 95 percent). It also ranks 29th for its export restrictions on food and health products (even after removing sanctions against Russia), with a relatively large number of product lines covered by restrictions.
components.security:
The UK ranks 8th in the security component. It scores strongly across several elements, including ranking 3rd on its allocation of naval resources to protect international sea lanes (worth around 0.083 percent of its GNI, compared to a CDI average of 0.019 percent). It has ratified all nine security conventions that are credited in the CDI, and since the 2023 CDI it has reconsented to Protocol V on the Explosive Remnants of War as part of the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons. It ranks 14th for its troop and financial contributions to global peacekeeping missions (equivalent to 0.02 percent of GNI, which is just above the CDI median of 0.019 percent). It ranks 24th on the female peacekeepers indicator, with women accounting for 8 percent of the UK’s peacekeeping forces, compared to the CDI average of nearly 13 percent.

The UK ranks 19th for the value and conflict potential of its arms exports: its exports are equivalent to 0.18 percent of GNI, in line with the CDI median, and the proportion of these that are sold to countries which are poor, militaristic, or undemocratic is also close to the CDI average.
components.technology:
The UK ranks 12th in the technology component, a rise of five places since the previous CDI, reflecting an increase in the foreign students it hosts.

On the UK’s policies to encourage technology creation, the UK ranks in the top 10 countries on its tax incentives to private researchers, equivalent to 0.34 percent of GNI (compared to a CDI average of 0.19 percent). However, the UK government could spend more directly on research and development, as here the UK ranks 21st and its allocation has fallen below the CDI average (0.51 versus 0.55 percent of GNI, respectively).

In terms of policies to diffuse and share technology, the UK ranks 6th for the number of foreign students it welcomes (when weighted by the income level of their origin countries), and over half of these are female (51 percent compared to a CDI average of 49 percent). Nevertheless, it ranks outside the top 10 on including researchers from lower-income countries in its international research teams. And its free trade agreements are assessed as being among the most restrictive of any CDI country relative to World Trade Organization standards.

GRC.overall:
Greece ranks 23rd in the Commitment to Development Index. Its best rank is in the environment component (11th), and its worst performances are in technology (30th) and health (36th). It saw a dramatic reduction in migrant inflows from lower-income countries in the last two years, meaning its rank in the migration component dropped 19 places to 21st.

When we assess Greece relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises by eleven places to 12th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Greece ranks 19th in the development finance component, though after income-adjusting its score, this rises by ten places to 9th. It ranks in the bottom half of the table on the amount of development finance it provides, giving 0.14 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent.

Relative to other CDI countries, it performs better on the quality of this finance, as almost all (98 percent) of Greek development finance is delivered through multilaterals. Its bilateral provision is transparent and largely untied. However, Greece’s bilateral development finance also does poorly on targeting recipients with the greatest needs, scoring poorly on poverty focus (38th) and fragility focus (29th: this is the area of this component where Greece could most improve.
components.investment: Greece ranks 16th in the investment component. It has strong financial transparency standards, ranking joint top or near the top of the table on most of the financial secrecy measures. However, it ranks relatively low (joint 24th) on business and human rights: it has not yet launched its national action plan on business and human rights, and it has not participated in the peer review process on the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. Furthermore, it performs worse than average (30th) on investment agreements, suggesting it should do more to limit clauses in agreements with developing countries that protect its investors at the expense of the development policy space of the countries that host them.
components.migration:
Greece ranks 21st on the migration component, a drop of 19 places since the last CDI. In the previous period, Greece had a very high level of inward migration from lower-income countries, particularly Afghanistan, but its migration level has now fallen below average, and inflows have tended to be from wealthier countries than its CDI peers. It now ranks 26th on our non-refugee migration indicator, from 2nd last year; it is also in the bottom 10 countries for the share of migrants that are female (37 percent). Greece, however, remains in the top 10 of countries for refugee hosting, with nearly 21 refugees per 1,000 people.

Greece ranks among the bottom half of CDI countries for its migrant integration policies, with particularly weak policies to ensure migrants have access to political participation, education, and citizenship. It should also sign and ratify the International Labour Organization’s conventions on Migrant Workers and Migration for Employment.
components.trade: Greece ranks 26th in the trade component. As an EU member state, it performs well on tariffs, ranking joint 4th on tariff averages and joint 7th on the number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more), weighted inversely by trading partner income. However, Greece ranks in the bottom half of the table on the quality of its customs and trade infrastructure (23rd) and on the number of trade restrictions on services (26th). On agricultural subsidies, it ranks 35th, as its farmers receive 26.0 percent of production value in subsidies, compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent. Greece should be open to EU-level reforms that reduce these subsidy levels to even the playing field with lower-income country food producers.
components.environment:
Greece ranks 11th in the environment component. It ranks just outside the top 10 for its greenhouse gas emissions, with direct emissions of 7.1 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita compared to a CDI average of 9.1, and it is one of only 12 CDI countries to have negative emissions embodied in international trade. Greece ranks joint top on environmental and biodiversity treaties—it has also ratified all the treaties assessed in the CDI and since the last edition has reported on its implementation of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora.

Greece has significant room for improvement on subsidies given to the production and consumption of fossil fuels, as its financial support for coal, oil, electricity, and gas (scaled for carbon intensity) is among the highest five countries in the CDI. Greece has also fallen into the bottom ten countries on the provision of harmful fishing subsidies—these amount to 13.5 percent of production value to its fishing industry—well-above the CDI median of 2.2 percent.
components.health:
Greece ranks 36th in the health component. It ranks 10th for export restrictions on food and health products and mid-table for its participation in health codes, treaties, and memberships. Among these are the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System module on antimicrobial resistance, which Greece joined in 2018, but it could improve by also participating in the antimicrobial consumption module. Greece’s wider efforts on antimicrobial resistance are poor, and it ranks last in this area due to high rates of antibiotic consumption in both humans and livestock, and weak governance.

Greece ranks in the bottom half of the table on the indicators measuring vaccination coverage (22nd). Although the country’s coverage for the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine is near-perfect and joint-highest in the CDI, coverage of the measles vaccine is low at 83 percent—well below the CDI median of 92 percent and the World Health Organization target of 95 percent.

In terms of pandemic preparedness, Greece performs poorly as one of 10 countries that have not fulfilled any of the four measures we assess, with no national influenza plan in the last decade and no joint external evaluation of public health risks with the WHO.
components.security:
Greece ranks 14th in the security component, but after we adjust Greece's score on the security component relative to an expected score based on its income, it rises by eight ranks to 6th.

Greece ranks in the top 10 for its peacekeeping contributions: its troop contributions to UN missions are slightly lower than the CDI average, but its financial contributions to the UN as a percentage of GNI are fourth highest of all CDI countries at 0.01 percent compared to an average of 0.007 percent. The financial-equivalent value of troops deployed to non-UN missions is also higher than the CDI average. Furthermore, a relatively high proportion of Greece’s UN peacekeepers are female (16 percent compared to a CDI average of 13 percent).

Greece performs relatively well on international sea lanes protection, contributing an equivalent of 0.05 percent of GNI, the sixth highest of CDI countries. It also does better than the average CDI country on arms trade, with a low volume of arms exports and with trading partners that are less likely to be poor, militaristic, and undemocratic countries—i.e., those that are more conflict-prone.
components.technology:
Greece ranks 30th in the technology component.

It ranks mid-table on government support for research and development (R&D), with approximately 0.64 percent of GNI allocated directly by the government to R&D, which is slightly higher than the CDI average of 0.55 percent. However, it performs less well on tax incentives, for which it ranks 23rd. Greece’s number of foreign students per capita (weighted by origin country income) was lower than the CDI average, and its research collaborations were more likely to be with researchers from other high-income countries. Furthermore, along with other EU members, Greece’s free trade agreements contain intellectual property rights provisions that are more restrictive than the World Trade Organization standard.

HUN.overall:
Hungary ranks 25th on the Commitment to Development Index. Its best scores are on the security and environment components (3rd and 6th place, respectively). It provides substantial contributions to peacekeeping missions, and its greenhouse gas emissions are lower than the CDI average. Hungary has the most room for improvement in development finance, where it ranks 34th; it gives little in the way of cross-border finance for international development and does not direct it to the poorest and most fragile countries.

When we assess Hungary relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises seven places to 18th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance: placeholder
components.investment:
Hungary ranks 28th on investment.

Hungary ranks in the top 10 for the extent to which its investment treaties leave space for partner countries to pursue their development objectives. However, it has made little attempt to enforce the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention and does not support the Extractives Industry Transparency Initiative. It also has no national action plan on business and human rights. Hungary should make greater efforts to fight corruption abroad and establish a plan for protecting against any adverse impacts businesses could have on human rights.

Hungary performs relatively poorly on the corporate tax rate alignment indicator. Its lowest available corporate income tax rate is 9 percent, lower than the globally agreed minimum of 15 percent, facilitating profit shifting by large multinational enterprises.
components.migration:
Hungary ranks 31st on migration.

Although Hungary ranks mid-table (19th) for the number of refugees it hosts relative to its own population (7 refugees per 1,000 people, up from 0.6 in the 2021 CDI, but still below the CDI average of 11 this year), Hungary ranks in the bottom half of CDI countries for the number of non-refugee migrants it accepts from lower-income countries. Furthermore, only 45 percent of the migrants it accepts are female, compared to an average of 48 percent across other CDI countries. Hungary also ranks well below average on the extent to which its policies help migrants to integrate. It has not ratified key International Labour Organization conventions on the rights of migrant workers, nor has it performed a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration.

Hungary should ensure that migrants and asylum-seekers have access to basic services, and it should remove obstacles that prevent them from working.
components.trade:
Hungary ranks 29th on trade but rises to 25th when scores are adjusted for income.

Along with other EU members, Hungary ranks joint 4th and joint 7th on the tariffs and tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more) indicators, respectively, with EU tariffs towards poorer countries being generally low. Hungary’s performance is middling on the degree to which its services trade is restricted, and its trade logistics have deteriorated in recent years compared to other CDI countries, meaning it ranks joint 34th for the indicator, down from 26th in the 2021 CDI.

Hungary has significant scope for improvement in limiting agricultural subsidies. It provides inefficient subsidies worth 25.7 percent of agricultural production, over twice the CDI average of 12.6, presenting a barrier to agricultural exporters from low-income countries. Agriculture policy is set at the EU level, but Hungary should be open to reducing subsidies in upcoming discussions over the EU budget to help level the playing field with lower-income country food producers.
components.environment:
Hungary ranks 6th on environment.

Hungary performs well across the board, coming in the top half of countries across most indicators. As a landlocked country, it provides no subsidies for fishing. It has ratified all environmental treaties included in the CDI—though it could produce a progress report on its implementation of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. Hungary also has among the lowest levels of subsidies for fossil fuels, ranking 4th on this indicator.

Whereas Hungary’s direct domestic greenhouse gas emissions are relatively low, only 5.8 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita compared to a CDI average of 9.1, its position slips as a result of further emissions from land use change and forestry and those embodied in international trade. In addition to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions, Hungary could raise the costs it imposes on carbon emissions to improve its performance.
components.health:
Hungary ranks 24th on the health component.

Hungary has high vaccination coverage against measles and diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis, placing it joint top of the vaccination subcomponent. It imposed export restrictions on 18 food and medical products over the last two years, above the CDI average of 11.

Hungary has the most room for improvement on measures aimed at detecting and preventing pandemics, and it could improve by updating its national influenza plan and completing a Joint External Evaluation (JEE) with the World Health Organization. Hungary also ranks in the bottom 10 on antimicrobial resistance (AMR)—although Hungary is below average in terms of the consumption rate of antibiotics in humans, it has yet to complete development of its national AMR action plan or be assessed on AMR governance as part of a JEE.
components.security:
Hungary ranks 3rd on the security component, and when scores are adjusted for income, this rises to 2nd.

Hungary comes 3rd on both the peacekeeping contributions and the arms trade indicators. The value of its financial and personnel contributions to peacekeeping operations is worth 0.045 percent of GNI overall, over double the CDI average—with, notably, the highest monetary equivalent value of troop contributions to non-UN but internationally approved peacekeeping missions proportional to its GNI by some margin. Of the UN peacekeepers it deploys, 13.5 percent are women, which is marginally higher than the CDI average but shows a decrease since our last assessment. Hungary also sells relatively few arms, and the destinations of its arms exports are among the least conflict-prone of any CDI country.

However, Hungary is yet to develop a national action plan on women, peace, and security in line with UN Security Council Resolution 1325.
components.technology:
Hungary ranks 26th on the technology component. Its best rank is on foreign students: Hungary has the 8th-highest number of foreign students relative to the total number of tertiary students when weighted by origin countries with a lower income.

Hungary has a middling performance on its support for knowledge production, ranking 23rd for the amount of direct government support it provides to research and development (equivalent to 0.50 percent of GNI, as compared to a CDI average of 0.55 percent) and 27th for the tax incentives it provides for private researchers, worth 0.10 percent of GNI (compared to a CDI average of 0.19 percent).
