Along with other EU countries, Hungary’s trade agreements are highly restrictive when it comes to intellectual property—beyond World Trade Organization standards—hindering the spread of useful knowledge to low-income countries.

IDN.overall:
Indonesia ranks 35th on the Commitment to Development Index and is the 16th best performer of the G20 economies. Indonesia’s strongest performances are on the technology and development finance components, where it ranks 22nd and 26th, respectively. It has the most room for improvement on migration, security, and trade, where it ranks in the bottom five countries.

When we assess Indonesia relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises to 31st. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Indonesia ranks 26th on the development finance component, but it rises to 7th when scores are adjusted for income.

Indonesia ranks lowest for the amount of cross-border Finance for International Development it provides, giving less than 0.01 percent of its GNI. On development finance quality, Indonesia ranks in the top half of the table (19th). The majority of Indonesia’s finance (89 percent) is provided through multilaterals. So, although it ranks in the bottom 10 for transparency, the weight on its bilateral programme is small. Its bilateral finance is also assessed as being mostly untied.

No data was available to assess the extent to which Indonesia provides finance in accordance with the priorities of partner countries.
components.investment:
Indonesia ranks 31st on the investment component.

Indonesia ranks joint 15th on the natural resources indicator: it participates in the Kimberley Process for preventing conflict diamonds, but its implementation of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative was downgraded from “meaningful progress” to “fairly low” in the latest assessment. It also comes just above mid-table for its corporate tax rate alignment, with a corporate tax rate of 22 percent, which is above the globally agreed 15 percent minimum, but below the developing country average of 25 percent.

According to Transparency International, Indonesia does not enforce the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and ranks joint last on anticorruption. Indonesia does not have a national action plan on business and human rights, and it comes in the bottom half of countries on limiting financial secrecy, as it does not require companies to provide country-by-country reports of their activities and has lax regulations on the identification of the beneficial owners of companies.
components.migration:
Indonesia ranks last on the migration component, its lowest rank.

Indonesia has one of the lowest intakes of migrants among CDI countries, and the migrants it does accept are slightly less likely to come from poorer countries than for the average CDI country. They are also less likely to be female: 46 percent of migrants arriving in Indonesia are female, compared to a CDI average of 48 percent.

Indonesia is in the bottom five for both the quality of its migrant integration policies and the number of refugees it hosts (0.03 per 1,000 people, compared to the CDI average of 11). It has also not ratified the International Labour Organization conventions on either migration for employment or migrant workers, nor has it completed a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Indonesia ranks 35th on the trade component.

Indonesia ranks 9th for limiting the trade-distorting agricultural subsidies it provides, worth 3.6 percent of production compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent. However, it ranks in the bottom 10 on all other trade indicators. Indonesia has relatively high tariffs against lower-income countries, and a high number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher), ranking 32nd for each. Its trade in services is the second-most heavily restricted among CDI countries. According to the World Bank, its customs procedures are relatively inefficient, and its trade infrastructure is of low quality compared to other CDI countries.
components.environment:
Indonesia ranks 31st on the environment component.

Indonesia has among the lowest direct greenhouse gas emissions per capita (only India’s are lower), at 3.8 tonnes CO2 equivalent, compared to a CDI average of 9.1 tonnes. However, it has among the highest emissions from land use change and forestry, which add another 1.7 tonnes per capita to its current emissions levels. Looking forward to 2030, Indonesia’s climate target as expressed by its Nationally Determined Contribution is assessed as being the least ambitious of all CDI countries, with planned emissions above those in a business-as-usual scenario. It ranks 30th for high fossil fuel production, with particularly high levels of coal production. It also provides a high level of subsidies for the consumption and production of these fossil fuels, and it has no carbon pricing measures.

Indonesia provides relatively little harmful subsidy support to fishing; these are worth under 0.1 percent of production value, placing Indonesia 13th on this indicator. Indonesia comes in the bottom half of countries for its participation in biodiversity and environmental agreements, and it should accept the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fish Subsidies and ratify the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals.
components.health:
Indonesia ranks 33rd on the health component.

Indonesia has relatively low consumption of antibiotics in humans, at 12.5 defined daily doses per 1,000 people, compared to a CDI average of 19.2, and it also has below-average consumption of antibiotics in livestock animals. Indonesia ranks mid-table for its participation in health-related treaties - it could improve further by fully aligning with the Code for the Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes and submitting confidence-building measures under the Biological Weapons Convention.

However, Indonesia ranks joint last on the tobacco control indicator for having lax regulations in international tobacco supply chains. It is also in the bottom five countries for low domestic coverage of both the measles and the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccines, both of which are far below World Health Organization targets.

On trade restrictions relating to food and health, Indonesia applied restrictions on 25 products, above the CDI-country median of 11. On pandemic preparedness, it ranked in the bottom half, with three of four measures unfulfilled, including the absence of a national influenza plan.
components.security:
Indonesia ranks 37th on the security component.

Indonesia ranks in the top 10 for the monetary equivalent value of troops it contributes to UN peacekeeping missions proportional to its GNI, but comes bottom for financial contributions to the UN Department of Peacekeeping Operations. Of the UN peacekeepers it deploys, only 6 percent were female, less than half the CDI average of 13 percent.

Indonesia should publish data on its arms exports, including the destination countries. It has ratified only five of the nine security treaties for which the CDI gives credit: for example, it has not signed the Convention on Cluster Munitions and should do so to improve.
components.technology:
Indonesia ranks 22nd on technology—its strongest component.

Indonesia’s trade agreements with developing countries are the least restrictive with respect to intellectual property rights of all CDI countries, helping to facilitate the transfer of global knowledge. It also ranks in the top five on research collaboration, indicating that its international research partnerships are more likely to be with academics from lower-income countries than for the average CDI country.

Indonesia has the most room for improvement on the number of foreign students it accepts: it has a relatively low population of foreign students from lower-income countries relative to its domestic tertiary student population, ranking second-lowest on this indicator, and these students are less likely to be female than for the average CDI country (46 percent compared to an average of 49 percent). The Indonesian government also spends less on research and development relative to the size of its economy (0.20 percent of its GNI) than the other middle-income countries included in the CDI.

IND.overall:
India ranks 36th in the Commitment to Development Index. Its best performance is on the environment component, where it ranks 8th, with very low emissions levels per capita. It has the most room for improvement on trade and development finance, where it comes last, and investment, migration and security, where it also comes in the bottom six countries in each.

When we assess India relative to expectations based on its income level, it rises by six ranks to 30th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
India ranks 38th on the development finance component.

India ranks 31st for the amount of Finance for International Development it provides, which is worth 0.03 percent of its GNI (although it is still a significant receiver of development finance itself). India is ranked 38th for the quality of its development finance. Its development finance contracts are only open to Indian firms, and it does not provide project-level information on its bilateral finance. No data was available with which to assess how closely India’s development finance aligns with partner countries’ priorities. India could improve the quality of its development finance by channelling a higher share through multilateral agencies—it provided 20 percent of its finance through multilaterals in 2023, half the share it provided in 2022 and far below the CDI average of 47 percent.
components.investment:
India ranks 33rd on the investment component.

India does poorly for financial secrecy, especially its lack of public country-by-country reporting requirements, ranking 34th on this indicator. Still, India ranks joint 1st for its corporate tax rate alignment, with its rates exceeding both the globally agreed 15 percent minimum and the developing country average of 25 percent, therefore limiting potential base erosion and profit shifting from other jurisdictions. India comes mid-table for the extent to which its investment treaties afford policy space for partners to pursue their development objectives.

According to Transparency International, India does not enforce the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and although it participates in the Kimberley Process for preventing conflict diamonds, it neither supports nor implements the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative.
components.migration:
India ranks 36th on the migration component.

India ranks near the bottom for the number of migrants arriving per head of population, although these migrants were more likely to be from poorer countries than for other CDI countries. Also, 57 percent of migrants were female, compared to a CDI average of 48 percent, placing India in the top five for the gender balance of its migrant inflows. India also accepts few refugees relative to the size of its population, with 0.2 refugees per 1,000 people—putting it 31st on this indicator.

India has most room for improvement on its migrant integration policies, where it ranks second to last. It should also ratify the International Labour Organization conventions on migration for employment and migrant workers.
components.trade:
India ranks last (38th) on trade.

India is ranked in the bottom five on the average tariff indicator for having high average tariff rates (when these are weighted in inverse proportion to the income of its trading partners). It has the fourth-highest number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher). It also has among the highest restrictions on trade in services, in particular for legal and rail freight transport services. It is in the bottom 10 for the quality of its trade infrastructure and its customs procedures.

India is mid-table on agricultural subsidies. It provides subsidies worth 11.8 percent of agricultural production, lower than the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
India ranks 8th on the environment component, its highest rank, and an improvement of 11 places since the last CDI, reflecting newly available data on fishing subsidies.

India performs well on climate action indicators, with the lowest direct greenhouse gas emissions of any CDI country, at 2.6 tonnes CO2 equivalent per capita, compared to an average among CDI countries of 9.1 tonnes. It also has negative emissions embodied in its international trade. India ranks mid-table (19th) for its production of fossil fuels, but it comes in the top half for the low subsidies it provides to fossil fuel production and consumption. Still, India has limited ambition in its climate targets. According to its Nationally Determined Contribution, by 2030, India plans to reduce emissions by 25 percent relative to a business-as-usual scenario (which incorporates continued strong economic growth). It has significant room for improvement on carbon pricing, where it ranks joint last for taking no measures to increase the cost of emitting carbon.

India should increase its participation in international biodiversity and environmental agreements, where it comes in joint 17th. It has not yet accepted the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fisheries Subsidies, and it should improve its reporting under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. Unlike for previous iterations of the CDI, some data is now available on the harmful subsidies India provides to fishing. We estimate this amounted to 2.5 percent of the value of landings, placing India 22nd on this indicator, and improving significantly on those countries with missing data.
components.health:
India ranks 26th on the health component. It now signs up to all the treaties, memberships, and codes we assess. India has also substantially improved its regulation of tobacco supply and trade.

However, India’s government has still made relatively expansive use of export restrictions on food and medical goods over the last two years, ranking 36th. India restricted trade in 64 relevant products in this period—well above the CDI median of 11—and these restrictions applied for longer than most others.

India also improved its domestic vaccination efforts, with coverage for both the measles and diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccines moving above 90 percent and towards the World Health Organization target of 95 percent.

India’s efforts to counter antimicrobial resistance (AMR) are below average: antibiotic consumption among both its human and its livestock populations is lower than CDI averages, but it should build on its recent membership of the WHO’s Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System (GLASS) module on antimicrobial consumption to improve its wider regulatory framework surrounding AMR.
components.security:
India ranks 33rd on the security component, rising by six ranks to 27th when its score is adjusted for income.

India exports relatively few weapons: arms exports are estimated to be worth 0.06 percent of its GNI compared to a CDI median of 0.18 percent. However, these are much more likely to be exported to more conflict-prone countries—those that are poorer, more militaristic, and less democratic—than exports from the average CDI country.

India has only ratified two of the nine security conventions for which the CDI gives credit (on chemical weapons and on certain conventional weapons. It is also in the bottom 10 countries for total contributions to peacekeeping missions (worth 0.009 percent of GNI), and only 2 percent of India’s UN peacekeeping troops are female, compared to a CDI average of 13 percent.
components.technology:
India ranks 31st on the technology component but jumps to 25th when scores are adjusted for income.

The Indian federal government’s support for the creation of new knowledge is relatively low, with its direct expenditure on research and development worth 0.39 percent of its GNI, compared to a CDI average of 0.55 percent.

India ranks in the top 10 countries for both its international research collaborations with lower-income countries and the extent to which it supports the diffusion of technology through its bilateral free trade agreements, indicating that its trade agreements contain intellectual property rights clauses that are less restrictive beyond World Trade Organization standards than those of most other CDI countries. However, India accepts relatively few foreign students relative to the size of its tertiary student population, and only 34 percent of its foreign student population is female, meaning it ranks 36th on both the foreign students and female foreign students indicators.

IRL.overall:
Ireland ranks 19th in the Commitment to Development Index. Its best rankings are in security (4th) and development finance (7th). It has the most room for improvement in technology (37th)—especially by providing more government funding for research and development—and environment (29th).

When we assess Ireland relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank falls by 13 places, to 32nd. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Ireland ranks 7th in the development finance component. It ranks mid-table for the quantity of cross-border Finance for International Development it provides, giving 0.32 percent of its GNI (the CDI average is 0.28 percent).

However, it ranks first on the quality of this finance for being transparent and completely untied, meaning it is open to bids from providers of other nationalities. It provides 54 percent, or a slightly higher-than-average share of its development finance via multilateral agencies. Its bilateral development finance has a very strong focus on poorer countries and a fairly strong focus on fragile countries.
components.investment:
Ireland ranks 24th in the investment component, falling 9 ranks to 33rd when its score is adjusted for its relatively high income.

Ireland has strong policies to ensure transparency in the financial sector, particularly in requiring its multinational firms to report on activities for each country in which they are active. Its bilateral investment agreements rank in the top 10 for how much policy space they afford Ireland’s counterparts to pursue their development objectives. However, Ireland ranks joint last on anticorruption as it has little to no enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, as assessed by Transparency International.

Ireland does very poorly on its corporate tax rate alignment—at 0.005 percent according to the Tax Justice Network, its lowest available corporate tax rate is the joint lowest in the CDI, far below the globally agreed 15 percent effective minimum, meaning Ireland is at higher risk than other countries of being used for corporate tax avoidance.
components.migration:
Ireland ranks 13th in the migration component, an improvement of six places since the last CDI.

It comes in the top 10 countries for refugee hosting, with 22.3 refugees per 1,000 people—a substantial improvement over its 2021 CDI performance, with a near tenfold increase in refugee hosting—largely due to an influx of Ukrainian refugees. Ireland also ranks in the top half for its domestic policies for integrating migrants into its society and economy, and in the top 10 for the proportion of migrants that are female: 53 percent against a CDI average of 48 percent.

Ireland has improved 20 places on its non-refugee migrant inflows from poorer countries, where it now ranks 15th; its level of inward migration per head is above average, although migrants tend to be from higher-income countries than most CDI countries. However, Ireland is joint last for its participation in international migration agreements. It should better protect their rights by ratifying the Migration for Employment and Migrant Workers conventions, as well as undergoing a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Ireland ranks 21st in the trade component. It performs well on limiting trade restrictions, ranking 9th for having few services trade restrictions, and, along with other EU members, joint 4th on tariff rates and joint 7th on the number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more). All tariffs are weighted inversely to trading partner income. However, Ireland ranks mid-table on trade logistics and 33rd on agricultural subsidies (a policy largely decided at the EU rather than country level): its farmers receive 21.7 percent of production value in subsidies, nearly double the CDI average of 12.6 percent.

Ireland could improve trade access for lower-income countries by improving the quality of its customs procedures and trade infrastructure, and by seeking to reduce the level of agricultural subsidies in forthcoming negotiations over the EU budget.
components.environment:
Ireland ranks 29th in the environment component.

Much of Ireland’s low ranking relates to its greenhouse gas emissions. Though its direct emissions from energy, industry, waste, and agriculture have fallen in recent years, at 10.7 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, they remain above the CDI average of 9.1. It also has relatively high emissions from land use and forestry, and those embodied in international trade. Ireland’s support to fossil fuel production and consumption is over 1 percent of GNI, and it ranks 29th on that indicator. Ireland should reduce the subsidies it provides for oil use and production especially, which are currently worth more than double the CDI average.

Ireland, like many EU countries, performs relatively well on carbon pricing, adding $25.39 to the cost of a tonne of emitted CO2, compared to a CDI average of $15.23. However, the EU’s fishing subsidy regime as applied in Ireland means its harmful fishing subsidies are worth 4.5 percent of landed fish value—far higher than the CDI median of 2.2 percent. Ireland also has room for improvement in how it engages with international biodiversity and environmental agreements; it has not submitted reports on the implementation of either the Convention on Biological Diversity or the UN Convention to Combat Desertification.
components.health:
Ireland ranks 23rd in the health component.

Along with other EU member states, it performs relatively well for how few export restrictions it imposes on food and health products. Ireland also performs above average on regulating international tobacco supply chains, having signed the Framework Convention for Tobacco Control and requiring multiple conditions on selling tobacco that help identify illicit trade.

In the health treaties, codes, and memberships indicator, Ireland has signed up to both the antimicrobial resistance and consumption modules of the World Health Organization’s (WHO) Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System. However, while its consumption of antibiotics in humans and animals is below average, its wider AMR governance is relatively weak; Ireland could complete a Joint External Evaluation with the WHO to improve on this front. This would also contribute to its pandemic preparedness, for which it is among 11 CDI countries that have not fulfilled any of the four measures we assess; for example, Ireland has not updated a national influenza plan in the last decade.

Ireland should also increase vaccine rates. Its measles coverage (at the nationally recommended age) is just 80 percent—well below the CDI median of 92 percent and the WHO target of 95 percent.
components.security:
Ireland ranks 4th in the security component, making this its strongest area in the CDI.

Ireland has ratified all nine major security treaties assessed by the CDI, ranking joint first on this indicator. It also ranks 4th on peacekeeping contributions as it contributes large numbers of troops to UN missions. However, Ireland should increase the number of women peacekeepers it sends to UN missions (6 percent are women, compared to the CDI average of 13 percent, ranking it 29th).

Ireland also performs strongly—within the top 10—on its arms trade: its arms exports as a proportion of GNI are the third lowest of all CDI countries, and these exports are less likely to go to fragile or militaristic states than for the average CDI country.

Ireland could further improve on this component by contributing vessels to protecting international sea lanes: it currently contributes none and ranks joint last on this indicator.
components.technology:
Ireland ranks 37th in the technology component, making this the area with the most scope for improvement.

It provides greater tax incentives for private research and development (R&D) than the average CDI country, worth 0.25 percent of GNI compared to 0.19 percent. However, Ireland could also stimulate more innovation by increasing direct government funding, as it allocates approximately 0.25 percent of GNI for R&D, less than half the CDI average of 0.55 percent.

Ireland should also make greater efforts to stimulate the international flow of its knowledge: along with other EU members, its free trade agreements are more restrictive than the standard World Trade Organization intellectual property right provisions. Furthermore, its academics tend to collaborate with researchers from lower-income countries less often than do researchers from most other CDI countries (it ranks 24th on this indicator).

ITA.overall:
Italy ranks 21st on the Commitment to Development Index. Its best performances are on the investment and environment components, where it comes in 7th and 15th, respectively. It has the most room for improvement on the technology and health components, where it ranks in the bottom 10. In particular, Italy should reduce its consumption of antibiotics and do more to foster research collaboration with academics from poorer countries.

When we assess Italy relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises to 17th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Italy ranks 16th on the development finance component.

Italy provides 0.20 percent of its GNI as cross-border Finance for International Development, below the CDI average of 0.28 percent and ranking 22nd. It does relatively well on the quality of this finance, for which it ranks 10th. It ranks joint 1st on the transparency of this finance because it provides project-level information through the OECD Creditor Reporting System, as well as for the degree to which its development finance is in line with the priorities of partner countries. In line with its medium-term development policy, Italy’s development finance is also directed towards countries that are poorer and more fragile than the CDI average, with a particular focus on Africa.

To improve further on this component, it should increase the amount of development finance it provides.
components.investment:
Italy ranks 7th on the investment component, its highest rank in the index.

Italy scores well—joint 1st—in our measure of corporate tax rate alignment, with its tax rates being above the globally agreed 15 percent minimum, as well as the developing country average of 25 percent. Italy also performs well on limiting financial secrecy, coming in the top five, with particularly good scores for regulations governing anti-money laundering and for requiring companies to provide country-by-country reports of their activities. It also ranks joint top on business and human rights for taking part in peer reviews of multinational enterprise regulations and having adopted a National Action Plan on business and human rights.

Italy ranks joint 15th on the natural resources indicator: while it participates in the Kimberley Process for preventing conflict diamonds, it neither supports nor implements the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. It also has room for improvement on the degree of development policy space it leaves its partner countries in its bilateral investment treaties.
components.migration:
Italy ranks 20th on the migration component.

Despite its geographical position in Southern Europe and its proximity to some of the “migration hotspots” in North Africa where many refugees to Europe depart from, Italy hosts 5 refugees per 1,000 people, which is under half of the CDI average of 11, and it also receives fewer (non-refugee) migrants from poorer countries relative to its population than the average CDI country. Italy has improved on the proportion of migrants that are female: up from 45 percent in the 2021 CDI to 48 percent, in line with the CDI average.

Italy ranks joint 2nd for its participation in international migration conventions, having ratified both International Labour Organization conventions for which the CDI gives credit, but not having yet completed a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration. It is also in the top half of the table for its domestic migrant integration policies.
components.trade:
Italy ranks 19th on the trade component.

Along with other EU members, Italy ranks joint 4th and joint 7th on the tariff averages and tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more) indicators respectively, with EU tariffs being generally low and having several exemptions for lower-income countries. However, Italy has significant room for improvement on services trade restrictiveness, where it ranks 30th owing in part to particularly harsh restrictions on trade in air transport and engineering services. Italy ranks mid-table for its trade logistics.

Italy should reduce its trade-distorting agricultural subsidies through the EU, which amount to 9.9 percent of farm gate production, and where Italy ranks 17th among CDI countries.
components.environment:
Italy ranks 15th on the environment component. It has ratified all biodiversity and environmental agreements for which the CDI gives credit, but it should produce a more up-to-date implementation report on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. It performs well for its low levels of fossil fuel production, ranking 13th, as it produces no coal and little oil and gas. Furthermore, Italy’s direct greenhouse gas emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry are lower than the CDI average, at 6.5 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per person (with the CDI average being 9.1).

Italy has the most room for improvement on the financial support it provides for fossil fuel production and consumption, where it is in the bottom five countries, amounting to 1.8 percent of GNI. Its harmful fishing subsidies are also high, worth 8.2 percent of production value—well-above the CDI median of 2.2 percent.
components.health:
Italy ranks 29th on the health component.

Italy is in the top half of the table for its relatively strict regulation of international tobacco trade. As other countries have reduced restrictions on food and health trade, Italy has retained them on 17 product lines in the last two years, slightly above the CDI median of 11.

Italy ranks joint 5th on participating in all treaties, codes, and memberships for which the CDI gives credit, including both the consumption and resistance modules of the World Health Organization’s (WHO) Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System. However, Italy has comparatively poor stewardship policies for antimicrobial resistance otherwise, with especially high antibiotic consumption in livestock animals. It has recently completed a Joint External Evaluation with the WHO, which may indicate some commitment to improve its approach.

On pandemic preparedness, Italy has substantial room for improvement, with no national influenza plan in the last decade and no recent biological simulation exercise.
components.security:
Italy ranks 18th on the security component, rising by seven ranks to 11th when adjusting for its income level.

Italy has ratified all international security treaties for which the CDI gives credit, ranking joint 1st on the indicator. It also performs relatively well on sea lanes protection, providing vessels worth 0.026 percent of GNI, ninth highest of CDI countries.

Although Italy is in the top 10 for the value of financial and troop contributions to peacekeeping missions it provides (to both UN and non-UN peacekeeping missions), the share of troops provided to UN missions that are women is low at 5 percent, compared to the CDI average of 13 percent.

Italy also has room for improvement on the proportion of arms exports it sends to poorer, more militaristic, and less democratic countries (such as Qatar and Kuwait), as this is above the CDI average.
components.technology:
Italy ranks 35th on the technology component, its lowest rank.

Italy’s government gives direct support for research and development (R&D) worth 0.49 percent of its GNI, lower than the CDI average of 0.55 percent. It also ranks in the bottom half of countries on the tax incentives it provides for private R&D, which are worth just 0.15 percent of GNI.

In terms of policies to encourage technology transfer and diffusion, Italy accepts fewer foreign students from poorer countries than most CDI countries, ranking 24th on the indicator—though 55 percent of those students are female (sixth highest in the CDI). Italy has the most room for improvement on research collaboration, indicating that Italian researchers are less likely to co-author with researchers in low-income countries than researchers in most other CDI countries. Along with other EU countries, Italy’s trade agreements are highly restrictive when it comes to intellectual property, going beyond existing World Trade Organization standards. This can prevent the spread of useful knowledge to lower-income countries.

JPN.overall:
Japan ranks 20th in the Commitment to Development Index. It does well on health, trade, and investment, coming in the top 10 on each. However, it ranks in the bottom half of the table in the migration component.

Japan performs strongly in the prevention of disease through high vaccination coverage and strong pandemic preparedness. It could, however, be more welcoming towards migrants and refugees, and it also has scope for more ambition on carbon pricing.

Japan’s overall rank does not change when we assess it relative to expectations based on its income level. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Japan ranks 31st on development finance, a fall of 14 places relative to the 2023 CDI, largely due to declining quality.

While Japan contributes 0.37 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development (just above the CDI average and an increase on the previous assessment), it has significant room for improvement on this finance’s quality, on which it ranks 35th.

Although Japan is transparent in its reporting and its projects generally align well with recipient priorities, its bilateral finance is increasingly tied to Japanese contractors and, in line with a broader strategic focus on the Indo-Pacific, is not focused on lower-income or fragile countries. The 16 percent share of its finance provided multilaterally is under half the average of 47 percent, and 8 percent lower than our last assessment.
components.investment:
Japan ranks 8th in investment, which makes it one of its strongest components.

Japan has adopted a national action plan on business and human rights and supports natural resource governance initiatives. Japan also shows strength in affording its counterparts a high degree of policy space to pursue their development objectives in its international investment agreements, placing it 4th on the indicator. Japan’s lowest available corporate tax rate is above both the 15 percent globally agreed minimum and the developing country average of 25 percent.

Japan has significant scope for improvement on financial secrecy, where it ranks 25th. It can do this by enhancing international legal cooperation, adhering more closely to the Financial Action Task Force’s recommendations on anti-money laundering, and requiring country-by-country reporting of activities by its companies. Japan can also increase the efficiency of its investment by enhancing its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention.
components.migration:
Japan ranks 33rd in the migration component. It reported some increase in migrant inflow relative to the last CDI but with very few immigrants from lower-income countries, it remained in the bottom 10 countries on this indicator. In addition, the absence of OECD data on the gender of its migrants meant that updated UN data was used, which suggested a low proportion of its immigrants have been female.

Japan could improve on migration, its weakest CDI component, by increasing the number of refugees it hosts. The current level is just 0.2 refugees per thousand of its population and is 30 times smaller than even the median country level (of 6.6 per thousand). It could also develop its domestic integration policies for migrants.
components.trade:
Japan ranks 6th in the trade component. Japan does well on ensuring a smooth customs regime and has good trade infrastructure. Japan’s distortionary agricultural subsidies have room for improvement—they increased slightly since the last CDI and are now worth 10.4 percent of the value of production and while they are below the CDI average of 12.6 percent, Japan ranks 18th on this indicator.

Japan has low barriers to trade in services, but it should do more to reduce both its average tariff rates and the number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more) towards lower-income countries; for each of these indicators, it ranks in the bottom half of countries.
components.environment:
Japan ranks 24th in the environment component, an improvement of five places from its performance on the 2023 CDI, reflecting new commitments to environmental treaties.

Japan’s greenhouse gas emissions per capita are in the bottom half of CDI countries. They are slightly lower than the CDI average across direct emissions and emissions from land use change and forestry, but slightly higher in emissions embodied in its international trade. However, its climate ambition is among the bottom 10 countries, with planned emissions reductions of just 27 percent relative to projected emissions in 2030.

Although Japan produces virtually no fossil fuels, ranking third on that indicator, it has significantly increased its fossil fuel subsidies since the last CDI. Its subsidies are now worth 0.6 percent of GNI, putting it in the bottom half of CDI countries. It also has significant scope to increase its ambition on carbon pricing. It currently imposes an average additional cost per tonne of CO2 emitted of $1.57, compared to the CDI average of $15.23.

Japan should also work to eliminate its currently very high harmful fishing subsidies, worth 10.1 percent of landed fish value and over the CDI average of 9.9 percent.

Japan has recently agreed to the fish subsidies agreement at the World Trade Organization, and has also updated its reporting to the UN Convention on Desertification, meaning it has moved into the top half of countries in its commitment to environmental and biodiversity treaties.
components.health:
Japan ranks 6th in the health component. In particular, Japan performs well on pandemic preparedness, and it has not imposed any restrictions on food and health exports affecting developing countries in the last two years. Japan has a National Action Plan on antimicrobial resistance, ranking second highest among CDI countries on AMR governance, though it can still reduce the risk of disease resistance by reducing its high livestock antibiotic consumption.

Japan also has high vaccination coverage for both measles and diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis, at 94 percent and 98 percent, respectively, and both above the medians of CDI countries (of 92 percent and 95 percent). However, Japan should improve its efforts on international tobacco regulation by signing the Protocol against Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products.
components.security:
Japan ranks 28th in the security component. It shows strengths in its engagement with international security conventions, with only Protocol V of the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons yet to be ratified. Japan also contributes some vessels to the protection of sea lanes in addition to its financial and troop contributions to peacekeeping efforts (ranking mid-table for each). Of the peacekeepers Japan contributes, 27 percent are women, which is among the highest in the CDI and over double the average.

With the lifting of its domestic arms exports ban in 2014, Japan should publish disaggregated data detailing the scale and recipients of arms exports—although these are likely to be small in volume, the lack of transparency means it is penalized on this indicator.
components.technology:
Japan ranks 16th in the technology component. It does very well in providing tax incentives for business research and development, contributing 0.47 percent of GNI in implied subsidies—the second highest in the CDI and two-and-a-half times the average. Japan also performs relatively well in research collaboration with lower-income countries, and it has few additional intellectual property rights restrictions beyond existing World Trade Organization standards in its free trade agreements with lower-income country partners.

However, Japan could increase the diffusion of technology by increasing the number of foreign students it hosts. It currently has a significantly lower proportion of foreign students from low-income countries compared to its CDI peers, and only 44 percent of foreign students are female.

KOR.overall:
South Korea ranks 24th in the Commitment to Development Index, with its best rank in the technology component (1st). It has most room for improvement in trade (33rd) and development finance (32nd).

When we assess South Korea relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank does not change. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
South Korea ranks 32nd in the development finance component. It ranks mid-table on development finance quantity, giving 0.20 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development—this marks an increase from two years ago, but is still slightly less than the CDI average of 0.28 percent.

It ranks in the bottom half of the table (31st) on development finance quality. It transparently publishes development finance data, and its development projects were reported by recipients as aligning with their development priorities more than for most other CDI countries. However, its financing is somewhat tied to Korean contractors and a smaller share than average—20 percent—is channelled through multilateral organisations. Furthermore, it has a slightly lower-than-average focus on poor states.
components.investment:
South Korea ranks 23rd in the investment component. It does well on bilateral investment agreements, indicating that it includes fewer clauses which protect its investors at the expense of the development policy space of their hosts in these agreements than do most other CDI countries. It also ranks joint top on the new corporate tax rate alignment indicator, with a corporate tax rate well above the globally agreed effective minimum of 15 percent.

However, South Korea ranks near the bottom of the table on natural resources because it neither implements nor supports the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. It ranks mid-table on business and human rights as it has no National Action Plan (NAP) on business and human rights, though it does include a chapter on business and human rights in a broader NAP. Furthermore, South Korea is assessed as having little or no enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention.

South Korea has made some improvements on limiting financial secrecy, having improved its international legal cooperation and reduced its banking secrecy. However, it could further improve by requiring its multinationals to submit annual country-by-country reports on operations to limit corruption and fully complying with the Financial Action Task Force’s beneficial ownership assessment.
components.migration:
South Korea ranks 29th in the migration component. It ranks in the bottom half of the table on migrant inflow (weighted inversely by migrant origin countries' incomes), and the migrants it does accept are less likely to be women than other CDI countries (at 44 percent compared to an average of 48 percent). It performs poorly on refugee hosting, with 0.1 refugees per 1,000 people—70 times fewer than the median CDI country.

South Korea’s domestic policies to help migrants integrate into society and the economy are about average, ranking joint 18th. It has completed a voluntary review of the UN Global Compact on Migration, though it has yet to ratify the International Labour Organization’s Migration for Employment Convention or its Migrant Workers Convention.
components.trade:
South Korea ranks 33rd in the trade component, its worst component. It ranks in the top half of the table on agricultural subsidies, providing 8.0 percent of farm gate production value in agricultural subsidies compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent. It does well on trade logistics—ranking joint 9th—with the quality of its customs and trade infrastructure both better than average among CDI countries.

However, South Korea’s services trade is highly restrictive, according to the OECD. Furthermore, it ranks last on the average tariff rates it imposes (when weighted inversely by the incomes of its trading partners), and in the bottom 10 on the number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher). To improve its trade-related policies, South Korea should liberalise its services trade and reduce the tariffs it imposes on its lower-income trading partners.
components.environment:
South Korea ranks 26th in the environment component. It has a relatively high level of greenhouse gas emissions, ranking 29th on the indicator. Direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry account for 13.2 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, compared to a CDI average of 9.1 tonnes. It does show high ambition for reducing these, with its Nationally Determined Contribution implying that it intends to reduce emissions by 38 percent below business-as-usual projections suggest it will be emitting in 2030—the 10th most ambitious target of all CDI countries. Korea also does well for its low production of fossil fuels, ranking in the top 10. However, its subsidies for oil have increased since the last CDI, and it is only just in the top half of countries on avoiding support for fossil fuels.

South Korea does less well for its carbon pricing scheme (which adds only $0.10 on average to the cost of emitting each tonne of CO2, compared to a CDI average of $15.23) and for its middling participation in biodiversity and environment agreements; Korea has accepted the World Trade Organization agreement on fishing subsidies since the last CDI but not the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals.
components.health:
South Korea ranks 20th in the health component. It does well for its high vaccination coverage, ranking joint 2nd with 96 percent coverage for the measles vaccine by the nationally recommended age and 98 percent coverage for the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine—both higher than the CDI medians of 92 and 95 percent, respectively. It imposed very few import export restrictions on food and health products over the last two years, ranking in the top 10.

South Korea has made progress since our last edition: it signed up to the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System on antimicrobial consumption and now commits to all seven treaties we consider. Still, there remains room for improvement on antimicrobial resistance (AMR), where it ranks in the bottom half: although its governance of AMR is rated highly, its human consumption of antibiotics is slightly above average (20.2 defined daily doses per 1,000 people per year compared to a CDI average of 19.1) and its use of antibiotics in livestock is considerably more intensive than average.

South Korea should also tackle illicit trade in tobacco and sign the relevant protocol, and it could do more to prepare for pandemics with a national influenza plan and biological simulation exercise.
components.security:
South Korea ranks 30th in the security component. It ranks mid-table for the amount it contributes to peacekeeping efforts—its contributions in troops and finances are worth 0.015 percent of GNI, compared to the CDI average of 0.019 percent. Of the peacekeeping troops it sends on UN missions, only 6 percent are female—less than half the 13 percent CDI average. South Korea does slightly better for its protection of sea lanes, as the vessels it contributes for this purpose are worth 0.003 percent of GNI compared to a CDI median of 0.001 percent.

South Korea ranks towards the bottom of the table on arms trade and its participation in international security conventions. Its exports of arms are worth 0.60 percent of GNI—three times the CDI median of 0.18 percent, and the recipients of these exports tend to be about as prone to conflict (poorer, more militaristic, and less democratic) as average across CDI countries. South Korea should become a signatory of both the Convention on Cluster Munitions and the Anti-Personnel Mine Ban Convention, and ratify the remaining protocols of the UN Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons.
components.technology:
South Korea ranks top of the technology component by some margin. It has very strong policies on knowledge creation: it has the highest level of direct government support for research and development (R&D), worth 1.2 percent of GNI, and the highest tax incentives for private R&D, worth 0.56 percent of GNI. These compare to CDI averages of 0.55 and 0.19 percent of GNI, respectively.

Its policies on knowledge diffusion are slightly weaker, particularly on the number of foreign students it hosts from lower-income countries (where it ranks 27th). That said, of the students it does accept, 57 percent are female—the third-highest proportion of all CDI countries. It also does fairly well on its international research collaborations, with academics from lower-income countries represented in its publications. It ranks near the top of the table on intellectual property rights, indicating that its free trade agreements generally contain fewer intellectual property rights restrictions beyond existing World Trade Organization standards than most other CDI countries.

LUX.overall:
Luxembourg ranks 10th in the Commitment to Development Index, an improvement of four ranks compared to the 2023 CDI.

Luxembourg ranks top on the development finance component, providing a large amount of finance relative to the size of its economy. It also performs well on migration, ranking 3rd, and technology, ranking 6th. Its weakest component is investment, where it ranks in the bottom five due to its weak enforcement of anticorruption and its low corporate tax rate. It also has room for improvement on security, where it ranks in the bottom half of countries.

When we assess Luxembourg relative to expectations based on its income level, it falls by 15 ranks to 25th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Luxembourg ranks 1st in the development finance component, dropping to 3rd if scores are adjusted based on its income level.

Luxembourg ranks top of the quantity indicator, contributing 0.93 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development, a cross-border grant-equivalent measure. It has also consistently met or exceeded the UN target of providing 0.7 percent of its GNI as official development assistance, providing 1 percent in 2024.

Luxembourg ranks 14th on development finance quality. It performs well in ensuring that its finance is focused on lower-income and fragile countries, and reports on its development finance transparently. However, Luxembourg does worse than average at ensuring its development projects align with its partners’ priorities, and the degree to which it ties its development finance to the use of its own goods and services has increased since our assessment in 2023.
components.investment:
Luxembourg ranks 35th in the investment component, and 37th after we adjust for its income, making this its weakest component by some margin.

Luxembourg ranks mid-table at 19th on limiting financial secrecy. It does well in requiring that multinational enterprises incorporated in the country are required to submit country-by-country financial reporting data, but it has a high degree of banking secrecy and fulfills relatively few of the Financial Action Task Force’s recommendations on anti-money laundering.

Luxembourg does well in having a National Action Plan on business and human rights, and it also supports the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. However, it is not a member of the Kimberley Process on conflict diamonds, meaning it ranks joint 15th on its approach to natural resource governance. It is assessed as having “limited to no enforcement” of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, meaning it ranks joint last on the anticorruption indicator. It also has scope for improving the degree of policy space in its bilateral investment agreements for its partners to pursue their own development objectives.

Luxembourg does poorly on the corporate tax rate alignment indicator—at 0.3 percent, its lowest available corporate tax rate is higher than those of only two other CDI countries and far below the globally agreed 15 percent effective minimum. This means Luxembourg is at higher risk than other countries of being used for corporate tax avoidance.
components.migration:
Luxembourg ranks 3rd in the migration component, though this drops to 9th when adjusting for income.

Luxembourg receives the highest number of non-refugee migrants relative to its population and, after inversely weighting by the income of the origin country, tops this indicator. The female share of migrants is 49 percent, just above the CDI average of 48. Luxembourg is in the top half of countries for hosting refugees, with 15 per 1,000 of population, and above the CDI average of 11.

Although Luxembourg has effective domestic integration policies for migrants, it has not ratified the International Labour Organization’s Migration for Employment Convention or the Migrant Workers Convention—nor has it completed a voluntary review of the implementation of the UN Global Compact on Migration.
components.trade:
Luxembourg ranks 17th in the trade component, an improvement of six places since the last CDI.

As an EU member, it has low average tariff levels and few tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher), ranking joint 4th and joint 7th on these indicators respectively. Luxembourg’s performances on World Bank assessments of trade logistics and infrastructure are around average, but the OECD has assessed it as having reduced restrictions on its services trade, where it is among the 10 least restrictive CDI countries.

Luxembourg has the most room for improvement on the high agricultural subsidies it provides. Although these fell since the 2023 CDI from 28.7 percent to 18.6 percent of the value of production, they remain among the 10 highest in the CDI and well-above the average of 12.6 percent. These subsidies distort trade and put developing-country producers at a disadvantage, and Luxembourg should push for the EU to reduce them.
components.environment:
Luxembourg ranks 19th in the environment component.

Luxembourg’s greenhouse gas emissions have fallen over the last decade, but it still has scope to reduce its direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry, which currently stand at 11.8 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita—and above the CDI average of 9.1 tonnes (Luxembourg emitted 17.1 tonnes per head in 2018). Luxembourg ranks top for its low fossil fuel production—producing no oil, coal, or gas. Since the last CDI, it has reduced the level of subsidies it provides for fossil fuel consumption, and now ranks 9th. Luxembourg has also continued to increase its carbon price, with the average tonne of CO2 now costing an additional $44.11—almost triple the current CDI average of $15.23.

Luxembourg does not provide harmful fishing subsidies and participates in most of the biodiversity and environment agreements assessed by the CDI, though it should improve reporting under the UN Convention to Combat Desertification and the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora.
components.health:
Luxembourg ranks 17th in the health component.

Luxembourg performs well on export restrictions of food and health-related goods, with relatively few product lines restricted over the past two years. It also performs better than its CDI peers in regulating international tobacco supply chains, ranking joint 9th.

Luxembourg’s vaccination coverage is above average, with 99 percent coverage for the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine among 1-year-olds, though it could improve its measles vaccination coverage, which stands at 90 percent—below the World Health Organization’s target level of 95 percent.

Luxembourg has the most room for improvement on its pandemic preparedness, for which it ranks joint last: it should update its national influenza plan and complete a Joint External Evaluation (JEE) with the World Health Organization. Completing a JEE would also contribute to improving its antimicrobial resistance governance and help tackle its above-average human antibiotic consumption.
components.security:
Luxembourg ranks 21st in the security component, though this falls to 30th when we adjust for income.

Luxembourg ranks mid-table for its peacekeeping contributions, equivalent to 0.014 percent of its GNI, slightly less than the CDI average of 0.019 percent. Furthermore, none of its UN peacekeepers were women, meaning it ranks joint last on that indicator.

Luxembourg ranks 2nd on the arms trade indicator: as a percentage of GNI, these were worth the second lowest in the CDI, and were furthermore exported to countries with the among lowest conflict potential (least poor, militaristic, and undemocratic) of all CDI countries. It has also ratified all nine international security conventions assessed in the CDI, ranking joint first on the indicator.
components.technology:
Luxembourg ranks 6th in the technology component.

Luxembourg allocates a large share of its GNI directly to research and development (R&D) at 0.71 percent, which is significantly above the CDI average of 0.55 percent (ranking 8th), though it does not provide tax incentives for business R&D (ranking 37th).

Luxembourg has a mixed performance on its policies for knowledge diffusion: it shows strength in its high number of international students, which account for just over 50 percent of its tertiary student population, though these tend to come from countries with higher incomes than average. Overall, it ranks third on foreign students. Furthermore, 52 percent of international students are female, higher than the CDI average of 49 percent. Luxembourg performs relatively worse on the representation of researchers from lower-income countries in international research publications, ranking 28th, and, like other EU countries, Luxembourg’s free trade agreements with developing countries include intellectual property rights clauses that are more restrictive than agreed under World Trade Organization standards.

MEX.overall:
Mexico ranks 37th in the Commitment to Development Index. Of the nine middle-income countries the CDI assesses, it is the 8th best performer. Mexico’s highest rankings are in security (29th) and environment and health (both 30th). It has the most room for improvement in the technology and development finance components, where it ranked 38th and 35th, respectively.

When we assess Mexico relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises by two places to 35th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Mexico ranks 35th in the development finance component, its second-lowest-scoring component.

Mexico ranks second to last for the quantity of Finance for International Development provided, contributing just 0.01 percent of its GNI, compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent of GNI.

Mexico ranks 33rd for the quality of the development finance it provides, buoyed by the relatively high proportion it channels through multilateral agencies and the fact that very little of Mexico’s finance is tied to its own goods and services. Mexico should do more to improve the transparency of its bilateral finance by reporting project-specific information for its development projects. It should also focus on ensuring a greater share of its aid is directed to poorer and more fragile countries.
components.investment:
Mexico ranks 34th in the investment component.

Mexico ranks in the top five countries for its international investment agreements, providing its counterparts with more policy space to pursue their development objectives than most other CDI countries. However, it ranks joint last on enforcing the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, as well as on the new corporate tax rate alignment indicator—the lowest available corporate income tax rate in the jurisdiction is 0 percent, meaning it is more at risk of being used to facilitate tax avoidance by large multinational enterprises.
components.migration:
Mexico ranks 32nd in the migration component.

Mexico accepts relatively few migrants relative to its population (when inversely weighted by the income of origin countries) and ranks in the bottom half of the table on this indicator, and the female share has dropped just below the CDI average. Mexico has middling domestic policies to help migrants integrate into society and the economy. It should ratify the International Labour Organization’s conventions on Migrant Workers and Migration for Employment, as well as complete a review of its implementation of the Global Compact for Migration.

Mexico hosts relatively few refugees, just 3 per 1,000 of its population compared to a CDI average of 11.
components.trade:
Mexico ranks 34th in the trade component.

Mexico performs well on the level of trade-distorting agricultural subsidies it provides, which are worth just 3.1 percent of farm gate production value compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent. However, it performs relatively poorly on other aspects of trade policy.

Mexico has high average tariff rates (when weighted inversely by its trading partners’ incomes) and a high number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher). Its trade logistics (the efficiency of its customs procedures and its trade infrastructure) are poor, ranking 38th, and its services trade is similarly restricted as assessed by the OECD.
components.environment:
Mexico ranks 30th on environment, a fall of eight places since the last CDI. The latest data on harmful fishing subsidies shows a significant increase since the last CDI, with their value now exceeding 11 percent of the value of landed fish (relative to a CDI median of 2.2 percent), putting Mexico among the bottom 10 countries on this measure.

Mexico ranks in the top 10 countries for its low levels of greenhouse gas emissions; since the 2023 CDI, its direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry rose half a tonne to 6.1 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, relative to the CDI average of 9.1 tonnes per capita. However, its climate ambition, as indicated by the targets set out in its Nationally Determined Contribution, suggests just a 19 percent reduction relative to a business-as-usual projection.

Mexico has significant room for improvement on its financial support to the domestic consumption and production of fossil fuels, where it ranks third bottom. As well as reducing these subsidies, Mexico should strengthen its carbon pricing scheme (it currently adds just $0.59 on average per tonne of CO2 emitted compared to an average of $15.23). Mexico is also among the minority of countries that have agreed to neither the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fisheries and the Convention nor the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals.
components.health:
Mexico ranks 30th in the health component.

Mexico ranks in the top half of countries for its approach to antimicrobial resistance (AMR), with the lowest antibiotic consumption rate in humans of any CDI country. It has scope to improve its AMR governance, which it could do by completing a Joint External Evaluation (JEE) with the World Health Organization. Completing a JEE would also contribute to increasing its pandemic preparedness, for which it ranks joint last.

Mexico has applied a relatively high number of export restrictions on health and medical goods, targeting 13 product lines over much of the last two years.

Mexico has improved its vaccination coverage for diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis, which rose seven percentage points to 85 percent since the last CDI though remains below the CDI median of 95 percent. However, Mexico’s measles immunization coverage has fallen and also stands at 85 percent (just below the CDI median of 92 percent).
components.security:
Mexico ranks 29th in the security component.

Mexico only contributes an equivalent of 0.001 percent of its GNI to peacekeeping efforts, ranking third-to-last. Still, of the personnel it does provide to UN peacekeeping missions, Mexico has the highest proportion of women at 41 percent.

Mexico should publish data on the value and destination of its arms exports, and it should accept the remaining protocols of the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons.
components.technology:
Mexico ranks 38th in the technology component.

While Mexico performs well on the degree to which its researchers collaborate with academics from lower-income countries, it has significant room for improvement on its efforts to diffuse knowledge by increasing the intake of foreign students, especially those from lower-income countries, for which it ranks bottom. No data was available to assess the proportion of these foreign students who are female.

Mexico’s government contributes just 0.25 percent of its GNI directly to research and development (R&D), under half of the CDI average of 0.55 percent, and it could increase this to improve on the component. It could also expand its tax incentives for private R&D, which are worth the equivalent of 0.003 percent of its GNI in the latest data (compared to CDI average of 0.19 percent).

NLD.overall:
The Netherlands ranks 11th in the Commitment to Development Index, a drop of five ranks since the last edition. It ranks top of the trade component and in the top 10 for development finance and security. It has the most room for improvement in investment (27th) and technology (24th). In particular, it should focus on improving the development-friendliness of its international investment agreements, improving its adherence to anticorruption investment standards, and collaborating more with researchers from lower-income countries.

When we assess the Netherlands relative to expectations based on its income level, it falls to 16th place. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance: The Netherlands ranks 6th in the development finance component. It gives 0.47 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development, meaning it ranks in the top 10 on development finance quantity, though the government has announced significant cuts to the development budget from 2026 and this figure is likely to fall significantly over the next few years. It is 6th on development finance quality, with its finance being very transparent, mostly untied, and strongly focused on poor countries. It channels a below-average proportion of its cross-border aid through multilateral institutions, and it has room to improve the degree to which its development projects align with recipient country development objectives (though it still performs better than the CDI average on this).
components.investment:
The Netherlands ranks 27th in the investment component—its lowest-ranking component. The Netherlands ranks near the top of the table at joint 4th for its natural resources governance, being a participant in the Kimberley Process to eliminate conflict diamonds and a supporter of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. It ranks joint 8th for its approach to business and human rights, with a national action plan on the subject and strong commitment to the OECD guidelines on multinational enterprises. It should improve its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, currently assessed as “limited” by Transparency International.

The Netherlands ranks mid-table on its financial secrecy: it generally requires its multinationals to submit country-by-country reports on their activities, but it has ample room to improve in banking secrecy, international legal cooperation, and anti-money laundering. The lowest available corporate income tax rate in the jurisdiction is assessed as being 5 percent, lower than the globally agreed minimum of 15 percent—meaning it is at higher risk of being used to facilitate tax avoidance by large multinational enterprises. Furthermore, it ranks 33rd for its bilateral international investment agreements: it should do more to ensure they do not protect its investors at the expense of the policy space of the countries hosting them to pursue development objectives.
components.migration:
The Netherlands ranks 11th on migration, with a middling performance on most of the indicators in the component. Its best performance is on its participation in international migration conventions, for which it ranks joint 2nd, though it should ratify the International Labour Organization’s Migrant Workers convention.

The Netherlands accepts a high number of non-refugee migrants relative to its population, though they tend to come from predominantly higher-income countries, thereby limiting the development effect. The proportion of these migrants that are female (52 percent) has risen slightly and is higher than the CDI average (48 percent). Its domestic policies to help migrants integrate into society and the economy are also slightly better than average. The Netherlands ranks 15th for the number of refugees it hosts: just over 14 per 1,000 people, compared to a CDI average of 11.
components.trade: The Netherlands ranks 1st in the trade component. Along with other EU members, it has low average tariff rates, ranking joint 4th, and imposes few tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher), ranking joint 7th. It has the least restrictive services trade of any CDI country and, according to the World Bank, has strong trade logistics, with good customs and infrastructure. It has the most room for improvement on its trade-distorting agricultural subsidies, provided mostly through the EU, for which it ranks 11th, though at 4.3 percent, even these are well below the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
The Netherlands ranks 14th in the environment component, a drop of four places, mainly reflecting an increase in its support for fossil fuels. It dropped from 7th to 30th on this measure, with significant levels of support given in 2022 in response to energy price spikes; its subsidy rate is now almost double the CDI median of 0.53 percent of GNI.

The Netherlands ranks 23rd for its greenhouse gas emissions. Direct emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry fell by over a tonne per head since the last CDI to 8.2 tonnes of CO2 equivalent, and are now below the CDI average of 9.1, though its emissions from land use remain above average.

The Netherlands is one of just six countries to tax harmful activities in its fishing industry, compared with the average CDI country which subsidises those activities by around 10 percent of the value of the fish the sector catches in total. Its carbon pricing schemes add $15.92 on average to the cost of emitting a tonne of CO2, compared to the CDI average of $15.23.

The Netherlands ranks within the top 10 on its participation in biodiversity and environmental agreements, having ratified or provided implementation reports for all treaties and conventions assessed in the CDI.
components.health:
The Netherlands ranks 11th in the health component. It ranks joint first for its regulation of tobacco supply chains, and in the top half of countries for antimicrobial resistance (AMR): antibiotic consumption is very low in humans (9.6 defined daily doses per 1,000 people per day against a CDI average of 19.2), although it could improve its governance with an up-to-date National Action Plan. The Netherlands has recently completed a Joint External Evaluation (JEE) with the World Health Organization which has improved its pandemic preparedness.

The Netherlands has increased the number of export restrictions on food and health products in the past two years and now ranks in the bottom half of countries on this measure. The same is true for vaccination coverage rates, where it has fallen below the average. On its participation in health treaties, codes, and memberships, the Netherlands could improve by becoming a member of the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System for antimicrobial consumption (GLASS-AMC), and by fully implementing the International Code on Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes.
components.security:
The Netherlands ranks 7th in the security component, an improvement of five ranks since the 2023 CDI. It ranks joint 1st on international security conventions, having fully ratified all treaties assessed in the CDI, and ranks 2nd on sea lanes protection, contributing vessels worth an equivalent of 0.09 percent of GNI (the CDI average is 0.02 percent). It ranks mid-table for its arms trade: its arms exports are worth an equivalent of 0.14 percent of GNI—slightly lower than the median CDI country—but these tend to go to countries which are more conflict-prone (poorer, more militaristic, and less democratic) than average.

It ranks mid-table for its peacekeeping contributions, equivalent to 0.014 percent of GNI (just below the CDI average), and 14 percent of the peacekeeping troops it sends on UN missions are female, slightly higher than the CDI average.
components.technology:
The Netherlands ranks 24th in the technology component, down from 16th in the 2023 edition of the CDI. It has strong policies for knowledge production, ranking 11th for the amount of direct government support for research and development (R&D) it gives, worth 0.66 percent of GNI, and in the top 10 for the tax incentives it provides for private R&D (worth a further 0.31 percent of GNI).

The Netherlands has a mixed performance on its policies to encourage knowledge diffusion. It accepts fewer foreign students from lower-income countries than the median CDI country—though of these, a high proportion (55 percent) are female. However, it ranks 36th for its research collaboration, suggesting it should include more researchers from poorer countries in its international research teams. Furthermore, along with other EU member states, the Netherlands’ free trade agreements contain provisions that are more restrictive on intellectual property rights than standard World Trade Organization membership stipulates, and thus impede the flow of innovation and knowledge internationally.

NOR.overall:
Norway ranks 3rd in the Commitment to Development Index. It ranks 1st for investment and places in the top three on development finance and health. It has significant room for improvement on trade, where it comes 31st primarily due to its high agricultural subsidies and tariff rates against poorer countries, and on environment, where it comes 17th, with high fossil fuel production.

When we assess Norway relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank falls by 25 places to 28th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Norway ranks 3rd on development finance, performing very well for quantity and ranking mid-table on quality aspects. It ranks 2nd on the quantity of its development finance, giving 0.9 percent of its GNI in cross-border Finance for International Development, significantly above the CDI country average of 0.28 percent. It also exceeded the 0.7 percent of GNI target for official development assistance (ODA) in 2024, providing 1.02 percent of GNI as ODA.

Norway ranks 17th for the quality of its bilateral development finance, a drop of 10 ranks since the 2023 CDI. Its development finance is untied, transparently reported, and has a strong focus on poorer countries. However, recipients report that projects were slightly less aligned with their own development priorities than is average for CDI countries, and a relatively small proportion of finance—23 percent—is channelled through multilateral institutions.
components.investment:
Norway ranks 1st in the investment component. It performs particularly well on investment standards for natural resources, and also does well on business and human rights standards and the degree to which its bilateral investment agreements leave partners with enough policy space to pursue their own objectives. It has been assessed by Transparency International as having “moderate” enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, which is better than most CDI countries, but it could improve by being more transparent about how the fines and confiscation penalties are calculated in foreign bribery cases, among other things.

Norway does fairly well on financial transparency, where it ranks 12th. In particular, Norway requires country-by-country reporting from companies operating within its territory and publishes a wide range of public statistics. However, there is still room for improvement, and Norway could make gains by implementing more stringent beneficial ownership regulations.
components.migration:
Norway ranks 6th on migration.

Norway comes mid-table on non-refugee migrant inflow. It accepts a relatively high number of migrants per head, though these migrants generally come from richer countries compared with the CDI average. It has also recently increased the share of women in its inward migration, rising to 53 percent from 47 percent in the previous CDI.

Norway comes 11th on refugee hosting, with over 19 refugees per 1,000 people—nearly 50 percent more than the CDI average. Still, Norway’s relative ranking on this indicator has slipped as other CDI countries did more to host refugees from Ukraine.

Norway is also strong on its migrant integration policies and has signed International Labour Organization conventions on migrant workers, though it has yet to complete a voluntary assessment of its implementation of the Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
Norway ranks 31st on trade, falling to last place when its score is income adjusted. This makes trade Norway’s weakest-performing component in the CDI.
