Norway’s tariff rates, weighed inversely by trading partner income level, are relatively high, and it also imposes a significant number of tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more) against poorer countries. Norway’s services trade is also more restrictive than average across the CDI, ranking 27th, as assessed by the OECD Services Trade Restrictiveness Index. This is especially the case in the air transport sector.

Norway has the highest agricultural subsidies of any CDI country assessed by some margin and these have increased since the last edition: it provided 56.5 percent of farm gate production value in agricultural subsidies, up from gives 45.8 percent in CDI 2023 and more than four times the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
Norway ranks 17th in the environment component, with relatively low greenhouse gas emissions and impressive climate target ambition towards 2030, but high fossil fuel production and moderate fossil fuel subsidies.

Norway’s direct emissions (excluding land use and forestry) fell half a tonne to 8.6 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, slightly below the CDI average of 9.1 tonnes. Its sequestration from land use was significantly greater than the CDI average, and this was only partially offset by emissions embodied in its trade.

Based on its Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC), Norway plans to reduce emissions by 53 percent compared to what it is projected to emit in 2030 in a business-as-usual scenario; and ranks top on this indicator.

Norway ranks last on fossil fuel production, with particularly high oil and gas production. Norway’s fossil fuel production is equivalent to over 100 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita—more than 10 times its own emissions and higher than any other CDI country. Still, Norway’s domestic carbon pricing is relatively ambitious, imposing an average additional cost per tonne of CO2 of $45.99: the third highest of all CDI countries.

Norway scores well on fishing subsidies, as it does not provide any harmful subsidies to encourage global fish stock depletion and it has recently signed up to the World Trade Organization agreement on fish subsidies. It could, however, improve its participation on biodiversity and environmental agreements by signing up to and reporting on implementation of the UN Convention to Combat Desertification.
components.health:
Norway ranks 2nd on health. It ranks 6th on antimicrobial resistance (AMR): its human and livestock consumption of antibiotics are both significantly below the CDI averages, and it has approved a national action plan on AMR. It has also signed up to the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System for both antimicrobial resistance and consumption.

Norway has significantly reduced its export restrictions imposed on food and medical products in the last two years, with just eight product lines affected relative to 51 in the last CDI, moving it into the top 10 on this measure.

Norway’s vaccination coverage across the measles vaccine and the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine is within the top 10 of all CDI countries. Norway has a middling performance on pandemic preparedness and could improve its score by completing a Joint External Evaluation with the WHO.

Norway has signed both the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control and the related Protocol against Illicit Trade.
components.security:
Norway ranks 12th in the security component, though after income-adjusting its score falls by 11 ranks to 23rd.

Norway contributes roughly 0.016 percent of its GNI towards peacekeeping, slightly less than the CDI average, though it provides a further 0.033 percent towards sea lanes protection, which is above the average. Of its UN peacekeepers, 22 percent are female, compared to a CDI average of only 13 percent, placing Norway 8th on this measure.

Norway’s arms sales were worth 0.16 percent of its GNI, which is less than the median of all CDI countries, and the destinations of those arms exports were assessed as being less conflict-prone than the CDI average.

Norway has signed and ratified all nine international security conventions we consider.
components.technology:
Norway ranks 13th in the technology component, a drop of nine ranks from the 2023 CDI. It does reasonably well in subsidising knowledge production, allocating 0.70 percent of GNI directly to research and development (R&D)—more than the CDI average but still a drop from over 1 percent in the 2023 CDI. In addition, Norway encourages private R&D with a further 0.15 percent of GNI through implied tax subsidies—though this, too, is a decline.

Norway ranks mid-table for its policies on knowledge diffusion to poorer countries: foreign students make up 5 percent of the total tertiary student population, and these students tend to come from richer countries compared to most CDI countries. Norway also ranks mid-table on research collaboration; its researchers co-author papers with researchers from relatively poorer countries less often than other CDI countries.

NZL.overall:
New Zealand ranks 17th on the Commitment to Development Index. It performs particularly well in trade (5th) and also comes in the top half of countries on technology, investment, security, and migration. New Zealand has most room for improvement on development finance, where it ranks 27th.

When we assess New Zealand relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises by three to 14th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
New Zealand ranks 27th on development finance. It ranks 17th on development finance quantity, providing 0.27 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development. Unlike the trend in most CDI countries, this is an increase from the 2023 CDI; New Zealand now exceeds the CDI average of 0.28 percent.

However, New Zealand ranks in the bottom 10 countries on development finance quality. It scores well on transparency, and its development projects are mostly open to bids from companies of other nationalities, but its finance allocations should focus more on poorer and more fragile states. Also, it disburses a below-average share of its finance through multilateral organizations (12 percent compared to a CDI average of 47 percent), and there is scope for New Zealand to improve the degree to which its development projects align with recipients’ development priorities.
components.investment:
New Zealand ranks 14th on investment. It ranks joint top on its corporate tax rate alignment, as its corporate tax rates exceed both the globally agreed 15 percent minimum and the developing country average of 25 percent, thereby limiting the potential for base erosion and profit shifting from other jurisdictions. It also ranks in the top three on its bilateral investment agreements, as these leave significant policy space for developing country counterparts to pursue their development objectives.

However, its commitment to investment for development is inhibited by its weak performance on the financial secrecy indicators, where it ranks in the bottom 10. It is also rated by Transparency International as having only “limited” enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and though it has recently participated in peer reviews relating to the OECD multinational enterprise guidelines, it has room to improve. New Zealand should adopt a National Action Plan on business and human rights, fully enforce the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and take steps to reduce financial secrecy—especially as regards beneficial ownership regulations.
components.migration:
New Zealand ranks 15th on migration. Its contribution to hosting refugees has fallen relative to others and is now in the bottom half of countries, with just 0.4 refugees per 1,000 people, compared to a CDI average of 11.

Still, New Zealand ranks 11th on migrant inflows (when weighted inversely by the income of their origin countries), and 49 percent of these migrants are female (above the CDI average of 48 percent). It also has strong domestic migrant integration policies, ranking within the top five on this indicator. However, it scores poorly for its participation in international migration agreements: it has not ratified the International Labour Organization’s Migrant Workers Convention, has excluded provisions in its ratification of the Migration for Employment Convention, and has not yet submitted a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration.
components.trade:
New Zealand ranks 5th on trade, making this its strongest component. It ranks 1st on average tariff rates against lower-income countries and joint 1st for avoiding tariff peaks, as it has no tariff lines with rates above 15 percent. It also ranks 1st for having few agricultural subsidies (which are 0.2 percent of production value, compared to a CDI average of 12.6 percent). Since the 2021 edition of the CDI, New Zealand has also somewhat reduced the restrictiveness of its trade in services and comes 14th on this indicator. However, New Zealand’s performance on trade logistics puts it in the bottom half of countries as assessed by the World Bank—the quality of its trade infrastructure is marginally above average, but its performance on its customs regime continues to lag others.

Environment
New Zealand ranks 25th on the environment component. It ranks 1st on limiting harmful fishing subsidies, actually taxing harmful elements of this sector rather than subsidising activities which could encourage global stock depletion. It also performs well on limiting financial support to the domestic consumption and production of fossil fuels, ranking 5th on this indicator.

New Zealand should improve its climate-related policies by reducing both its production of fossil fuels—especially gas and coal—and its greenhouse gas emissions. Since the 2023 CDI, its direct greenhouse gas emissions from energy, waste, agriculture, and industry fell almost a tonne to 14.6 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, but this remains far above the CDI average of 9.1 tonnes per capita. Still, New Zealand scores well on our measure of climate target ambition, with its Nationally Determined Contribution ranked in the top 10 most ambitious of all CDI countries, aiming for emissions levels at least 40 percent below business-as-usual projections for 2030.

New Zealand received much less credit for its carbon pricing in this edition of the CDI as government revenue from emissions trading fell substantially in the latest data, suggesting the additional cost it imposes per average tonne of CO2 emitted fell from over $16.17 in the previous edition to just $0.29.
components.environment: placeholder
components.health:
New Zealand ranks 21st in the health component, an improvement of six places on the previous CDI. It ranks joint first on export restrictions on food and health products, having not imposed any such restrictions in the last two years. It also performs well on pandemic preparedness, having completed a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization (WHO), and updated its National Influenza Plan in the last decade.

New Zealand has reported reduced human consumption of antibiotics and so moved into the top half of countries avoiding antimicrobial resistance. Still, New Zealand ranks in the bottom 10 countries for its low vaccination coverage: its coverage for both the measles and the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccines remains below CDI averages. New Zealand should also improve its regulation of international tobacco supply chains by signing onto the Framework Convention for Tobacco Control, and it should improve its participation in international health agreements and memberships by signing onto the Minamata Convention and participating in the WHO’s Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System.
components.security:
New Zealand ranks 13th on security. It ranks joint 1st on treaties as it has fully ratified all nine security conventions assessed by the CDI. It also ranks top for its arms exports: these are worth an equivalent of just 0.002 percent of its GNI, the lowest of all CDI countries for which we have data, and the proportion of these exports that are directed towards poor, militaristic, and undemocratic countries (those with greater conflict risks) is also the lowest of CDI countries.

New Zealand’s contributions to global peacekeeping are middling—it provides troops and financial contributions worth roughly 0.016 percent of its GNI, which is slightly below the CDI country average of 0.019 percent of GNI. However, women are well represented in its UN peacekeeping forces, accounting for 24 percent (almost double the CDI average). It does not provide any vessels to international sea lanes protection.
components.technology:
New Zealand ranks 10th on technology. It provides relatively little support for new knowledge creation: the government spends just 0.48 percent of GNI directly on research and development (R&D), below the CDI average of 0.55 percent. Still, New Zealand has increased the tax subsidies it provides to business R&D, and these are now equivalent to a further 0.14 percent of its GNI—though still lower than the CDI average.

New Zealand’s high rank on the technology component is buoyed by its relatively stronger policies on technology diffusion: it ranks in the top 10 on the number of foreign students it hosts (when weighted inversely by their origin country incomes), and in the top half on including researchers from poorer countries in its international research teams. Its free trade agreements also tend to contain much fewer restrictive intellectual property rights provisions than is true for most CDI countries, further promoting technology transfers and putting New Zealand 2nd on this indicator.

POL.overall:
Poland ranks 27th on the Commitment to Development Index. It comes in the top half of countries for its performance on migration, but it has significant room for improvement on the health, development finance, and technology components, where it comes in the bottom 10 countries.

When we assess Poland relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises by six places to 21st. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Poland ranks 30th on the development finance component, rising by six ranks to 24th when income adjusted.

Although the most recent estimates of Poland’s cross-border Finance for International Development have slightly increased since the last edition of the CDI—at a time when most countries have reduced their finance commitments—its development finance is still worth just 0.18 percent of GNI—well below the CDI average of 0.28 percent, placing Poland 24th on the quantity indicator.

Poland performs slightly worse on the quality of its development finance, coming in at 29th. Polish development finance is transparently reported, and Poland gives 72 percent of its development finance through multilaterals. However, recipients report that projects do not align with their countries’ priorities as much as the average across CDI countries, and Poland’s bilateral development finance has a much lower focus on relatively poorer and more fragile countries than most CDI countries.
components.investment:
Poland ranks 20th in the Investment component. It comes in the top half of countries for limiting financial secrecy but has further scope for improvement, especially on its anti-money laundering practices.

Poland scores well for its commitment to business and human rights standards, having responded to the UN High Commissioner’s Survey on Business and Human Rights, adhering to the OECD Guidelines on Multinational Enterprises, and having a dedicated National Action Plan on the topic. Still, Poland’s enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention has been assessed as limited to none by Transparency International. Poland also does not implement or support the Extractives Industry Transparency Initiative.
components.migration:
Poland ranks 19th in the migration component. This represents a significant improvement over its rank of 34th in the 2021 CDI, with this rise largely resulting from the significant number of Ukrainian refugees it has accepted since Russia’s invasion. Poland comes 5th out of CDI countries on refugee hosting relative to its own population, with 26.7 refugees per 1,000 people in 2024, a significant increase over the 0.1 refugees per 1,000 people it hosted in 2021; many of these new refugees are from Ukraine.

However, Poland’s performance on migration is held back by its poor migrant integration and protection policies. Poland has not completed a voluntary review of the UN Global Compact for Migration, nor has it signed two of the relevant International Labour Organization conventions on migrant worker protections.

Poland also ranks 22nd on non-refugee migrant inflows from poorer countries. Of the migrants it accepts, only 37 percent are female, placing it 35th on the gender balance of immigrants.
components.trade:
Poland ranks 25th in the trade component, rising to 16th when income adjusted.

Along with other EU members, it ranks joint 4th and joint 7th on the tariffs and tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more) indicators, respectively, with EU tariffs being generally low and having several exemptions for poorer countries. However, Poland is more restrictive than most countries on its services trade, ranking 32nd on this indicator.

Poland also ranks in the bottom half of countries on trade logistics, with weaknesses particularly in its trade infrastructure. It also ranks near the bottom of the table for its trade-distorting agricultural subsidies. The value of its agricultural subsidies, agreed at the EU level, has fallen substantially to 18.9 percent of farm-gate production value (30.7 percent in the 2021 CDI assessment), but remains well over the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
Poland ranks 21st in the environment component. It ranks joint 6th on its participation in international biodiversity and environmental agreements, having ratified all nine treaties assessed by the CDI and provided up-to-date implementation reports in all but one.

Poland’s direct emissions (from energy, industry, waste, and agriculture) were 9.5 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, marginally above the CDI average of 9.1. However, Poland’s greenhouse gas footprint is reduced through its international trade and sequestration of emissions through its land use and forestry, meaning it ranks mid-table on overall emissions per head.

Poland ranks in the bottom half on fossil fuel production. This is especially true for Poland’s coal production: despite committing to a coal phase-out by 2049, progress has been slow, and although there was a drop in recent years, it remains high at almost double the CDI average. Poland’s fossil fuel subsidies were also higher than the CDI average, with the highest level of support given, again, to highly polluting coal.

Poland also ranks joint-last on its harmful fishing subsidies, which contribute to global stock depletion and overfishing.
components.health:
Poland ranks 35th in the health component, its weakest performance.

Poland has significant room for improvement on its antimicrobial resistance stewardship, with antibiotic consumption higher than the CDI average both for its human population and its livestock. Poland is one of just two CDI countries which have not started drafting a national action plan on antimicrobial resistance.

Poland also scores poorly—ranking joint last—on measures to improve pandemic preparedness and response. It has not completed a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization, updated its National Influenza Plan, or completed a Performance of Veterinary Services evaluation with the World Organisation for Animal Health in the last decade.

Poland has ratified the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control but should do more to regulate tobacco supply chains by monitoring and reporting on illicit trade under the convention. On other health-related treaties assessed by the CDI, Poland does well, although it could do more to fully implement the International Code on Marketing of Breast Milk Substitutes.
components.security:
Poland ranks 23rd in the security component. After its score is adjusted for its income, this rises by seven ranks to 16th.

Poland's financial and troop contributions to peacekeeping are worth 0.02 percent of its GNI, slightly more than the CDI average. Of the UN peacekeepers it deploys, only 9 percent are female, a decline over previous assessments and below the CDI average of 13 percent. Poland did not contribute any vessels to protect sea lanes.

Poland’s arms exports are in line with the CDI median (0.18 percent of its GNI), and the countries Poland exports these arms to are assessed as slightly less conflict-prone than the CDI average. Poland has signed and ratified most international security treaties we assess, but it should adopt the Convention on Cluster Munitions.
components.technology:
Poland ranks 29th in the technology component, marking continued progress on this component compared to the previous CDI editions.

Poland’s government spends roughly 0.50 percent of its GNI on direct support for research and development (R&D). It has increased the tax incentives for private R&D to 0.30 percent of GNI, up from 0.16 percent two years prior and now ranking in the top 10 for the indicator.

Poland also ranks around mid-table on accepting foreign students from poorer countries, and on collaborations resulting in publications with researchers from poorer countries. Like other EU countries, Poland’s free trade agreements with developing countries include intellectual property rights clauses more restrictive than agreed under World Trade Organization standards.

PRT.overall:
Portugal ranks 12th on the Commitment to Development Index. Its best performances are in the environment, migration, and technology components, where it ranks in the top 10. Portugal has most room for improvement on investment, where it comes in the bottom half of countries due to declining anticorruption policies and deteriorating financial secrecy.

When we assess Portugal relative to expectations based on its income level, it rises 10 places to 2nd. Full income-adjusted results are available at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Portugal ranks 15th on development finance. Portugal provides just 0.22 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development, which is lower than the CDI average of 0.28 percent but represents an increase since the 2023 CDI.

The quality of Portugal’s development finance is in the top half of countries, ranking 11th. Portugal contributes 77 percent of its aid through multilateral agencies (above the CDI average of 47 percent) and has a stronger-than-average focus on poorer and more fragile recipients in its finance allocation. Its finance is transparently reported and generally untied. It also does well to align its development projects with its partners’ priorities.
components.investment:
Portugal ranks 22nd on the investment component. Its performance is mixed across the component, ranking mid-table at 21st when it comes to limiting financial secrecy, lagging behind on banking secrecy, public statistics, and how readily beneficial owners can be identified. It is also weak on its anticorruption efforts, with its enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention assessed as “limited” by Transparency International.

Still, Portugal comes joint 1st on our measure of corporate tax rate alignment, with a corporate income tax rate above the globally agreed 15 percent minimum, and also above the developing country average of 25 percent.

Portugal is mid-table for its natural resource governance, as well as for business and human rights. It ranks 36th for the development-friendliness of its international investment agreements, which leave little policy space for counterparts to pursue their development objectives, ranking in the bottom five countries.
components.migration:
Portugal ranks 10th on the migration component, accepting a relatively high number of non-refugee migrants (weighted inversely by the income of their country of origin), and having excellent domestic migrant integration policies in areas like education, health, and employment. It also ranks 1st for its participation in international migration conventions, the only country to have ratified both International Labour Organization conventions on migrant workers assessed in the CDI and to have submitted a voluntary review under the UN Global Compact for Migration.

Portugal comes 21st on refugee hosting, with 6.2 refugees per 1,000 people. This represents a substantive increase over the 0.2 refugees hosted per 1,000 people in the 2021 CDI, with refugees from Ukraine making up almost 90 percent of the total. Portugal ranks in the bottom half of countries for its share of female immigrants, which stands at 45 percent.
components.trade:
Portugal ranks 16th on the trade component, though after income-adjusting its score, this rises by seven ranks to 9th. Along with other EU members, its tariff rates (when weighted inversely to trading partner income) are low, and it has fewer tariff peaks than average (the number of tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or more). It is also among the top five CDI countries on avoiding restrictions on trade in services across 22 sectors.

Portugal has most room for improvement on agricultural subsidies and its trade logistics system. It provides subsidies worth 17.3 percent of agricultural production, agreed at the EU level, which are above the CDI average of 12.6 percent. Its trade logistics also rank in the bottom half, with the efficiency of its customs regime and border management clearance assessed by logistics professionals as below the CDI average.
components.environment:
Portugal ranks 2nd on environment, making this its strongest component. It ranks joint 6th for its participation in international biodiversity and environmental agreements, where it could update its implementation reporting to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. It also provides as many harmful fishing subsidies which encourage global stock depletion as the median CDI country.

Portugal’s greenhouse gas emissions per person are seventh lowest in the CDI, with its direct emissions (those from domestic energy, industry, waste, and agriculture) amounting to just 5.1 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, as compared to the CDI average of 9.1. Its emissions from land use and forestry as well as its indirect emissions (those embodied in international trade) are also relatively small.

Although Portugal’s per person levels of fossil fuel production are among the lowest of CDI countries, it has below-average performance in terms of the financial support it provides to the domestic consumption and production of fossil fuels, especially for oil. On the other hand, Portugal has a fairly ambitious carbon price, imposing an additional cost of $23.48 per average tonne of CO2 emitted, which is over the CDI average of $15.23 per tonne.
components.health:
Portugal ranks 22nd in the health component. It ranks within the top five countries for its commitment to regulation of international tobacco supply chains, and ranks second of all countries for its domestic vaccination coverage.

Portugal has significant room for improvement on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) stewardship, where it ranks among the bottom 10 countries. Portugal’s AMR governance requires strengthening, and its human consumption of antibiotics is above average.

Portugal has not yet completed a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization, and its national influenza plan has not been updated for more than a decade—these actions would help improve its pandemic preparedness, where it ranks joint last. It also ranks mid-table for the number and duration of export restrictions it has placed on food and medical goods over the past two years.
components.security:
Portugal ranks 11th on security. It is one of a number of countries to have ratified all nine major security conventions the CDI assesses, ranking joint 1st as a result. It also scores well for its peacekeeping contributions (worth 0.02 percent of its GNI) and support for naval vessels protecting international sea lanes (worth another 0.05 percent of its GNI). However, of the UN peacekeeping troops it deploys, a relatively low share—just 8 percent—are female, compared to a CDI average of 13 percent.

Portugal ranks in the top half of countries regarding its arms trade. It exports a higher volume of arms (equivalent to 0.2 percent of GNI) than the median across CDI countries, but these generally go to destinations with significantly below-average risks of conflict.
components.technology:
Portugal ranks 8th on technology. Its government spends slightly more than average directly on research and development (R&D), worth 0.57 percent of Portugal’s GNI. It also has relatively generous tax incentives for business R&D, worth an additional 0.38 percent of GNI, the fifth highest in the CDI.

In terms of policies to encourage technology transfer and diffusion, Portugal ranks in the top five countries for welcoming a large number of foreign students, which make up over 10 percent of its tertiary student population. These students are also among the most likely to come from poorer countries. It also gives greater representation to poorer country researchers in its international research collaboration than most CDI countries. However, Portugal, like other EU member states, should make the intellectual property rights clauses in its bilateral trade and investment agreements with developing countries less restrictive by not going beyond existing World Trade Organization standards.

SAU.overall:
Saudi Arabia ranks 33rd in the Commitment to Development Index. It performs best in health (3rd) and development finance (8th). It has most room for improvement in the investment component (38th), as well as on environment (37th), migration (37th), and security (38th).

When we assess Saudi Arabia relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank falls four places to 37th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Saudi Arabia ranks 8th in the development finance component, jumping to 2nd when assessing its performance relative to its income.

It ranks 6th on development finance quantity, giving 0.47 percent of its GNI in Finance for International Development, compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent. It also ranks in the top 10 for the quality of its development finance. Its finance is transparent and mostly open to bids from companies of other nationalities, and though its allocation is not particularly well-focused on poorer countries, it has the second-strongest focus on fragile states. That said, it provides relatively little support to multilateral organisations (7 percent compared to the CDI average of 47 percent).
components.investment:
Saudi Arabia ranks last in the investment component, its worst rank.

Saudi Arabia ranks last or joint last on four of the six indicators in the component: for business and human rights, natural resource governance, anticorruption, and investment agreements. It should engage with the OECD’s responsible business conduct principles; participate in the Kimberly Process, and support and implement the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative standard; enforce the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention; and include fewer provisions in its bilateral investment agreements, which limit the policy space of its counterparts to pursue their development objectives.

Saudi Arabia’s best performances in the investment component are on the new corporate tax rate alignment indicator, with a corporate income tax rate of 20 percent (higher than the globally agreed effective minimum of 15 percent), and on financial secrecy—though it still ranks low at 30th for this. It should require its multinational enterprises to submit country-by-country reports and make more datasets publicly available to improve.
components.migration:
Saudi Arabia ranks 37th in the migration component.

It ranks in the top 10 on migrant inflows, accepting a relatively large number of migrants (weighted inversely by the income of their origin countries) relative to its population. However, of these migrants, only 22 percent are female compared to a CDI average of 48 percent. Furthermore, its migrant integration policies are assessed as being the worst of all CDI countries. It accepts very few refugees (second least in the CDI in both absolute numbers and on a per head basis) and has not ratified the International Labour Organization’s Migrant Workers Convention, nor its Migration for Employment Convention.
components.trade:
Saudi Arabia ranks 27th in the trade component.

It ranks 5th on tariff peaks, with few product lines having rates of 15 percent or higher. However, its average tariff rate (weighted inversely by trading partner income level) is relatively high—ninth highest across the CDI. Saudi Arabia ranks in the bottom half of countries on trade logistics, with comparatively poor customs procedures and only slightly better trade infrastructure. To improve on this component, Saudi Arabia could lower its tariffs against poorer countries and improve its customs and trade infrastructure, as well as publish data on its agricultural subsidies.
components.environment:
Saudi Arabia ranks 37th in the environment component and is in the bottom 10 on all indicators.

Its domestic greenhouse gas emissions are high at 22.1 tonnes of CO₂ equivalent per capita against a CDI average of 9.1 tonnes. A large amount of CO2 is embodied in its fossil fuel production relative to the size of its population, with particularly high production of oil. It does not publish data on the level of subsidy it provides for the production and consumption of these fossil fuels. Saudi Arabia’s climate target—its Nationally Determined Contribution—is relatively unambitious, suggesting that by 2030 it plans to reduce its emissions by 29 percent against business-as-usual projections.

Saudi Arabia has no carbon pricing scheme in place, and it does not participate in many of the biodiversity or environmental agreements assessed in the CDI: it should ratify the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands and become a member of the International Tropical Timber Organization. Since the 2023 CDI, it has accepted the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fisheries Subsidies but it should publish data on any subsidies it provides to the fishing industry.
components.health:
Saudi Arabia ranks 3rd in the health component, rising 13 places since the 2023 CDI thanks to a number of improvements.

Saudi Arabia ranks joint 4th for its vaccination coverage: immunization coverage by the nationally recommended age is 96 percent for measles (against a CDI median of 92 percent) and 97 percent among 1-year-olds for diphtheria, tetanus toxoid, and pertussis (against a CDI median of 95 percent). It also ranks joint 5th for its regulation of tobacco supply chains, with much-improved monitoring and reporting of illicit trade since the 2023 CDI.

Saudi Arabia ranks in the top half of countries on antimicrobial resistance (AMR): it has strong AMR governance, and antibiotic consumption among its human population has fallen slightly, though it remains above the CDI average. Since the last CDI, it has become a member of the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System module on antimicrobial consumption (GLASS-AMC) and it now participates in all seven health treaties we assess. It has also improved its pandemic preparedness through undertaking a biological simulation exercise in the last two years.

Saudi Arabia still has room for improvement on the number of restrictions it imposes on the export of food and health products. It has reduced these in the last two years, although it still ranks in the bottom half of countries on this indicator.
components.security:
Saudi Arabia ranks 38th in the security component.

Whilst Saudi Arabia ranks 15th on its allocation of naval resources to protect sea lanes (worth around 0.012 percent of its GNI, compared to a CDI average of 0.019 percent), it ranks in the bottom 10 for all other indicators.

On peacekeeping contributions, its financial contributions to the UN Department of Peace Operations are lower than most CDI countries, and, as it contributes no personnel to UN or non-UN missions, its overall contributions are in the bottom 10 (equivalent to 0.007 percent of GNI, versus the CDI average of 0.019 percent). Saudi Arabia does not publish data on its arms exports, which harms its score. It also ranks 37th on security conventions, having ratified few of the conventions for which the CDI gives credit.

Saudi Arabia could improve on this component by contributing peacekeeping troops to UN missions (and ensuring women are well represented among them), ratifying all major security conventions, and publishing data on its arms exports.
components.technology:
Saudi Arabia ranks 17th in the technology component, a fall of 9 ranks since the 2023 edition of the CDI.

Saudi Arabia generally has good policies to diffuse and share technology. Out of all CDI countries, Saudi Arabia’s international research collaborations are most likely to be with researchers from poor countries, so it ranks 1st on this indicator. It also ranks in the top 10 for the number of foreign students from lower-income countries it welcomes to its universities, though women are very poorly represented among them. Its bilateral free trade agreements are also ranked mid-table in not containing more restrictive intellectual property rights provisions than already exist under World Trade Organization standards.

However, Saudi Arabia could improve its policies to encourage technology creation. Its government could spend more directly on research and development (R&D), as here Saudi Arabia ranks in the bottom five, with an allocation of 0.22 percent of GNI versus a CDI average of 0.55 percent. It is also missing data on its tax incentives for business R&D. Additionally, Saudi Arabia should ensure women are better represented in its international student population, as they currently account for just 37 percent (the CDI average is 49 percent).

SVK.overall:
The Slovak Republic ranks 22nd in the Commitment to Development Index. It performs well on the security and environment components, ranking 2nd and 4th respectively, with generous peacekeeping contributions, few arms exports, and relatively high levels of carbon pricing.

The Slovak Republic has also played a significant role in hosting refugees from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, although its wider indicators suggest it could improve its policies on migrant integration.

When we assess the Slovak Republic relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises 11 places to 11th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
The Slovak Republic ranks 22nd in development finance. It should increase the quantity it provides in Finance for International Development: it only contributes 0.13 percent of its GNI in the most recent estimates, less than half the CDI average of 0.28 percent.

The Slovak Republic performs well on the quality of its development finance, with a high proportion of finance supporting multilaterals and reporting transparently, though its international finance is somewhat tied to securing goods and services from domestic companies. There is also scope for increasing the share of its bilateral finance directed to poorer and more fragile countries, where it performs very poorly compared to most of its CDI peers.
components.investment:
The Slovak Republic ranks 25th on the investment component. It does well in affording its developing country counterparts a high degree of policy space to pursue development objectives in international investment agreements. Its corporate tax rate is above the globally agreed minimum (of 15 percent) but below the average in developing countries (of 25 percent).

The Slovak Republic should support the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative and fully enforce the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention (its enforcement is judged to be little to none by Transparency International). It should also implement a national action plan on business and human rights as recommended by the UN.
components.migration:
The Slovak Republic ranks 28th on the migration component.

The Slovak Republic hosts a substantial number of refugees from Ukraine, which contributes to a figure of almost 23 refugees per 1,000 population and around 100 times more than in previous years. It ranks 6th on this indicator.

More generally however, the Slovak Republic could do much more to support migration. It reported very low levels of migration from other countries at 0.3 migrants per 1,000 of its population and very few migrants were from lower-income countries—it ranked 35th out of 40 on this indicator. In addition, a below-average share of migrants were female (42 percent). Its policies on integrating migrants into its society and economy also have substantial room for improvement. The Slovak Republic does not protect the rights of migrant workers by ratifying or implementing either of the relevant International Labour Organization conventions.
components.trade:
The Slovak Republic ranks 23rd on the trade component, with this rank rising 11 places to 12th after adjusting for its income level.

Alongside other EU countries, the Slovak Republic’s average tariff rate (weighted inversely by trading partner income level) is amongst the lowest compared to the CDI average. The EU has several agreements and tariff exemptions for lower-income countries, which has a large effect on these indicators given the higher weight assigned to poorer countries.

The Slovak Republic is below average on the ease of its trade logistics, adding to costs for its exporters and importers alike. It should be willing to accept lower EU agricultural subsidies at the forthcoming negotiations of the EU budget: subsidies provide unfair competition to lower-income countries and in the Slovak Republic are worth 20.6 percent of farm gate production, compared to the CDI average of 12.6 percent.
components.environment:
The Slovak Republic ranks 4th in the environment component. Its emissions per head are lower than most CDI countries. As part of the EU’s emissions reduction plans, it expects to reduce emissions by 34 percent relative to business as usual in 2030, putting it in the top half of countries in terms of ambition.

The Slovak Republic has signed and ratified all biodiversity and environmental agreements for which the CDI gives credit. It has relatively ambitious carbon pricing, as it imposes an additional cost per tonne of CO2 emitted of $20.98, which is above the CDI average of $15.23.

The Slovak Republic performs well on the fossil fuel production indicator, producing significantly fewer carbon-intensive fuels than most CDI countries. Still, it should also reduce its subsidies to fossil fuel production and consumption, and particularly to coal, where it ranks in the bottom 10 countries.
components.health:
The Slovak Republic ranks 18th in the health component. It ranks in the top 10 on vaccination coverage, with 95 percent coverage for measles, and 96 percent coverage for diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. Antibiotic consumption is below the CDI average in animals, but the Slovak Republic has higher-than-average human antibiotic consumption, contributing to the risk of drug-resistant disease.

The Slovak Republic placed relatively few export restrictions on food and health goods that impact developing countries in the last two years, and it effectively regulates international tobacco supply chains. It should fully participate in international health treaties, codes, and memberships; it ranks in the bottom five countries for this indicator.
components.security:
The Slovak Republic ranks 2nd in the security component. It ranks second on peacekeeping contributions, providing an equivalent of 0.05 percent of GNI—almost three times the CDI average—primarily through troop and personnel contributions to UN missions. Of the peacekeepers it provides, around 12 percent are female, which is slightly lower than the CDI average.

The Slovak Republic also reported low arms exports, worth only 0.13 percent of GNI compared to the CDI median of 0.18 percent. These exports were also generally to less conflict-prone or fragile states.
components.technology:
The Slovak Republic ranks 36th in the technology component. The Slovak government could be much more generous in its support for research and development (R&D) as it only contributes 0.33 percent of its GNI, compared to the CDI average of 0.55 percent. The implicit subsidies it provides for private R&D through tax incentives are worth a further 0.13 percent of GNI—also less than most other CDI countries.

The Slovak Republic should be less restrictive (along with other EU countries) in limiting the spread of knowledge and technology transfers through its strict intellectual property rights terms in its free trade agreements with lower-income countries.

The Slovak Republic is in the top half of the table for the number of foreign students from lower-income countries in its tertiary education population, ranking 14th, but since 2023 the proportion of those that are female has dropped from 54 percent to 48 percent, now lower than the CDI average.

SWE.overall:
Sweden comes 1st in the 2025 Commitment to Development Index. While Sweden also topped the 2023 and 2021 editions of the CDI, its lead over the next-best performing country has narrowed each edition. In addition to leading the overall ranking, Sweden is also the top performer on the environment component, and ranks in the top five on development finance, migration and health. Despite its reputation for innovation, it has the most room for improvement in its policies for producing and sharing new technologies, ranking mid-table on the technology component.

When we assess Sweden relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank falls by two places to 3rd. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
Sweden ranks 2nd in the development finance component. In our latest assessment, it provided 0.72 percent of its GNI in cross-border Finance for International Development—more than double the CDI average of 0.28 percent. Still, this figure represents a continued reduction in development finance volumes since 2021. Sweden surpasses the 0.7 percent of GNI UN-approved target for official development assistance (ODA), having provided 0.79 percent of GNI in 2024. The current government, which took office in late 2022, announced a move away from the previous government’s target of spending 1 percent of GNI in ODA.

The finance Sweden provides is of a high quality, ranking 2nd. Sweden performs better than the CDI average in terms of transparent reporting, untied procurement, and focus on poorer and more fragile countries. Sweden has most room for improvement in increasing contributions through multilateral organisations, currently 36 percent, and by aligning a greater share of its development projects with recipient country priorities.
components.investment:
Sweden ranks 6th in the investment component. It ranks joint 1st for business and human rights, fully engaging with the OECD responsible business conduct principles, and also tops the ranks for limiting financial secrecy. It performs well on natural resource governance, ranking in the top five for the indicator. However, Sweden’s performance on anticorruption is middling, with Transparency International now assessing Sweden’s enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention as “limited”.

Within the investment component, Sweden performs worst for the development-friendliness of its international investment agreements, ranking in the bottom 10 countries. It should improve by leaving more policy space for poorer countries to pursue development objectives within its bilateral investment agreements.
components.migration:
Sweden ranks 5th on the migration component, down from first in the last edition of the CDI.

Sweden is now below average in the number of non-refugee migrants it receives per head of population, and it ranks 18th after this is weighted by migrants’ origin countries’ incomes (to reward CDI countries that accept more migrants from poorer countries). Sweden could welcome greater numbers of female migrants: 47 percent of Sweden’s immigrants are female, placing it in the bottom half of CDI countries. Sweden ranks 9th in the number of refugees it hosts relative to its population (21 per 1,000 people, compared to a CDI average of 11).

In the most recent assessment available, Sweden demonstrates stronger policy efforts to integrate migrants into its economy and society than other CDI countries, though this does not reflect the most recent changes in Sweden’s migration policy, such as raising the minimum salary requirement to be eligible for a work permit. Sweden ranks in the top five countries for its ratification of international conventions aiming to protect migrants, but it should further demonstrate its commitment to migrants’ rights by ratifying the International Labour Organization’s Migration for Employment Convention.
components.trade:
Sweden ranks 9th in the trade component, though after income-adjusting its score, this falls by six ranks to 15th. As an EU member, its average external tariffs towards poorer countries are low, with few tariff peaks (tariff lines with rates of 15 percent or higher). Sweden also has very efficient customs procedures and good trade infrastructure, facilitating streamlined and lower-cost trade across its borders.

However, Sweden’s openness on trade is held back by its relatively poor performance on agricultural subsidies, which rose from 11.5 to 12.6 percent of production value since the 2023 CDI while other countries’ subsidies fell (Sweden now ranks 22nd on this indicator, down from 19th). The forthcoming EU budget negotiations are an opportunity to reduce these subsidy levels. Sweden’s performance is also middling in its restrictiveness on trade in services across sectors, where it ranks 18th.
components.environment:
Sweden ranks 1st in the environment component. Sweden has the highest price on carbon emissions in the world at $72.57 per tonne, far above the CDI average of $15.23. Sweden’s direct and indirect greenhouse gas emissions also stand at 5.9 tonnes of CO₂ equivalent per capita, lower than the CDI average of 10.2 tonnes. Of this, the indirect emissions embodied in Swedish international trade are more than double the CDI average, indicating that Sweden displaces more emissions to other countries. Its fossil fuel production is also among the lowest five of CDI countries.

Sweden has a below-average performance in terms of financial support for the domestic consumption and production of fossil fuels. While it should reduce or eliminate its fossil fuel subsidies, it has instead markedly increased these over the last two editions of the CDI—more recently in response to energy price shocks resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. They are currently equivalent to 0.62 percent of Sweden’s GNI, and are particularly high for oil and coal.

Sweden provides a high level of harmful fishing subsidies, ranking 26th on this indicator. Sweden also has room to improve its participation in international biodiversity and environmental agreements and should update its implementation by reporting on the UN Convention to Combat Desertification.
components.health:
Sweden ranks 4th in the health component. It ranks in the top five for its efforts to tackle antimicrobial resistance (AMR): it has very low antibiotic consumption in humans and livestock, though it should complete a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization (WHO) to improve its performance on AMR governance. This, along with completing a Performance of Veterinary Services evaluation, would also contribute to its pandemic preparedness and response, for which it ranks joint 14th.

Sweden’s vaccination coverage puts it in the top half of countries but still short of WHO targets of 95 percent. Sweden participates in all seven health treaties, codes, and memberships that are considered by the CDI. As with other EU member states, it does relatively well in terms of its export restrictions on food and health products. Sweden ranks joint 5th for its regulation of international tobacco supply chains.
components.security:
Sweden ranks 6th in the security component, though after income adjusting its score, this falls by six ranks to 12th. It has ratified all nine security conventions we assess and contributes an above-average number of troops and volume of finance to global peacekeeping (equivalent to 0.036 percent of GNI), ranking 6th for its peacekeeping contributions overall. Women are marginally better represented in its UN peacekeeping forces—at 17 percent—than is average across the CDI (13 percent). Sweden also contributed to the protection of international sea lanes, ranking 17th on the indicator.

Sweden ranks mid-table for its arms exports: it exports more than the median CDI country (equivalent to 0.29 percent of GNI compared to 0.18 percent), but these exports are to countries that are assessed as being less conflict-prone than average.
components.technology:
Sweden ranks 19th in the technology component, up from 26th in the 2023 edition of the CDI, but still its weakest component. The Swedish government gives a higher-than-average level of funding directly to research and development (R&D), equivalent to 0.76 percent of GNI, and part of the effect driving the improvement in rank is an increase in the tax incentives Sweden provides for private R&D, more than doubling from 0.10 percent of GNI in implied subsidies to 0.22 percent.

Sweden should do more to diffuse its knowledge and technology to poorer countries by welcoming larger numbers of foreign students from these countries, and by giving greater representation to poorer country researchers in its international research collaborations. Furthermore, Sweden, alongside other EU member states, should make the intellectual property rights clauses in its free trade and investment agreements less restrictive, not going beyond existing World Trade Organization standards.

TUR.overall:
Türkiye ranks 32nd in the Commitment to Development Index. It performs strongly in the migration component, with the high number of refugees it hosts. It has significantly improved its performance on both health and technology since the 2023 CDI, increasing its position in each by 7 and 11 places, respectively. However, it still has significant scope to improve in the environment, trade, and security components, where it ranks in the bottom 10.

When we assess Türkiye relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank rises by five places to 27th.

components.development-finance:
Türkiye ranks 29th in the development finance component.

Türkiye’s Finance for International Development amounted to 0.22 percent of its GNI, just below the CDI average of 0.28 percent. This is well below the level of official development assistance (ODA) Türkiye reports because its reported ODA includes Türkiye’s substantial support for Syrian refugees within its borders. We give full credit for Türkiye’s refugee hosting in the migration component but exclude any domestic spend from our development finance measure.

Türkiye ranks in the bottom half of the table on development finance quality. Much of its support goes to Syria, and so it has a relatively strong focus on poorer and more fragile countries in its bilateral finance, and it reports on this finance regularly and transparently. However, it provides a very low proportion (4 percent) of its finance to the multilateral system relative to a CDI average of 47 percent. Its performance is also held back as there is insufficient published data to assess the extent to which Turkish finance is tied to the provision of goods and services from Turkish contractors, and the degree to which recipient countries report projects as aligning with their own priorities. Türkiye should make more data available in these areas to permit such assessments.
components.investment:
Türkiye ranks 29th in the investment component. It ranks in the top half of the table on the investment agreements indicator, which measures how countries perform in ensuring that their bilateral investment agreements do not restrict the policy space of their counterparts to pursue development objectives. Since the last CDI, it has increased its corporate tax rate in line with the developing country average of 25 percent (and well above the globally agreed minimum of 15 percent) and therefore receives the top score on that indicator.

Türkiye ranks near the bottom of the table on natural resources. It should strengthen its commitment to promoting good natural resource governance by supporting and implementing the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. Türkiye also ranks near the bottom of the table on the financial secrecy, business and human rights, and anticorruption indicators. It should improve its investment-related policies by adopting a National Action Plan for business and human rights, by enforcing the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and by requiring its multinational companies to submit annual country-by-country reports on their operations to limit corruption.
components.migration:
Türkiye ranks 12th in the migration component, a fall of nine places since the 2023 CDI, although it remains its best-performing component.

Türkiye continues to rank first on hosting refugees, with 37 refugees per 1,000 people. Despite a higher level of refugee hosting in other countries, this is still over three times the CDI average of 11 refugees per 1,000 people. However, Türkiye scored much less well on the migrant inflow indicator—the number of its migrants relative to its population has fallen below the average since the last CDI. Although they tended to be from lower-income countries than is the case in other CDI countries, Türkiye only ranked 25th on this indicator. The gender balance of its immigrants was one percentage point above the CDI average at 49 percent female.

Türkiye ranks in the bottom 10 countries on its migrant integration policies and has substantial room for improvement. On international conventions, Türkiye should ratify the International Labour Organization’s Migration for Employment Convention and Migrant Workers Convention, but it receives credit for undertaking a voluntary review of the UN Global Compact on Migration.
components.trade:
Türkiye ranks 32nd in the trade component. It ranks in the top 10 for agricultural subsidies, keeping them low at 2.9 percent of production, relative to the CDI average of 12.6 percent.

Türkiye performs less well on the other trade indicators. It can improve its trade-related commitment to development in several ways. It could lower its tariffs on imports from lower-income countries, where it ranks in the bottom 10 in terms of the level and the number of tariff peaks over 15 percent. It could improve its customs and trade infrastructure, where it ranks in the bottom 10 countries. These costs can be regressive, impeding imports from poorer countries. Türkiye could also lower its restrictions on services trade, where it also ranks in the bottom 10 countries.
components.environment:
Türkiye ranks 33rd in the environment component. Its greenhouse gas emissions are amongst the lowest in the CDI, with direct emissions of 6.4 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita compared to a CDI average of 9.1. Together with negative emissions from trade, and in land use change and forestry—meaning it acts as a carbon sink in this sector—this means it ranks in the top five on overall emissions. However, its ambitions for emissions reductions by 2030, as contained in its Nationally Determined Contribution, are above business-as-usual projections and the second least ambitious of all countries.

Türkiye is in the top half of the table on avoiding fossil fuel production. Despite relatively high coal production, its gas and oil production are well below the CDI average. Türkiye’s performance has improved as its financial support to fossil fuels has fallen relative to its economy size, and it now ranks in the top half on this indicator. It ranks joint last on carbon pricing, imposing no additional cost for emitting CO2, and joint second to last on the international biodiversity and environmental conventions indicator, signing up to and reporting on just three of the eight assessed in the CDI.

Türkiye should introduce emissions reduction plans with more ambition, implement carbon pricing mechanisms to reflect the costs of CO2 emissions to society, and ratify relevant environmental treaties.
components.health:
Türkiye ranks 31st in the health component, a rise of 7 places from the last CDI: it improved its pandemic preparedness by conducting a biological simulation exercise.

Türkiye has relatively effective regulation of international tobacco supply chains (ranking in the top 10 on the indicator), and ranks joint fourth on coverage of the diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine.

Türkiye should reduce the number of export restrictions it places on food and medical products, having implemented among the most of all CDI countries in the last two years. It should improve its antimicrobial resistance governance by completing a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization, and it should also work to update measures and lower the consumption of antibiotics in its population, where it appears to consume among the highest of any country in the CDI (45.6 defined daily doses per 1,000 people compared to the CDI average of 19.1).
components.security:
Türkiye ranks 36th in the security component. It performs well in its efforts in international sea lanes protection, contributing an equivalent of 0.015 percent of GNI in naval vessels and ranking in the top half on this indicator. Still, Türkiye ranks in the bottom half of the table on contributions to peacekeeping missions, with below-average financial and troop contributions to the UN compared to its CDI peers. It is also below average on the gender diversity of its peacekeepers, with only 8 percent of them female compared to a CDI average of nearly 13 percent.

Türkiye also ranks in the bottom 10 countries on arms trade. Its arms exports as a proportion of its GNI are above average among CDI peers, and the proportion of these exported to poor, militaristic, and undemocratic countries is among the highest of CDI countries. Türkiye has only fully ratified four of the nine security treaties assessed in the CDI. It should fully ratify the other five to contribute to the promotion of stronger international security norms and laws.
components.technology:
Türkiye ranks 28th in the technology component, an improvement of 11 places since the previous CDI mainly due to an increase in its effort on research and development (R&D). It performs well on international research collaboration, with a higher incidence of researchers from poorer countries in its international research teams, meaning it ranks fifth on this indicator. It also performs in the top half of countries on the intellectual property rights indicator, indicating that the restrictions it includes in bilateral free trade agreements do not go as far beyond the standard World Trade Organization protections as in many other CDI countries.

However, Türkiye has improved its technology-related policies with greater government support for R&D, although it still ranks in the bottom half of countries on this measure, as both direct budgetary allocations to research and tax breaks on business R&D as a share of GNI are significantly below CDI averages. It could also welcome more foreign students from poorer countries and ensure women are well represented among them, as the share of female students is lower than in almost all other CDI countries, at just 37 percent.

USA.overall:
The United States ranks 28th in the Commitment to Development Index. Its strongest-performing areas are trade (10th) and security (17th). On development finance, it performed in the bottom half of countries even before the Trump administration took office and instigated the dismantling of USAID, substantial terminations of aid grants and contracts, and a recissions package that withdrew almost $8 billion for foreign assistance previously approved by Congress. More broadly, the US has most room for improvement relative to other donors on environment (36th), technology (33rd), health (32nd), and migration (26th).

When we assess the US relative to expectations based on its income level, its rank falls by 10 places, to 38th. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
The US ranks 25th on development finance, and after adjusting its score for its relatively high income, this falls by 14 ranks to 38th. The data used in this assessment predates the Trump administration, which, after taking office, proposed steep cuts to finance volumes and cancelled many foreign assistance awards while also terminating large swathes of experienced staff, which is likely to significantly affect the quality of aid.

While the United States was the largest foreign aid donor in the world in absolute terms, based on 2024 data, the country provided just 0.18 percent of its GNI in cross-border, grant-equivalent Finance for International Development compared to a CDI average of 0.28 percent—putting it in the bottom half of the table on development finance quantity.

The quality of that finance has deteriorated since our last assessment, down from 13th to 28th. Though US finance is very transparent and aligns well with its partner countries’ development objectives, its focus on poorer and more fragile countries has fallen. In addition, US finance is somewhat tied to bids from US contractors. Inhibiting its effectiveness. The share of finance channelled through multilateral institutions has also dropped to 14 percent from 24 percent two years ago.
components.investment:
The US ranks 18th on investment, though after income adjusting its score, it falls by 13 ranks to 31st.

The US ranks joint 1st on anticorruption, with active enforcement of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention as assessed by Transparency International. It contributes to improved governance of natural resource investment (ranking joint 4th on this indicator) by participating in the Kimberley Process and supporting the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. Its bilateral international investment agreements leave significant policy space for developing country counterparts to pursue their own development objectives (ranking 8th). The US also performs well on business and human rights, implementing the OECD guidelines on multinational enterprises (ranking joint 8th).

However, the US ranks last on limiting financial secrecy. It is rated “non-compliant” on the Financial Action Task Force’s beneficial ownership assessment, does not require its multinational firms to produce country-by-country reports, and has no provisions for automatic exchange of information with other governments. It is also the only country assessed in the CDI not to have ratified the Council of Europe / OECD Multilateral Tax Convention. The Trump administration has also withdrawn its commitments to the OECD Pillar Two framework (which was negotiated by the Biden administration and attempts to limit base erosion and profit shifting by multinational enterprises), and although agreement for a “side-by-side system” has been reached within the G7 as of June 2025, concerns remain about potential retaliatory measures and how this will impact global confidence in the application of a global minimum tax.
components.migration:
The US ranks 26th on migration, though the Trump administration has introduced significant changes to US migration policy that are not captured here and are likely to result in a deterioration in its score on this component.

The US welcomes fewer migrants from lower-income countries relative to its population than most CDI countries, ranking 30th on this indicator. It also welcomes comparatively few refugees—1.3 per 1,000 people (below the CDI mean of 11). Still, its score is improved by the gender balance of migrants it accepts, ranking in the top five on the proportion of migrants it hosts that are female (55 percent compared to a CDI average of 48 percent). Its policies for integrating migrants into its society and the economy as assessed in 2020 were relatively strong (ranked 6th).

The US ranks joint last on its participation in international migrant conventions and could improve by performing a voluntary review under the Global Compact for Migration, and ratifying the International Labour Organization Conventions on Migration for Employment and Migrant Workers to protect the rights of its migrant workers.
components.trade:
The US ranks 10th on trade based on data relating mainly to 2023, and before the Trump administration adopted a new series of shifting reciprocal and sector-specific tariffs. This approach is likely to have detrimental effects on its lower-income trading partners.

The US has high quality customs and trade infrastructure, ranking joint 14th on trade logistics, and it has relatively unrestricted trade in services, ranking 16th. It performs in the top half of countries in terms of avoiding trade-distorting agricultural subsidies, providing an equivalent of 6.3 percent of farm gate production as subsidies to domestic farmers, and lower than the CDI average of 12.6 percent.

The US’s average tariff rates (when weighted inversely to trading partner income) are higher than the CDI median and it also has more tariff peaks (rates of 15 percent or more), ranking 24th and 25th, respectively. As the US implements its new trade regime, it should consider the impact on the poorest countries, and consider extending the African Growth and Opportunity Act, which expires at the end of September and provides duty-free treatment for select goods produced in qualifying sub-Saharan African countries.
components.environment:
The US ranks 36th on environment, making this its weakest component.

The US performs poorly—ranking last—on its participation in international biodiversity and environmental agreements, which incorporates its latest withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement.

The US also ranks near the bottom of the table (36th) for its high greenhouse gas emissions, with 18.5 tonnes of CO₂ equivalent per capita emitted directly from its energy, industry, waste, and agriculture (excluding land use and forestry), an increase of 0.5 tonnes since the last CDI and now double the CDI average of 9.1 tonnes (all based on 2023 data). The US did have high ambitions for reducing this, ranking within the top five on climate target ambition: based on its Nationally Determined Contribution, the previous administration planned to reduce emissions by 45 percent relative to 2030 projections of business-as-usual.

The US also ranks well—within the top five—for giving low levels of support to fossil fuels. However, it performs less well on carbon pricing, with just $1.27 added to the cost of emitting an average tonne of CO2 countrywide, against a CDI average of $15.23. It also ranks 33rd on fossil fuel production, producing large amounts of oil, gas, and coal relative to the size of its population.

The US could improve its environmental performance by rejoining the Paris climate accord, fully participating in and ratifying all biodiversity and environmental agreements and treaties assessed in the CDI, reducing fossil fuel production and greenhouse gas emissions, and implementing an ambitious nationwide carbon pricing scheme to incentivise a reduction in fossil fuel use.
components.health:
The US ranks 32nd on health.

It ranks joint 6th on pandemic preparedness, as it has completed a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization (WHO) and has developed a national influenza plan in the last decade. The US also ranks well on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) at 8th—it does well on AMR governance according to its recent WHO Joint Evaluation Exercise but should look to reduce its above-average levels of antibiotic consumption per capita (of 22.8 defined daily doses per 1,000 people vs the CDI average of 19.2).

The US ranks 38th on its participation in health treaties, codes, and memberships, and it ranks joint last on regulating international tobacco supply chains. It also does poorly on the degree to which it places export restrictions on food and health-related goods, ranking 35th, with restrictions affecting over 50 product lines over the last two years (most countries applied 12 or fewer).

The US could improve its health-related performance by signing onto the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants and Basel Convention on Hazardous Waste, and the WHO’s Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System module on antimicrobial consumption, as well as fully implementing its commitments under the International Code on Marketing of Breast Milk Substitutes.
components.security:
The US ranks 17th on security.

The US ranks 1st on sea lanes protection by a significant margin, contributing an equivalent of 0.2 percent of its GNI in naval vessels protecting international waters, as compared to a CDI average of 0.019 percent, and with the next-best country, the Netherlands, providing less than half as much at 0.09 percent. It ranks in the bottom 10 on peacekeeping contributions – whilst providing large numbers of troops to non-UN but internationally approved missions, its financial contributions to the UN Department of Peacekeeping Operations have been declining in both absolute and relative terms. Of the UN peacekeepers it deploys, only 10 percent are women, which is slightly below the CDI country average of 13 percent.

However, the US ranks 35th—joint with China—on its participation in international security treaties. It also ranks mid-table for its arms trade, with a higher-than-average volume of exports relative to its GNI (0.23 percent against a CDI median of 0.18 percent)—though these exports are sold to less poor, more democratic, and less militaristic states, which are assessed as less conflict-prone, than the CDI average.
components.technology:
The US ranks 33rd in the technology component, with performance in the top half on technology creation, but lower-than-average performance on most policies for technology diffusion.

In its policies to stimulate technology production, the US ranks 12th on government support for research and development (R&D) by allocating 0.65 percent of GNI directly to R&D (above the CDI average of 0.55 percent), and it ranks 28th on tax incentives by providing the equivalent of 0.07 percent of its GNI as subsidies to private researchers in 2023, a decrease from 0.16 percent in 2021 and below the CDI average of 0.19 percent.

On its policies to encourage technology diffusion, the US ranks in the top 10 on research collaboration: US researchers were more likely to collaborate with researchers from lower-income countries than for most CDI countries. But it ranks mid-table on the numbers of foreign students it welcomes from poorer countries, and among the bottom of the table on the proportion of these that are female (45 percent against a CDI average of 49 percent). The intellectual property rights (IPR) provisions that the US includes in its free trade agreements are significantly more restrictive than those contained in the standard World Trade Organization provisions, and it ranks 38th for this indicator.

The US could improve on the technology component by welcoming more students, especially women, and reducing the stringency of the IPR provisions in its trade agreements to facilitate greater international flow of knowledge.

ZAF.overall:
South Africa ranks 29th on the Commitment to Development Index, and it is the best performer amongst the BRICS+ countries we assess. South Africa’s strongest component is security, where it ranks 9th, while it has the most room for improvement on the migration component—for which it ranks 34th.

When we assess South Africa’s performance relative to expectations based on its income, it jumps to 13th place. Full income-adjusted results are at the end of the country report.

components.development-finance:
South Africa ranks 28th in the development finance component, rising to 12th after adjusting for income. It performs better on the quality of the finance it provides than the quantity.

South Africa ranks in the bottom 10 countries for the quantity of Finance for International Development it provides, contributing just 0.02 percent of its GNI as grant-equivalent cross-border development finance (under a tenth of the CDI average of 0.28 percent) with a significant fall in multilateral commitments since the 2023 CDI.

In terms of quality indicators, South Africa comes in the bottom half of countries. It does well in ensuring that its finance targets partners who face more severe development challenges, ranking in the top five on each of the fragility and poverty focus measures. South Africa also channels the majority—62 percent—of its development finance via multilateral institutions. However, its finance was mostly tied and less transparent than average. No data was available to assess the extent to which its development finance is provided in accordance with the priorities of its partner countries.
components.investment:
South Africa ranks 32nd on investment.

South Africa has signed on to the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention—one of the few non-OECD members to have done so—but its enforcement is rated as “limited” by Transparency International. South Africa should also improve its commitment to business and human rights standards by drafting a relevant national action plan. It should improve its natural resource investment standards by implementing the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative.

South Africa has improved its efforts to address financial secrecy since our last assessment. The Financial Action Task Force’s rating of South Africa’s rules regarding disclosure of the beneficial ownership of legal persons improved from “partially compliant” to “largely compliant.” That said, South Africa still has scope to improve on financial secrecy, particularly on banking secrecy, publishing of public statistics, and anti-money laundering.

South Africa’s strongest indicator is corporate tax alignment, with its lowest available corporate income tax rate set at 28 percent, which is above both the globally agreed minimum of 15 percent and the developing country average of 25 percent.
components.migration:
South Africa ranks 34th in the migration component, falling 17 places since the last edition.

South Africa has dropped significantly in terms of the number of migrants from lower-income countries it receives.
