It was top on this indicator based on data in the 2023 CDI, but has now dropped to 31st—inward migrants still tend to be from lower-income countries, but updated UN data suggests South Africa has accepted fewer than 1 migrant per 1,000 inhabitants annually between 2020 and 2024, relative to a CDI average of 11. There is also a significant gender gap among its immigrants: only 42 percent of immigrants are female relative to a CDI average of 48.

South Africa also ranks in the bottom half of the table on refugee hosting, with 1.1 refugees per 1,000 people.

South Africa could also improve its commitment to migration for development by ratifying the International Labour Organization’s Migration for Employment Convention and Migrant Workers Convention.
components.trade:
South Africa ranks 30th in the trade component. It performs well in limiting its trade-distorting agricultural subsidies to just 0.7 percent of farm gate production value, which is considerably lower than the CDI average of 12.6 percent.

However, South Africa has significant room for improvement in reducing its tariffs against lower-income countries, where it ranks in the bottom five countries we assess. It is also in the bottom half of countries on the quality of its trade logistics.

Following the OECD’s latest assessment, South Africa has reduced restrictions on trade in its services, moving out of the bottom 10 on this indicator.
components.environment:
South Africa ranks 27th in the environment component, with relatively low greenhouse gas emissions, but it has significant room for improvement on other indicators in the environment component.

South Africa’s current direct greenhouse gas emissions amount to 7.7 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per capita, under the average across CDI countries of 9.1. However, its embodied emissions in trade are negative, meaning that some of South Africa’s direct emissions are emitted in goods consumed within other countries, and so its net emissions are lower than most (rank 5th).

Based on its Nationally Determined Contribution, by 2030, South Africa plans to reduce emissions by 25 percent relative to projections based on its expected economic growth, placing it 33rd on the climate target ambition indicator.

South Africa ranks in the bottom 10 countries on fossil fuel production, almost entirely in coal, and is in the bottom half of countries on fossil fuel support, with relatively high subsidies given to coal and oil production. It remains to be seen whether the South Africa Just Energy Transition Partnership announced in 2021 will accelerate the transition away from coal.

South Africa also ranks in the bottom half of the table on its participation in international biodiversity and environmental agreements. It is not a member of the International Tropical Timber Organisation but since the last CDI it has accepted the World Trade Organization Agreement on Fisheries Subsidies.
components.health:
South Africa ranks 27th in the health component. It scores strongly on both pandemic preparedness and its commitment to treaties but scores poorly on vaccination rates, preventing antimicrobial resistance, and regulating tobacco trade.

Since our last edition of the CDI, South Africa has received credit for signing on to report antimicrobial resistance (AMR) reporting on consumption through the Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System. It also tops the indicator on health treaties and codes, having signed up to all seven we assess. Still, the newly available data suggests a very high level of human antibiotic use, and despite progress on governance of AMR, South Africa ranks in the bottom five on preventing AMR.

South Africa also ranks in the bottom five countries on tobacco supply chains, having not yet signed onto the Protocol against Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products. It has low vaccination coverage for both measles (84 percent compared to a median of 92 percent) and for diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis (79 percent compared to a median of 95 percent).

South Africa scores well for its efforts to prepare for pandemics, having completed a Joint External Evaluation with the World Health Organization (WHO), and an assessment of its veterinary services with the World Organisation for Animal Health. It should also update its National Influenza Plan and complete a more recent simulation exercise with the WHO.

South Africa has largely refrained from implementing trade restrictions on food and health products in the last two years.
components.security:
South Africa ranks 9th in the security component, rising to 3rd when adjusting for its income—its best performance. It ranks joint 1st on its participation in international security conventions.

South Africa contributes 0.026 percent of its GNI to peacekeeping efforts, more than the CDI average of 0.019 percent. South Africa also performs better than the CDI average on the gender diversity of its UN peacekeepers, ranking 9th on this indicator with 19 percent of its UN peacekeepers being female.

South Africa ranked 9th for its arms trade: the value of its arms exports was below the CDI average relative to the size of its economy, and its arms sales were just below the CDI average in terms of being sold to countries at higher risk of conflict—those which are poor, militaristic, or undemocratic.
components.technology:
South Africa ranks 14th in the technology component, rising to 7th after adjusting for its income.

Although its government spends relatively little on research and development—0.32 percent of its GNI as compared to the CDI average of 0.55 percent—it scores well across indicators which measure its commitment to the diffusion and transfer of technology.

South Africa performs well in ensuring that its international research collaborations include researchers from lower-income countries, ranking 2nd on this indicator. South Africa also ranks joint 4th on intellectual property rights, having fewer restrictions in its free trade agreements that go beyond existing World Trade Organization standards. South Africa welcomes a relatively low number of foreign students, though these are the most likely to come from poorer countries. It should continue to focus on improving the gender ratio: only 47 percent of foreign students are female, and while this is lower than the CDI average of 49 percent, it does represent an improvement since five years prior when the proportion was 44 percent.
